name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, I have asked you to intervene because I would like to point out that a new education law has recently been adopted in Ukraine.It is a law that annuls rights.Between these annulled rights and those for the communities of Romanians who lose the freedoms they had.It is about the right to education in Romanian.They will be able to learn this language only in the first four years of school and not later.Romanian is one of the European languages and I think that Ukraine made a big mistake by canceling these rights.I would ask you to intervene on this issue so that Ukraine can make amends.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to support Mr Preda in raising the issue of the recently-adopted new law on education in Ukraine and its Article 7, which determines the language of education and which restricts the existing rights of national minorities at secondary and higher level to get education in their mother tongue. The Article limits existing rights and eliminates well—functioning minority language school systems, which have worked very well so far. I do not think that Parliament has dealt with this issue with adequate attention. I would therefore kindly like to ask you, Mr President, to address the issue, because preserving language diversity is a European value and the right to a mother tongue is a basic human right. So I would like to ask you to consider this question and to deal with it very carefully.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this is now a sort of dismal tradition when we start the plenary in Strasbourg. We are confronted with the news of new human disasters and natural catastrophes. This time it is the terrible earthquake in Iran and Iraq, with a death toll of hundreds. As Chair of the Delegation for Relations with Iran, I am coming forward immediately with a letter of deep condolences to be sent to the people of Iran. Whatever the politics of contemporary Iran, this is a matter of human solidarity and it is at your discretion, Mr President, how to express our compassion – the compression of the European Parliament – for the people affected. (Applause)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to inform you and the body that Turkey and the occupying regime continue to ban the transfer of humanitarian aid to my heroically trapped compatriots, who have been refusing to leave their land and homes for 43 years. It is an unacceptable, overt and provocative act that violates human rights, violates the treaty signed with the Third Vienna Agreement but also every principle of International and European Law. It is inconceivable today, in 2017, for the European Union to continue to support with pre-accession assistance and other facilities this country that does not respect any authority inside and outside Turkey. We must take the initiative and send a clear message: attitudes like that of Turkey, which violate principles and values, which violate European principles and our ideals, cannot be tolerated by the European Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: The final draft agenda, set for the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules, at its meeting on Wednesday 8 November 2017, was distributed.The following proposed amendments were presented: Monday The ENF group asked to add as the first item to the agenda for Monday afternoon, ie today, the Council and Commission statements on the earthquake in Iran and Iraq.I give the floor to the Hon.Franz Obermayr to submit the request on behalf of his group.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! Letters of condolence are good, but help is better. It affects a region on both sides of the border: Iraq and Iran. With an earthquake strength of 7.3 on the Richter scale, both regions are affected. There are around 340 fatalities and 4,000 injured on the Iranian side. The cities of Erbil, Halabja and Duhok on the Kurdish side in Iraq are also badly affected. I think the extent of the disaster is unknown and I think we should talk about how the Union should intervene on both sides here. I think it would be a good way for the Union to act here, not only in humanitarian terms but also, of course, in a proper diplomatic mediator role. Because this region is not very stable anyway, and it is precisely this earthquake that can contribute to further destabilization. This is where the Union can make a significant contribution to helping in this emergency situation.

name: Presidente. –
text: The ENF group called for the Council and Commission statements on the Black Monday protests in South Africa to be added as the first item to the agenda on Monday afternoon.I give the floor to the Hon.Atkinson to formulate the request on behalf of his group.

name: Janice Atkinson
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, last week the ENF Group put forward the situation in South Africa as one of the topics for urgent debate on cases of breaches of human rights. Unfortunately, this proposal was rejected, but the situation remains extremely serious. I was in South Africa on Monday 30 October, when thousands of South Africans were standing up to crime. They were mourning together, wearing black, in memory of those who have died in violent crimes, including farmers. At least 72 people have died in farm attacks in South Africa since the start of this year. Being a farmer in South Africa is one of the most dangerous professions in the world and it is not just farmers who are at risk. Every day, an average of 52 people are murdered in South Africa, and there are huge concerns about the functioning of the police. Strangely enough, this does not seem to be an issue for the international community. My proposal is to have a debate on this issue, on a statement from the Commission and the Council, as the first item on the agenda this evening. However, I do not actually hold out much hope because Members are just going to vote against it because it is us. Think about the human rights atrocities that are happening across the globe – and that includes South Africa – and I challenge you to turn down this proposal!

name: Presidente. –
text: For Tuesday, I would like to inform you that: The EFDD Group has asked for the Council and Commission statements on the situation in Catalonia to be added as a second item to the agenda for Tuesday morning.Consequently, the report by Hon.Sehnalová on cooperation between national authorities responsible for enforcing consumer protection legislation will be moved to Tuesday afternoon and voted on Wednesday.I give the floor to the Hon.Carver to formulate his group's request.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, whilst many in this place wish that the democratic tragedy which has befallen Catalonia would just go away, this is not the time to act like the proverbial ostrich by burying our heads in the sand. We have witnessed the blatant misuse of the European Arrest Warrant for political purposes, something that my party, UKIP, has warned about for many years. If this Parliament really does have any teeth, then colleagues will vote in support of my motion to add a debate on the situation of democracy and the rule of law in Spain to this week’s agenda. If we do not do so, then never again will Members have the moral right to preach about self-determination and democratic rights, not least when the situation in Malta and Poland will be debated this week. So the argument for refusing on the grounds of avoiding interference in the home affairs of a Member State does not stand. What is good for the goose must be good for the gander, as we say my country. As I have said before, the eyes of the world are on us and it is high time to put the concerns of the Catalonian people before the internal politics of some of the political groups in this Chamber. I also call for this vote to be roll-called.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mr Carver is a promoter of Brexit. Therefore, he does not have to surprise us that he promotes as many debates as possible that divide the European Union. That is not our case. We are not going to vote on his proposal, but I am going to give you two more arguments. The European arrest warrant ... (the president calls for order) ... Those who do not know how to listen are appealing to democracy. They should first learn to listen and then use the name of democracy. The European arrest warrant is issued by a judge; it has been issued by a judge in Spain. And it is resolved by a judge; a judge in Belgium is going to solve it. Neither this Parliament nor any Parliament is the one to tell a judge what he should do. If we start censoring the judges in this Parliament, we are going to end the division of powers in Europe. Nor do we have to criticize what a judge does in Spain, nor do we have to condition what a judge is going to do in Belgium. Let the judges decide for themselves without telling them in Parliament what to do. That is not democracy. And I finish, Mr. President, with a second argument. In Catalonia there is an electoral campaign. On December 21 there will be a decisive election. Everyone shows up and everyone can vote. Let us not condition the elections from this Parliament. Let each country and each region have their autonomy. Let's not impose Europe, and less at the request of those who want to destroy it.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there is a human rights abuse occurring within the borders of the European Union itself. EU citizens who work for the European Patents Office are in dispute with the EPO but are being denied legal redress. This is a contravention of their most basic human right. Courts in Germany and the Netherlands have found substance in their claim, but the EPO hides behind its sovereign immunity to avoid coming to terms. Now this is bad enough, but the EU is about to hand over judicial functions to the EPO under the Unified Patent Convention. We have to establish that no organisation within the EU has the right to abrogate observance of citizens’ basic human rights. So I urge the House to support this motion for a debate, and I believe that you are going to grant a roll-call vote, Mr President, to decide whether this is added to the agenda or not.

name: Искра Михайлова
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, the principles of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 emphasize that the approach to promoting smart, sustainable and inclusive growth must reflect the role of urban agglomerations and urban , rural and coastal areas and to take into account the links between rural and urban areas in the European Union. Eurostat publishes European statistical information at regional level in a number of statistical domains in accordance with Regulation (EC) № 1059/2003 establishing a common classification of territorial units for statistical purposes. This information is widely used in the context of the European Union's regional policy. In recent years, Eurostat has expanded the scope of published statistical information to include certain territorial typologies to meet the growing need for relevant information. The Commission has identified these territorial typologies in cooperation with the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development and has adopted a methodology for their establishment and maintenance, in particular for the degree of urbanization, including the identification of urban agglomerations. However, this regulation does not yet cover territorial typologies, and the current proposal we are considering today is addressing this issue. The proposal would allow data aggregation based on typologies. For example, gross domestic product in rural and urban areas can be compared and employment can be measured according to the level of urbanization. The proposal aims to establish legal recognition of territorial typologies, including the definition of urban agglomerations, for the purposes of European Statistics. The necessary for the calculation of the territorial typological and statistical coordinate networks, based on the distribution and density of the population in the individual cells of the coordinate network, which serve as a basis for the calculation of the territorial typologies. The role and names of the local administrative units, LAU level, are also explained. The proposal also contains provisions giving the Commission the power to adopt delegated acts to adapt the NUTS classification. The Committee on Regional Development in the European Parliament, having regard to the need to amend, detail and update the classification of territorial units for the collection, compilation and dissemination of regional statistics, adopted the proposed dossier under a simplified procedure, without any additions by the Commission. During the trialogue, technical improvements proposed by the Council were adopted by the Council, Parliament and the European Commission. There are two preconditions that need to be emphasized when considering this dossier. The proposed changes and improvements in the typology do not predetermine the identification of specific areas for European Union policy intervention. Some of the proposed territorial typologies are already in use. The proposed system is more flexible and offers a network of types of regions at NUTS level and at LAU level in combination and allows for the collection, analysis and dissemination of statistics to distinguish urban, rural, urban with additional areas, metropolises, suburbs. The establishment of statistical networks at European Union level will allow harmonization of data collection and analysis. In addition, certain terminologically sound definitions are introduced, such as "urban centers", "urban clusters", "rural networks", "urban areas", "densely populated areas", "cities and densely populated areas", "cities and suburbs". No effect is foreseen on the European Union budget and I, as rapporteur, propose that Parliament adopt the Commission proposal.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, rapporteur, honourable Members, I wish to thank, first of all, the rapporteur Ms Mihaylova, and the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive approach to the proposal. Following fruitful cooperation between the three institutions, in particular at the trilogue, I believe we have reached our common objective. Regions in the European Union are very diverse. We see that regions with urban characteristics sometimes work very differently from rural regions and face different challenges. While urban regions often offer better economic opportunities and infrastructure, they might face problems like pollution, traffic congestion, crime and overcrowding. Rural regions, on the other hand, often lack infrastructure. These differences can also be observed when it comes to coastal regions, in which a large share of GDP is generated by the blue or ocean-centric economy. Tercet will help our understanding of these phenomena by aggregating pre-existing data by typology. By doing so, it will back socio-economic territorial analysis and help to shape good evidence-based policy. The proposal is quite timely as it, for instance, includes a definition of cities that helps support the implementing of the urban agenda and city-focused policy. As of now, there is no agreed legal definition of what a city actually is in Union law and this, as we all know, hinders a common understanding of the term and leads to the risk that we might not speak about the same thing when we talk about cities. To ensure a harmonised use of the term and a consistent application, it is vital that we achieve an unambiguous interpretation of the concept of cities, and of course the same applies for rural areas.

name: Андрей Новаков
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Mihaylova on her hard work on this report. When we talk about territorial typologies, I believe that we need even more detailed and detailed comparable information with which to know the exact level of development of each region, urban agglomeration, city or small settlement. This will help us to better refine the legislation and to choose a better policy for a given settlement. I believe you will all agree with me that each region has specifics that require an individual approach. Having said that, I believe that after 2020, cohesion policy funding must rise to NUTS3 level. We should not allow small settlements to become hostages of large and developed cities near them and therefore to be an inadmissible beneficiary under the operational programs. Moreover, we need to add more criteria to our funding approach: the level of infrastructure development and the social index, not just gross domestic product. Moreover, when an important transport corridor for the European Union passes through a region, I believe that the main burden of funding must fall on the European Union. We cannot count on small settlements to co-finance large projects on an equal footing with all other beneficiaries.

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D Club. - Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur on the encouraging report. We know that Eurostat publishes a wide range of regional statistics in accordance with the Regulation establishing a common classification of spatial units for statistics, more popularly speaking NUTS. These statistics are widely used in decision-making at the level of regional policy of the European Union and in determining the type of support from the Cohesion Fund for which European regions can apply. The current regulation on NUTS does not yet cover spatial typologies, this issue is addressed by this proposal. Spatial typologies are also usable in the European Statistical System, in particular the degree of urbanization and the definition of cities. An example of this is the establishment of conditions for funding from the European Regional Development Fund, for the implementation of innovative measures in larger and smaller cities or suburbs. However, the ESS still does not officially recognize these typologies due to their uncertain legal status. The explanatory memorandum to the Commission's proposals rightly states that territorial typologies have a major impact on regional policies, they provide useful evidence that can help shape adequate proposals and more integrated territorial approaches. This would properly respect the diversity of the European Union's regions. We need more statistics because of the indisputably significant differences between the types of territories, which are not always the same in the Member States. Responding to this need, the proposed regulation aims to legally identify regional typologies at NUTS 3 level, local government units and network cells, in order to integrate them into the existing NUTS Regulation. The proposed territorial typologies of labels are mainly: urban, rural, urban and coastal areas. This will allow thematic statistical regulations and poles initiatives to collect European statistics through territorial typologies in order to effectively determine the needs of individual areas in a fact-based way. I support the initiative, which therefore seeks to establish spatial typologies for the purposes of European Statistics, thus ensuring a harmonized and transparent application at the level of the European Union and the Member States, based on the definition and statistical criteria. However, the division into cities, rural, urban and coastal areas is not comprehensive, this was an excellent opportunity to recognize spatial typologies and European islands with more than 17 million inhabitants and whose special status is already recognized by Article 174 of the Lisbon Treaty. Islanders rightly question how adequate policies can be created for islands at all if their status is not territorially recognized. One of the big problems of all the initiatives we are trying to implement is the lack of statistics on which to base them. The application of island-level statistics would provide a thorough overview of the characteristics of these areas, many of which are common, regardless of the geographical location, size or level of development of the island. Such data should be comparable to other areas of typology and would greatly facilitate the development of targeted provisions of European Union legislation whenever necessary. Insularity as a factor that increases transport costs, reduces security of energy supply, makes access to education more difficult and significantly limits access to the labor market, is a very well-known term for everyone living on the islands - it is time to respect it at European level. The adoption of this Proposal is a good step forward, but we must continue to work on its improvement in order to really prove in practice the unity in our territorial diversity.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam President, the spatial typologies that have been used for years by this regulation will be included in the legal system of the Union, so in the future we will be able to count on more accurate statistics according to which many European policies are tailored. I believe that this will lead to a re-examination of some previous statistical divisions in order to make even better use of funds. I will take the example of Croatia, which is divided into two NUTS II regions, in such a way that some of the poorest parts of Pannonian Croatia are placed in the same region with the most developed northwestern part of the country, making it difficult for them to access funds. Of course, this must be corrected. I am satisfied that with this proposal some non-administrative units will be able to deviate from the established thresholds due to special geographical, socio-economic, historical, cultural or environmental circumstances. This is particularly important for islands where we need to further facilitate participation in the funds in order to prevent further depopulation and reduce the economic marginalization of the island population.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking my esteemed colleague Iskra Mihaylova, Chair of the Committee on Regional Development, for her contribution to this report and for informing us of the Commission's intentions. And of course, I would like to immediately emphasize my support for this step forward, which the Commission wants to make with this act, and highlight the three principles that I believe are really important and embedded in this document, namely data accuracy, consistency in approach to terminology, comparability when we are talking, for example, about gross domestic product. So, all these principles are extremely important to me and that is why I believe that in this way the territorial typologies we have, as a proposal for a new concept in some way, will really see the light of day in a far better way than it is today. I have some experience about it as a former Istrian prefect. I know what the problems are in the division of regions into NUTS regions and what the situation was, for example, in our country, in Croatia, when we divided Croatia, we tried to make a fair division of NUTS regions. We have really serious problems here. And that is why I support the introduction of a local government unit, because I believe that in this way we will be able to conduct cohesion policy even better and that we will have better data, more accurate statistics so that we can make better decisions and better and more help different regions. help and how they need it. What I want to point out in the end are two things. Firstly, I would like to offer the Commission the experience that Croatia has when it comes to collecting data in tourism. Tourism is important for Croatia, but Croatia has excellent experience in collecting data when we talk about the tourism industry. And secondly, let us not forget that the goals of cohesion policy have not yet succeeded. We have not yet achieved cohesion policy properly in our Parliament, and that is why I call on the Commission to do everything possible on this occasion to make cohesion policy better than it is today.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Madam Commissioner, this new modification of sub-national territorial units redefines the territorial grid of sub-regional levels by delimiting them in particular in urban, peri-urban and rural areas, and by integrating the new metropolitan poles which are emerging. All this is very good and seems to pave the way for a reinforced urban policy for the future post-2020 cohesion policy. However, I hope that all these efforts made to establish a new territorial reading grid, the usefulness of which is beyond doubt, will also be accompanied by statistical data, also reinforced and ever more precise, concerning in particular the network of social inequalities in the scale of the European Union as well as concerning urban poverty - data which is sorely lacking in the 7th Cohesion Report and without which it is very difficult to analyze the way in which European policies meet the objective of cohesion. I believe that these data will help us to defend the cohesion policy which is so often attacked today.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission proposes to make changes to the current legislation on territorial typologies and gives them legal recognition, including a definition of cities, for the purposes of European statistics. I welcome this proposal because it would allow data to be aggregated by typology, and therefore we could compare the GDP of rural and urban areas and measure employment according to the degree of urbanization. This information is important when planning future policies and making strategic responses. I believe that the whole discussion on the allocation criteria must have a fundamental place in the negotiations of the future cohesion policy, which I hope we will start in May-June 2018. In setting the post-2020 framework, the Commission is considering the development of new criteria that make it possible to identify the territories facing demographic challenges. We believe, as the Regional Development Committee itself suggests in several reports, that GDP and population density are not sufficient indicators. Other indicators under the three general dimensions of social progress, basic human needs, foundations of well-being and opportunities would allow for a better understanding of economic and social challenges across Europe.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Today we are talking about spending billions of euros in tax money.And to be able to judge that, you actually need experience with earning real money in business or as an entrepreneur, because only then will you know what the burden of tax is.The colleagues here are mainly experienced in getting money from government or semi-government relations.So what I would like to advise colleagues: first gain some experience in the business world or as an entrepreneur and then come back before throwing billions of euros in tax money back here with a few pen strokes.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - Let me congratulate you at the outset on your work, both on the part of the Commission and the rapporteur, and express my support for the proposed document, which aims to improve the territorial typology, ie to have better information on what we are actually doing. on the ground is happening. We live in a time of digitalization, in a time of a lot of information and we can always process this information better and better. Regional development must not happen spontaneously, because if it happens spontaneously without influencing it, it will continue to happen to us that we will have growing problems that are happening both in urban centers and in rural areas. On the one hand, as already mentioned, overpopulation, daily migrations, air pollution, on the other hand, depopulation of the countryside, less economic activity and many environmental problems in the countryside. Recently, a lot has been happening in the field of organizing processes in cities within the so-called smart cities, and some of us have recently launched activities around smart villages, that is, organizing processes in rural areas, processes where we will be with everyone information, which we will also get with better Eurostat data, can raise the quality of life in rural areas, in cities and also the coexistence of these important cells of our society. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Madam President!I would like to ask Mr Bogovič: the statistics are supposed to show us where improvements can be made.In regional development, of course, we have a great opportunity to make better use of research infrastructure, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.Do you think that these statistics mean that this situation can be improved?

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- Certainly, with more data and also with the guidelines that we also implement within the framework of smart specialization, it is possible to combine the potentials that the regions have, to create a synergy of these potentials on the one hand from institutions, research,which are a generator of innovation, on the other hand, we also connect small businesses, medium-sized enterprises, local communities and the population.And I am convinced that this is the right direction and that in this way we will make Europe more prosperous and also more prosperous regions.(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Ms. President!Honorable Member, you mentioned smart cities and even smart villages, and so you, as a former mayor, a later Minister of Agriculture, have a great deal of experience.Therefore, I would like to ask if you are satisfied with the typological state that exists today.In terms of villages, I don’t really see much yet what the exact definition would be in the European nomenclature.Where would you go next in this regard?

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- As I have already said, and thank you Tibor for this issue, we are working together in the field of smart villages and by obtaining additional information, additional data, we will be able to really intervene in these micro-problems, which are sometimes very important.Today, within a single NUTS 3 unit, let alone in larger NUTS 2 units, there are so many different micro locations, micro problems, that we simply do not detect enough of them.In this way, when we reduce this territorial coverage to smaller units, we will certainly have input data with which we will be able to better and more effectively manage the problems on these micro units.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteur, thank you for your work. Dear colleagues, the problem of depopulation is common in several countries of the European Union that see how their population, year after year and for decades, has been concentrated in cities, to the detriment of rural areas and towns. In Spain, of course - my country - it is a particularly pressing problem, and even the Government itself has created the figure of the Commissioner against the Demographic Challenge to promote a national strategy against this. With this problem that I am telling you - that of depopulation - in mind, this proposal put forward by the Commission represents an opportunity to create statistical instruments that allow the situation in the regions to be analyzed in more detail and to apply Community policies. The report, of course, raises a very positive question, which is to give legal recognition to the territorial typologies that have been used in the European statistical system, so that they serve as categories when designing cohesion or rural development policies and thus allow to compare regions and geographical areas. However, in my opinion, it is a somewhat missed opportunity. I subscribe to what has been said by colleagues regarding the categorization of the islands; and also, on the other hand, when drawing a new grid to distinguish three new typologies — urban centers, urban groupings and rural areas — I think that the topography of the territories should have been taken into account more. A mountainous surface or a flat surface cannot be treated in the same way. This question, which might not arouse more interest, is important to analyze the different territories, because there are population centers located on unevenness, which greatly affects when it comes to finding a suitable place to install an agricultural warehouse with the one to earn a family living. Keep these things in mind as well.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Thank you, Madam President, I welcome the Commission's proposal and, at the same time, congratulate the rapporteur and those who have worked on this document. Cohesion policy has, as we all know, the role of bridging social disparities between the regions and the Member States of the European Union. However, the efficiency of these policies is conditioned primarily by the knowledge of the realities on the ground that represent different particularities from one country to another or from one region to another. Unfortunately, today we are witnessing a consistent migration phenomenon, more precisely, massive concentrations in the urban space which have as a consequence the worrying depopulation of the rural space generated by its lack of attractiveness. However, this phenomenon has different variables from one country to another and from one region to another. Territorial typologies must be harmonized, transparent legal instruments applicable throughout the European Union that will increase the effectiveness of European policies, and in particular cohesion policy. Whether we are talking about employment, rural development, agriculture or tourism, demography or poverty, these must be benchmarks that lead to increased inclusion at European level and strengthen the links between urban and rural areas. The successful implementation of future policies and actions at European level is dependent on the correct understanding of the information provided by the typology of the different regions. However, I would like to point out that, without a decentralization of the decision, which must be brought as close as possible to the citizen, the effectiveness of cohesion policy will be far from achieving its goal. Thanks.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, cohesion policy must, of course, support and promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. This means that the role of cities should be reflected, the role of urban areas, rural areas, coastal areas and especially islands, but also mountainous remote areas. Thus, statistics derived from territorial typologies are very important tools. In this way we will be able to analyze data such as the GDP of rural areas, to measure employment and what it has to do with urbanization. These data will mainly help the island regions, especially the Aegean islands which are affected by the troika policy, the memoranda, but also by the thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants who are settled there. Another is a city on an Aegean island, where there is increased transport and energy costs, and another is a city in mainland Greece. It is therefore necessary to reduce VAT for the Aegean islands, because only in this way can they move forward and become competitive. In Turkey the VAT is 5% and in Greece the Troika imposes a VAT of 24% for the Aegean islands. This situation cannot continue.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, the existence of basic definitions and statistical criteria for the various territorial typologies is a key tool in shaping the Union's regional policy and drawing useful conclusions. In order to have comparable territorial units we have to choose different territorial levels and data from the Member States, so that the variation in the size of the territorial units is as small as possible; otherwise, drawing conclusions based on linking different statistical domains, such as regional accounts, the labor market, rural and island development, agriculture, tourism, maritime policy and others, will show distortions and divergences. Statistics as a science needs tools that are technologically neutral, up-to-date and always adapted to the target, in order to ensure the best quality of reality capture.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like once again to thank the rapporteur, Ms Mihaylova, and the shadow rapporteurs, for their preparatory work and their support during the process. I would also like to thank honourable Members for their support for our initiative. I am convinced that the proposal will help us in producing the necessary evidence to come to fact-based decisions in the framework of regional development. It will certainly contribute to understanding common patterns in the socio-economic situation of the different kinds of regions.

name: Искра Михайлова
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to thank all the speakers today and the shadow rapporteurs in the REGI Committee, as well as the competence of the Committee itself, which has been extremely responsible in supporting the proposal and committing itself to the negotiations on it. I just want to emphasize that, in addition to collecting more, more precise, more relevant data, with this proposal we will build an integrated approach to data accumulation and use in the preparation of European Union policies. This integrated approach will allow us to integrate the different types of policies according to the territories in which they are developed, and thus increase the impact of European Union investment. I hope that this seemingly technical dossier will contribute to improving the European Union's common cohesion policy and that its timely adoption will facilitate both the measures in the current programming period and the preparations for the post-2020 period.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That closes the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 14 November 2017.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the recognition of professional qualifications in inland navigation and repealing Council Directive 96/50 / EC and Directive 91/672 /EEC of the Council by Gesine Meissner on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (COM (2016) 0082 - C8-0061 / 2016 - 2016/0050 (COD)) (A8-0338 / 2016).

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I can really say: Today is a good day for inland navigation. Inland navigation is not that well known, but it is very important for the entire transport sector. The Commissioner will probably join us in a moment. It is the case that from now on, if we confirm the trialogue result, we will have uniform rules for inland waterway training - that is, for skippers, for helmsmen, for able seamans and sailors. Incidentally, all of this is also available in the female form. So there are already some women who work in this sector. The inland navigation sector as a whole also welcomes this regulation very much, for a number of reasons. One is: we need more inland shipping in the future. This is a very environmentally friendly means of transport and we want to intensify it. But we have too few qualified employees. And because of the different training courses we have no employee mobility; we would like to increase that. At the same time, we want to make it possible for a career changer from another area to qualify for inland shipping. And all in all, the whole thing should then happen with the latest technology with the use of simulators and with the exchange of experience, so that afterwards we have even more security through good qualifications and competence on the fuller rivers. It is about general qualifications and also about additional qualifications. Additional qualifications are required, for example, when driving passenger ships or driving dangerous goods or liquefied gas or when driving particularly long convoys or when dealing with radar. These are all extra exams that have to be taken. You also have to take into account that the rivers are very different - different lengths, different levels of complexity. I also learned a lot in the process, for example that the Danube has a particularly strong current and is on some places require special route knowledge, just like the Rhine, for example, which is sometimes particularly busy and prone to accidents. Here, too, you need special route knowledge, and you have to acquire that qualification if you want to drive there. The standards are based on something that has been around for a long time, namely the requirements of the Rhine Commission. There are also some river commissions for other rivers who are very familiar with their river and now allow everything to flow into it. Of course we have old certificates, and we then found an interim solution for how long they can remain valid. None of that was a big problem. The big problem was to see for whom, for which states this should apply. For example, not all Member States have rivers. Malta, for example, has no river, but has a seafaring school. It could be that one day the Maltese will think about it, maybe they want to train inland boatmen and do the practical part - I'm just seeing Peter van Dalen - in Holland. That would be possible. And that's why we said: We have to see who does it apply to and who does it not. For example, we immediately removed the sport boats and also the military and the police and the rescue services. And then we said: You have to think about it, if you have no rivers at all - like Malta, Cyprus and Denmark, which has a river but is not navigable - then you can say: You don't have to do anything at the moment, unless you think about starting an apprenticeship. Then of course you have to fully implement the law. The second is the case of Finland. Finland has many lakes but no direct rivers and is not connected to the European river network. I also learned there: There are Finnish saunas with an outboard motor, which of course don't need a captain's license; that is clear. They now have the option that they only have the Implement recognition of the EU driving license in any case, but also have and are allowed to maintain their own training.But only if the Finnish seafarers - on the lake - do not go to the Rhine, then they must also have the other training.And finally, you can say: everyone else has to fully implement it.So it was pretty complicated to get through this.As I said, I learned a lot about Europe's rivers.And I had a lot of fun, especially with my shadow reporters - I don't even see them all.I know Merja Kyllönen, for example, apologized, she is not there.But many others are there, Peter van Dalen is there.It was very exciting and I think we achieved a good result together with the Maltese.I thank you very much.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the Commission warmly welcomes the compromise reached by the co-legislators on this file in June 2017. I would personally like to warmly thank the rapporteur Ms Meissner, and Ms Boylan and the shadow rapporteurs who contributed to such constructive cooperation in reaching an agreement. Inland waterway transport is a sector with long traditions and European know-how. It is essential to maintain this high level of professionalism for future generations too. We need to face the challenges of an ageing workforce. This legislation will bring significant benefits in addressing the labour shortage in inland waterways transport by facilitating labour mobility. Crew members will be able to exercise their profession in a cross-border environment more easily because Union certificates of qualifications will be recognised on all inland waterways throughout the Union. This includes: benefits, as now the rules will apply to all the crew members and not only boat masters as currently; and further harmonisation within the Union, as the Rhine certificates will be issued in accordance with the same requirements as those set by the future directive. At the same time, the new rules also take account of the different characteristics of EU countries in order to avoid disproportionate administrative burdens. Last but not least, the recognition will be built on a modern, competence-based system that will increase safety and improve the attractiveness of the profession. Amendments from the European Parliament and the negotiations brought many useful clarifications to the Commission’s proposal and a number of valuable additional competence requirements. In addition, other modifications can be considered as balanced compromises preserving the objectives of the proposal. This legislation represents clear progress in comparison to the situation today and shows that the EU can deliver for small businesses, people and jobs. This move forward is also part of a bigger picture in the context of decarbonisation. Inland waterway transport already transports 500 million tonnes of cargo and provides 1.36 million river-cruise trips. The sector will be strengthened through innovation and the emergence of a healthy and dynamic business environment. This will provide great benefits for the 10 000 companies, SMEs and micro-enterprises already operating in Europe, representing over 42 000 jobs in freight and passenger transport. At the same time, it will also lay the groundwork for future generations and the creation of jobs and growth in the sector.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - First of all, I would like to mention that I am replacing my colleague Renaud Muselier. He is not here tonight and on his behalf I would like to thank Mrs Meisner for the many work she has had on this file. At first it seemed very simple, but especially when the countries that do not have inland waterways got involved, Mrs Meisner had to find a proper compromise with the shadow rapporteurs. I very much agree with Ms Bulc: we have a wonderful sector at the head here, but with enormous staff shortages and a lot of opportunities. Then it is very nice that the Dutch can sail in Germany, Germans can sail in the Netherlands and maybe Poles in the Netherlands and vice versa. That is really the internal market as we like to see it and uniform professional qualifications are the future for our youth. Ultimately, a compromise was found: if you do not have inland navigation, you do not have to transpose the directive, but if you have inland navigation and you have not transposed it, then you must recognize the diploma from the other country. It is a bit of a European compromise, but I agree with Mrs Bulc: we can go on and on.

name: Claudia Țapardel
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, a year and countless meetings and trilogues later, here we are at the end of this extremely important dossier for European inland navigation and the European transport system. On this occasion, I would like to thank Gesine first of all for the excellent work she has done as rapporteur on this file. I also thank the other rapporteur colleagues for the constructive approach in the negotiations. I believe that this report is a success for the internal market because it brings concrete solutions to the problems facing the inland navigation sector. The situation we started from is that we currently do not have a clear system for developing navigation standards and no smooth process for recognizing all existing certificates, especially for recognizing certificates for the Rhine River and the Danube. This is also the reason why the profession of navigator has become unattractive for the younger generations. But what the agreement between Parliament and the Council brings is an effective European system for issuing and recognizing the certificates issued by each Member State. It is of course unfortunate that we have not been able to achieve an implementation without exception of the directive, but I believe that we have laid the foundations for a system that will concretely improve navigation on the main rivers where it is really needed. All European states will be obliged to recognize European certificates, even if they do not issue such documents, and the criteria and requirements included in the delegated acts will be published in all European languages. This was a request of the Social Democratic Group. All this will support the free movement of labor and we will be able to attract more people to this sector. In terms of social issues, I think more could be done. However, it is important that we managed to include it in the recitals the fact that employers are obliged to apply social standards and the remuneration of the states where the activity is carried out, even if the employees come from third countries.In addition, the Commission will need to ensure that these social norms are truly respected and that women's participation is encouraged.In parallel, we have ensured that, in the long term, the Commission will carry out regular evaluations of the new system, especially from the perspective of digitization, which will help us to monitor working and rest times, but also to eliminate existing red tape..That being said, I consider the final result of the trilogues to be very good and I recommend a positive vote from Parliament.Thank you and I hope it will be a step forward for better traffic and better labor mobility in the transport sector.Thank you very much, Madam President.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - First of all, thank you very much to Gesine for all the work and efforts. We have achieved a good result and I also think with a new piece of legislation that is good for European and Dutch inland shipping. The Commissioner has already said it: there is a need for more mobility. We need more people and in this way we can promote the intake and promotion of qualified people in the inland shipping sector. Competences, the supervisory director rightly pointed out, that's what it's all about now. Of course, diploma and grades, that continues to count, but it is mainly about what skills someone brings. Such an approach also promotes the influx of people who have not grown up in inland shipping from an early age, and in this way we have opportunities for both side entrants and people who already want to move up to other ranks in the sector. , so more opportunities for qualified people. As shadow rapporteur - and the rapporteur has already referred to it - I have also really committed myself to good involvement of the river committees, because the river committees have the people who have the knowledge of the practice, who know what is going on and also know what is going on. should be asked. But I think that the involvement of the river commissions and of the CESNI committee is now guaranteed and that really guarantees expert input. Finally, unfortunately we see quite a few accidents and near-accidents on European inland waterways due to a lack of language skills and that is why I am very happy that a long-standing wish, at least of my own, is being honored, namely a command of basic English. That has to come in now, we already have something like this in shipping, it is called sea speak and now river speak is also being introduced. I think that is an essential step forward for safe inland navigation. In short, I wholeheartedly support this.

name: Gabriele Preuß (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I now come from a region where inland shipping is vital to industry. And I am sure that their importance will increase even more in the near future. Because if we are serious about intermodality and decarbonisation, then we have to use waterways better and more effectively. We have to create European perspectives for employees, and this law is such a step because we are finally making it possible for qualifications to be recognized. Inland navigation is an exciting sector and we should motivate young people to take up such professions. We must therefore continue to work consistently and achieve measurable progress in areas such as digitization and the greening of the fleets. It is therefore important for the Commission to provide further impetus here and make the appropriate budgets available. Many thanks to Ms. Meissner and to the rapporteurs ... (The speaker speaks without a microphone.)

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - It is good that there are common criteria so that people who want to work in inland navigation or want to progress in such a job can have their competence recognized more easily. The EU qualification certificate can then open doors where different separate regulations existed in the past. In Flanders, we have grown thanks to our waterways and it is time we rediscover the possibilities of transport via water. 80% of Flemish companies are located no more than ten kilometers from a navigable waterway. European inland waters are also still underutilized. As a sustainable alternative to road transport, inland shipping can also contribute to a reduction of the environmental consequences of transport. I myself have already seen with my own eyes how entrepreneurs in the sector in Flanders are working who respond to the advantages of inland shipping with innovative solutions. However, future growth stands or falls with qualified personnel. Now the average age is 55 years. In order to make inland navigation professions more attractive, the new directive is therefore welcome.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Let me congratulate Mrs Gesine Meissner on her report, the way she presented it to us and her cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs. I would also like to refer to the words spoken by Commissioner Bulc, who made us realize that inland navigation is still an important part of the European Union's transport sector, that is, inland navigation is part of the transport space we have. The advantage that I see here is also largely that we harmonize the regulations, we recognize the certificates in principle, but what is important - as was also mentioned - I come from a country that mostly flows on its inland rivers - well that's right arranged - but it has vocational schools training for the needs of inland navigation. I think that this solution will be a good basis for verifying, modernizing and modernizing the vocational training program.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Congratulations to Ms. Meissner. I am Viennese and I grew up with a direct view of the Danube, of the landing stage at Mexikoplatz, and friends of mine worked on Danube ships. In this respect, I am familiar with the tough working conditions and how important it is that these jobs that you have on ships also have a promising future. It is therefore particularly important that young people find the job of working on a barge accordingly attractive. For this we need fair working conditions in all employment relationships and a universally applicable right to equal treatment and social protection and, of course, above all, good, binding regulations when it comes to working hours and rest periods - this of course applies to all traffic. With standards to be set across Europe in training and the necessary qualifications to be allowed to work on a ship, not only do all employees enjoy more safety, but also the passengers. It is therefore important to ensure a high quality of training for ship personnel and at the same time to protect boat personnel - sailors. The protection of minors is particularly important to me. I am therefore also grateful that my amendments in this regard have been accepted: Applicable national youth protection provisions must apply, unless there is a higher contractual level of protection.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting a very good report, even though she has worked on only a certain minimum legal basis. I would like to appreciate that the report presented addresses part of the problem that the current inland navigation is actually going through, where we lack, in particular, the recognition of qualifications in question. This is undoubtedly essential for the further development of the sector and it is also important for the general functioning of the two systems, meaning the Danube certificate and the Rhine certificate. We need to make this profession more attractive to young people, I think it is important to mention the issue of digitization, but also the interconnectedness of European inland navigation. I know that the rapporteur has only worked with what the directive that we are talking about here actually allows. On the other hand, I think we stayed a bit halfway. Recognizing qualifications is important, but it is also important to further develop the field, and I think that should be our task in the future.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, and I would like to congratulate Gesine. It is an extremely important report from my point of view because we cannot exclude from sea transport and transport, river transport. I was born near the Danube, I know what that means. At the same time, I believe that we can make a lot of regulations in the field of transport, I am also part of the Committee on the Internal Market, but if we do not regulate the professional qualifications to be these unitary European certificates to allow cross-border development, to allows labor mobility, it is an extremely important field and I think it is very good that the report also included the issue of respect for the right to work, rest, all issues related to workers, but also the issue of gender equality and I congratulate you especially because it is an area where women have had more difficult access, perhaps because of too little information. And I think, Commissioner, that it is good to have an assessment of qualifications, not just qualifications and the issuance of certificates, and I am glad that this report will be voted on because it will complement transport and transport regulations. Thanks.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, it is well known that inland waterway transport plays an important role in the development of the internal market. We know how the Rhine and the Danube are used for transportation. Of course, in order to further develop this whole process, it is necessary to facilitate the mobility of the workforce and this means mutual recognition of the seafaring certificates of those who are masters of vessels, but at the same time, of course, recognition of the professional qualifications of seafaring brochures. Of course, we know that there is a need for practical experience, which should be mandatory because there are many departments that have special risks. In addition, we must take the social aspects into account, ie we will now have wage and social rights based on the country of work and not the country of origin of those who work; therefore, social dumping is effectively eliminated.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their comments, and I would like, once again, to underline the fact that this legislation will bring significant benefits in addressing the labour shortage in inland waterways transport by facilitating labour mobility. I am happy that we all agree on that. It will also ensure that the qualifications of all workers on board inland navigation vessels are recognised throughout the Union. This is clear progress in comparison with the situation today and it shows that the EU can deliver for people and jobs. Before I conclude, let me comment on a few of the Members’ remarks. First, on exemptions, the Commission agreed to well-designed exceptions, in particular for the transposition of specific provisions that have no application in some Member States which have no inland waterways. It makes sense to have these kinds of exception. Secondly, regarding assessments, I would stress that modernising our rules also means moving away from specific mandatory training to ensuring the relevant competences through common assessment standards. So this is addressed as well. I would also like to comment on remarks by a speaker who asked for further support for the sector. Allow me here to draw attention to some of the things that are already happening, and already in the pipeline, which affect the inland waterways sector in a broader sense, beyond considerations of labour mobility. These measures on the table were introduced in the second Mobility Package, in which we introduced combined transport with inland waterways playing a significant role as one of the decarbonised sectors. I would also like to draw attention to the additional financing of alternative fuels infrastructure, which inland waterways should take advantage of. All of a sudden, inland waterways are part of a systemic solution as we consider how to address the challenges in transport. In closing, I would like once again to thank Parliament for its constructive cooperation on this issue, and I look forward to a positive vote tomorrow.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! We have already noticed: we naturally have many advocates of inland navigation around here. I would like to take up what Gabriele Preuss said again: We need more use of the waterways. Most people don't think about it. All of us who have worked on this know the importance of inland shipping. Not all countries have rivers that are navigable. That's it. But especially here in the north - the Netherlands, Germany and, of course, France and Romania - have many inland waterways, and we have to use them more, because it actually relieves the roads and is also extremely environmentally friendly. So it is good that we now want to create more mobility - we all want that - and of course we will also ensure digitization and other improvements - environmental friendliness, etc. I would like to say something again about the compromise that has been raised. It was really nice that we had represented the Netherlands, Romania and Finland with the reporters and the shadow rapporteurs - very different countries. Malta, which has no river at all, had to negotiate the whole thing for the Council. This has really led to the fact that we have figured out how a law can be made so that an EU-wide - I will now say: Driving license for inland navigation, it is of course not said - different ways must be recognized everywhere, if you have a river at all, but that you don't have to implement the whole law, as for example in Finland, where it takes a lot of effort to pour it into national legislation. I think we have really found a good compromise - I'm very happy about that. But that was a very tough struggle. In between we weren't sure if we'd get it right. But it worked. So thank you again to everyone. One more thing: We also wrote in it - that was not the case before - that it has to be translated into all languages.Above all, Claudia hatapardel made sure of that.Of course that's important.If you want worker mobility, everyone needs to understand what it is about.The Commission now has two years to come up with concrete proposals for certificates and such.Member States have four years to implement it.Then we will probably have made great strides in inland shipping.Thank you and of course tomorrow please agree!

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday 14 November 2017.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Dieter-Lebrecht Koch, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal "Saving lives: improving vehicle safety in the EU" (2017/2085 (INI) (A8-0330/2017).

name: Markus Ferber
text: deputy rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner! Unfortunately, Mr. Koch is still on the way. It's nice when you have to deal with traffic problems in transport policy. He asked me to give his speech. I have good news and bad news for you. First the good: as far as road safety is concerned, we live in Europe in one of the safest regions in the world. The number of accident victims has almost halved since 1992. Now the bad news: Despite the sharp decline, around 25,500 people still died on Europe's roads in 2016 - i.e. a small town - 135,000 suffered serious injuries, often associated with permanent impairment. Worldwide, 3,500 people will lose their lives in traffic again today alone. No matter where this happens - our most vulnerable road users, i.e. pedestrians and two-wheelers, are most frequently affected. And an average of 113 other people are directly affected by each accident victim, be they family members, friends or work colleagues. The further reduction in the number of deaths in accidents - Vision Zero -, but also the target agreed by the EU transport ministers in March of this year to reduce the number of seriously injured by 50% make measures necessary to improve the vehicles, infrastructure and the behavior of road users affect. And these measures should not contradict each other, but complement each other. Human error is complicit in around 92% of all accidents, and in 72% it is even the main cause. This makes it clear that we have to start here above all. You all know the causes: carelessness, distraction are just as much a part of it as alcohol and drugs behind the wheel, carelessness, overconfidence and inappropriate speed. Education and training as well as raising the awareness of all road users are good and indispensable, but they are enough not from. In addition to the error-forgiving infrastructure, we need invisible drivers and helpers in an emergency: the driver assistance systems. Above all, they should make a contribution to correcting the misconduct of drivers and minimizing their distraction and inattention. On the path to fully autonomous driving, it will be precisely these technical systems in vehicles that can save lives. Driver assistance systems have to warn drivers in critical situations and give them the opportunity to react in good time in order to maintain control of the vehicle. If the driver does not do this or does this incorrectly, then they should also be able to intervene independently, as it were automatically. The task of driver assistance systems is firstly to inform the driver of dangers and to support and relieve him, secondly to promote a fuel-efficient driving style and thirdly to contribute to the sustainability of road traffic and a smooth flow of traffic. Because then, fourthly, you can increase the driving comfort of the driver. I would just like to mention a few topics: First, the maximum limit for the blood alcohol concentration of drivers or the greater consideration of weaker road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and people with restricted mobility. As far as the driver assistance systems themselves are concerned, I would only like to make the standard installation of safety-relevant systems mandatory. That is why I - Mr Koch - propose: An essential contribution to increasing road safety based on scientific evidence must be made, a positive cost / benefit ratio, and these systems must be ready for the market. That is why I mean that automatic emergency braking assistants with pedestrian and cyclist detection, emergency braking displays, lane departure warning systems, turning assistants - in the case of trucks in connection with a camera device -, tire pressure monitoring systems and eCall for motorcycles meet exactly this criterion.In addition, I am building on a bundling of technical components that help make cars more affordable due to the increased number of units.The penetration of our vehicle fleet is crucial for the effectiveness of these systems.Therefore, the purchase price of the vehicles must not increase so much that in the end the purchase is discouraged.I hope that this will become a consumer right for all citizens of Europe.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to welcome Mr Koch’s report. Thank you for the outstanding job that you have done. It recognises that road safety is a pan-European issue that needs to be addressed through an integrated approach. This implies adequate road safety management, enforcement of rules, driver training, road infrastructure and vehicle safety, as well as post-collision care. I fully agree. Every year too many families have to deal with the terrible effects of the severe injuries inflicted to a quarter of a million people because of traffic accidents. And even worse, every year about 25 500 people die on EU roads. That is a bus load every single day. 70 people. We must act and be more robust in our response, because the outlook is not that good at all. Over the last decades we made a lot of progress in road safety, reducing the number of deaths quite significantly. Thousands of lives were saved. But in recent years this reduction has stagnated. In some countries the numbers are even on the rise, and this is unacceptable. We do have to find a new way forward. Enforcement of rules by Member States on speeding, drink driving, safety belts and other unsafe driver behaviour has already had a positive effect. This is also the case for improving driver training and road infrastructure. The report rightly concludes that these are areas for improvement. The Commission fully agrees with those conclusions, and this is why we have recently proposed new measures, for example on the training of professional drivers. But there is more good news. Commission services have been preparing a revision of the general safety regulation and a pedestrian safety regulation. This has been done in a totally transparent and open manner by involving all relevant stakeholders from day one. In essence, we performed the ultimate peer reviewing exercise before deciding on what we should do and how. We have received very broad support from the European Parliament in this report, but also from the Member States’ road safety advocacy groups, and last but not least, the automotive industry itself. Let us focus now on the accident avoidance technologies. Advanced technologies can help us a lot in preventing traffic accidents from happening all together. One of the most effective technologies available today is automatic or autonomous emergency braking. The car stops completely by itself when it sees that an accident is about to happen. This way, a collision between two cars can be prevented. Another technology that we are looking at is emergency lane-keeping system. It detects that that car has drifted out of its lane for whatever reason, on a collision course, and steers the car back into its own lane. In fact, these two advanced systems will also be used for automated and connected driving. Speeding is one the main killers on our roads. This is why we are also looking into a ground breaking technology such as intelligent speed assistance. Another major challenge for road safety is how to effectively deal with drivers who are too distracted to drive safely by themselves. This was not explicitly developed in the report, but it deserves our attention too. We know about the increase in road fatalities due to growing use of smart phones while driving. Therefore, driver distraction and fatigue monitoring systems are also firmly on our radar. The EU will absolutely be at the forefront of car safety when these safety measures are out into effect. These measures already have a huge potential to protect EU citizens, as standard equipment on all passenger cars. But we should not stop there. The second item I would like to discuss with you is the protection of pedestrians and cyclists in traffic. We must have seen and heard terrible stories of trucks running over children at road crossings and hitting cyclists when making a turn. It is time that we recognise the urgent need for a comprehensive approach to protect the most vulnerable road users against current truck designs, such as blind spots. A first step is to add special detection systems to heavy duty vehicles that will know when pedestrians and cyclists are in the vehicle’s blind spot zone. But the second step is the most important one: designing larger windows. Our analyses show that when a driver can see the danger directly, accidents with pedestrians and cyclists are prevented. With these two steps together, we are looking at a revolutionary approach to make trucks in cities a lot safer for pedestrians and cyclists. The work to draft the new proposed vehicle safety legislation is now in progress, and we aim at including it in the third mobility package coming next year. All in all, the Commission is taking all measures which are in our competent to address this silent killer on EU roads. It is our responsibility to do more. We expect that other actors will play their part as well – especially Member State authorities – when it comes to education, training, enforcement and infrastructure safety. So once again, let me thank the honourable Member for such an excellent report that supports this important work, and I do hope that I can count on your continued support and engagement in the coming months.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Firstly, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her clear explanation. I think she has been very clear about what to do in the last six minutes and I very much agree that Dieter Koch has delivered a good report and the defense by Marcus Ferber has been excellent as usual. Road safety is an underestimated problem in the European Union and the personal mistakes are known to all of us. You are from Italy and we know that there are many road safety problems in that country too. Today we are looking at the technical side and we are doing that in preparation for the new general safety regulation when it comes to vehicles. We can do an awful lot in that area. The technical possibilities are almost unlimited with sensors, with side lighting, with beeping systems, and so on. One point does require extra attention: making phone calls, operating a laptop, working with modern means of communication while you drive. You see the number of accidents in that area increasing. I hope that the European Commission will also come up with adequate and very innovative measures in this regard, because we cannot afford those road deaths.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: for the group S & amp; D. - Commissioner, Mr President, although road safety in the European Union has improved significantly over the last ten years and the number of road deaths has fallen by almost half, we are still talking about more than 25 000 road accident victims. In addition, recent statistics show that we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths and seriously injured people in line with our long-term goals. Traffic accidents are determined by a number of factors and their combinations. From the behavior and mistakes of road users, which include fatigue, stress, distraction while driving and driving under the influence of alcohol and addictive substances, to enforcing the rules, education and training. The condition of the infrastructure, vehicle safety and effective emergency care have an impact. This report focuses on proposals to improve vehicle safety, which should respond to advances in technological development and use other options to prevent accidents or mitigate their consequences. I would like to remind you that, at the beginning of this parliamentary term, for example, we approved the installation of eCall in all new car models from 1 April next year. It was the European Parliament and some Member States, including the Czech Republic, that led the initiative. Driver assistance systems undoubtedly fall into the category of innovations in vehicle safety. For example, an automatic emergency braking system with pedestrian and cyclist recognition can help reduce the number of the most vulnerable road users, who account for 30% of road fatalities. Vulnerable road users are also largely affected by the blind spot reduction system for lorries. In addition to assistance systems, greater safety can be ensured by changing the design of the front and rear of heavy trucks, buses or coaches. Improving visibility can help drivers better assess the situation on the road, prevent a collision or mitigate its consequences. This is especially true when it occurs to a collision with cyclists or pedestrians, for whom such a collision may have fatal consequences.It is still true that the biggest killers on Europe's roads are speeding, alcohol, seat belts, which is why we support initiatives that address these risk factors.I trust that the Commission will take into account the proposals contained in this report in the forthcoming revision of the General Security Regulation, which it intends to present at the beginning of next year.And I hope he won't be late.Ladies and gentlemen, despite all the measures we are talking about today, the most important thing is that, as a society, we perceive road accidents with the dead and seriously injured as something unacceptable that can and must change.On Sunday, we will commemorate World Day of Traffic Accident Victims.It is not enough to remember these everyday misfortunes.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - The figures have already been mentioned by the Commissioner: every year on our European roads 25 500 people are killed and 135 000 people are injured. That is a tragedy for those involved, for families and for our society. Safer road traffic and reducing the number of road casualties is also an absolute priority for us. As very correctly stated in this report, the integration of smart driver assistance systems in vehicles can certainly contribute to this. Agreements are also needed about the quality of those systems and also to ensure that trade is as fair as possible. Nevertheless, I have questions about expensive European studies about binding targets for road checks or, for example, for European interference in the cycling infrastructure, which are requested in the report. Such initiatives, such decisions, are better taken by the competent authorities in the Member States, ie at national or regional level, where they better respond to the needs of the specific context and road situation and the needs of road users there. Flanders, the nation I represent, provides the proof. The Flemish transport minister succeeds in reducing the number of road casualties year after year. Customized policy therefore works. Let us therefore work with the Member States and the regions to create a safer Europe that really saves human lives.

name: Dominique Riquet
