text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Dieter-Lebrecht Koch for his excellent report and recall, of course, the important issue of road safety. In order not to go over the very many human and technical factors, which can be solutions and which the Commissioner has detailed very well, I would like to come back or underline two specific points, but which seem important to me. First, recognizing the intrinsic dependence between accidentality and the quality of infrastructure, including the quality of the road network. It should be noted, for example, that motorways, despite their high speed level and their high concentration of vehicles, only represent 5% of serious accidents, testifying to the direct relationship between road safety and the nature and quality of infrastructure. As a reminder, a recent study took stock of the financial situation of truck drivers in Europe. 270 billion in revenue for the States, per year, all taxes combined, for 160 billion in terms of investments, especially for maintenance. It is therefore 110 billion missing that could be beneficial to improve the missing infrastructure. It should also be noted that road accidents, while destroying the lives of families, also represent a high cost for society, particularly in terms of health expenditure. Where there is often insistence on the repressive means available to States, and which are also a source of additional revenue amounting to billions to improve road safety, public authorities should also do their work better upstream, by investing more to prevent risk and save lives. My second point concerns the awareness of the medical profession may be insufficient. I speak here as a former doctor. Everyone knows, of course, that alcohol drugs are dangerous while driving, but it seems to me that there is a real work to be done towards the medical world as regards the road safety problems linked to certain diseases, certain disabilities, certain treatments or addictions sometimes caused by necessary drug consumption, but which has psychotropic effects or effects on driving. These direct impacts on driving safety require better consideration, but also better education, both for the public and above all for the medical profession in the care of patients. Indeed, it seems that the doctor is often turned towards his patient, but not in his capacity as driver of a car, and that the disabilities, the diagnoses, the consequences of the diagnoses that he has made or the treatments that he will prescribe have extremely important consequences for driving. You know that it is estimated that around 10% of accidents are linked either to disabilities that have not been taken into account, or to treatments whose consequences on driving ability have not been highlighted. This is a point that also deserves to be taken into account.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, let me first of all thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive and stimulating work. I am glad that many of my proposals have been included in the report, which is very vigorous and ambitious. There can be no doubt that this is a fundamental issue that deserves our attention. In 2016, 25,500 people lost their lives in road accidents in the EU and another 135,000 suffered serious injuries. Despite the fact that Europe is doing well compared to other continents, we can do even more to protect lives. The report therefore focuses, for example, on driver assistance systems, which will significantly improve road safety, and calls for their installation in all new cars. However, modern times raise a number of important issues with road safety. According to experts, in 2020 there will be about 10 million self-driving cars on the roads. So the very basic question is, who should have the "main word" in such a means of transport - a car or a person? I am convinced that it must be true that a person is the one who has the main control over everything. Traffic automation should not serve to make the driver a servant, but should be the master who uses technology to the benefit of all road users. Although the debates on this report have often been reminiscent of science fiction novels, there can be no doubt that the future will change the transport sector, and we as the European Parliament and as Europe must be prepared. After all, if we fall asleep on security, we risk human lives.

name: Michael Cramer
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur very much, also for the good cooperation and the report that he has presented. I would of course also like to thank the Commissioner for the words she said at the beginning, because it was an initiative by Parliament and we also hope that the Commission will follow suit. Of course, people are important. But it's about the interaction between vehicle behavior and infrastructure, it's not just about better vehicles. That became very clear in the report. Of course, people can be supported, but they cannot be left out, they retain responsibility. That is why the automatic emergency braking assistants, which also recognize pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists, are very, very important. And of course we also want the assistants to keep the respective speed limits; they also have to actively intervene to save lives. It shouldn't be that it is just a regulation that you can abandon at will, but here the technical possibility must also be used. We have been dealing with the blind spot when turning for 15 years. We know it's about the bigger mirrors and then it's always: in ten or fifteen years. In any case, the blind spot when turning must be eliminated and replaced by a direct line of sight. This is very important. It has already been said: the distraction. I was at DEKRA last year. There was a film about basketball players being shown. The audience was given the task of seeing whether everyone had been on the ball. In between an orangutan ran across the field and 90% percent of the audience did not see the orangutan because they only looked at the ball. That means: The distraction is very important for safety. The human being is really crucial here. Alcohol and drugs were mentioned. That is of course important, and it should also be prohibited by law.But also through control, because where a law is not controlled, the law is superfluous.We have now made this design.It is now the Commission's turn, and I would like to express my thanks for the support that the Commissioner has given us.We don't want to wait a year - you said in the coming months - for that to happen, for it to be implemented across Europe, because we want to save human lives.25,000 dead on the roads of the EU are 25,000 too many.We also think of the relatives who continue to suffer from it years later.That is why we have to do something here to improve road safety.This report is the first huge step forward.We hope that this will be implemented as soon as possible.

name: Daniela Aiuto
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the issue of road safety - you recalled today - cannot ignore the use of the most advanced technologies, which can meet us, on the one hand as a support to driving to reduce - l 'my colleagues also said - human error as much as possible, and on the other hand to know in real time if those who drive a vehicle are in the right conditions to do so, that is, if they have a driving license or not valid, or has taken substances that may affect the ability to drive the vehicle. The tools already exist, some only in the experimental phase, but they must be encouraged and implemented. But we know well that safety also depends on the conditions of the roads and infrastructure in general. Often the funds allocated to their care, maintenance and implementation are badly spent or badly managed by the Member States, and in Italy, especially in the South, we are unfortunately well aware of the sad effects of poor maintenance. Their correct use should therefore be monitored in a more effective and transparent way. Let us remember, in fact, that most accidents occur on secondary roads, which for this very reason, due to their nature, are often neglected.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - President! Commissioner, thank you for being here. First of all, I would like to emphasize that my colleague Koch has put a very thorough, forward-looking report on the table, which contains a lot of useful and worthwhile suggestions. We all agree that safety must be a priority in transport. After all, despite all the technical developments, the number of injuries and fatal accidents is still very high and meaningless. We are talking about 135 000 and 25 000 a year, respectively, in the Union. The report rightly states that there is a need to step up road inspections, install safety systems and modernize infrastructure maintenance, because without them, innovative systems will not work. At the same time, it is a fact that the average age of vehicles running on Europe’s roads is more than 10 years, so it is clear that we are not seeing the latest cars and technologies on the roads and streets. The Commission should therefore draw up proposals to facilitate development and series production, thus avoiding the practice of having to pay the additional costs and surcharges due to the incorporation of the latest safety technologies to the end user, ie the car purchaser. We must work to ensure that the latest security technologies are incorporated as soon as possible and as widely as possible, and that they are made available in Hungarian. Without mass production and distribution, we cannot expect a rapid improvement in the achievement of the ambitious goals set.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we are having this debate today because progress on road safety in Europe has been much too slow – we all know this. The Commission has been expected for some time to put forward revisions to vehicle safety, pedestrian protection and infrastructure safety rules, as well as new targets and measures to reduce serious road injuries. All of these have, quite frankly, been unacceptably delayed. As the Commissioner said, in the meantime we have 70 road deaths every day on roads in the EU. In the UK, the latest annual figures show a 4% increase in road deaths from the previous year. As a representative from London, I do want to focus on urban areas. The Commissioner is right: what we actually need is a comprehensive approach. Technical vehicle safety measures are important but are only part of the answer. Pedestrians and cyclists are particularly at risk, as the statistics show all too clearly. Yes, we need our passengers and goods to be able to move around our cities, but prioritising pedestrians and cyclists and segregating them from other traffic wherever possible must be our ultimate goal.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I want to congratulate the rapporteur for this initiative because his work proposes realistic measures to incorporate the principle of prevention into investment in infrastructure, vehicle design and driver behavior. Only then can we reach 2050 without fatalities due to road accidents. Currently, as we have heard, more than 25,000 people die each year in the Union as a result of these types of incidents and about 120,000 are seriously injured. As stated in the report, the keys to solving this problem lie in training and technology. The report also points to a complementary route to sanctions that really encourages drivers to respect traffic regulations designed to protect them: the idea of ​​decisively linking the taxation of vehicles and the rates they pay for insurance to the security conditions of the same. For this, it is essential to advance in standards that make it possible to define throughout the European Union the scope, operation and guarantees of driving assistance devices and new developments in vehicle design focused on improving visibility and the effect of possible impacts. Finally, the other great key to accident prevention is in the infrastructures: on the roads and signage. We have to guarantee that the former can incorporate devices that, with the available technology, are no longer science fiction. For example, designing and investing in speed limit signs or lane separation bands or road limits capable of interacting with vehicles and thus limit the effect of factors such as distraction, drowsiness, etc., on the deterioration of the road. road safety. For this, it would be definitive that these parameters are included in the requirements that an investment in roads must meet in order to have support European Union and that the money collected from tolls is directly and mandatorily reverted to investment in road maintenance and improvement.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, it has been several years since the European Commission and the European Parliament have adopted two key objectives for improving road safety. The first was to halve the number of road deaths by 2020. The second is to achieve zero mortality in the European Union by 2050. Currently, about 25,000 people die on the roads every year and 135,000 are seriously injured. The European Parliament has in the past adopted a number of important documents that improve the quality of infrastructure and the safety of road vehicles. It was not until 2015 that a regulation was adopted on the introduction of the eCall in-vehicle system. Most accident victims are cyclists and pedestrians. Therefore, a number of EU states and the Czech Republic have adopted regulations on the mandatory wearing of reflective elements by pedestrians under specified conditions. The resolution following the Dieter-Lebrecht Koch report has one gap. There is a lack of regular training of all drivers. Even the best mandatory driver safety assistance components cannot replace this training. With this reservation, I highly recommend the report under discussion for approval. I believe that in the near future, the obligation to regularly train all holders of driving licenses associated with the driving test will be implemented in the legislation. 90% of accidents, Commissioner, are caused by inappropriate driver activity.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report and also to thank the Commissioner because I think the two views seem to be aligned. We have much common ground on the issue of car safety: improving the safety of vehicles, reducing road deaths, and – as you have said yourself, Commissioner, on numerous occasions – reducing the number of serious injuries on our roads, because, as we know from so many people, these can have a horrific effect on individuals and their families. Many people live with such injuries for the balance of their lifetime. Ninety-five per cent of accidents are related to human error, and technology can play a very important role in reducing those errors. We have seen much, to date, in terms of introducing technology to cars. Seat-belt reminders were a small step that actually does save lives and reduces what could be the horrendous impact of injuries. I am delighted that some amendments I made in relation to heavy goods vehicles were adopted, ensuring that we have ambitious direct-vision standards included in truck design. Commissioner, I am glad you included that point in your speech this evening. We need to address blind spots and protect pedestrians and cyclists. When you think about it, the right place for these large vehicles is not on our roads in urban areas, but we can do a lot in terms of vehicle design to address their safety and the threat that they pose to cyclists and pedestrians. I very much look forward to the third Mobility Package, in which many of these measures will be included, and we look forward to approving them.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D).
text: - I appreciate the fact that the European Parliament is once again debating road safety.We have an increasingly serious problem.Well, it is true that road safety in Europe has increased in the last twenty years, which is confirmed by the fall in the number of victims.On the other hand, and this must be emphasized with full force, this process has been stagnating for several years.The report places a strong emphasis on the possibilities offered by technology.In my opinion, at least as much space and attention should be devoted to new legal and organizational solutions.Because technical progress alone will not solve everything.And the second and last problem: remember that we will have more and more cyclists on the road.Well, in my opinion, the proposals to protect the life and safety of cyclists are too passive proposals.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Dear colleagues, road safety remains one of the European Union's priorities in combating the scourge of deaths and accidents on European roads, which affect hundreds of thousands of families every year. To achieve the goal of zero fatalities, we must come up with concrete and effective measures, in conjunction with the Member States, on vehicle safety, road infrastructure and driver behavior. In these three vectors, there is still much to be done: combating alcohol on the road, remodeling infrastructures and developing safe mobility plans for pedestrians and cyclists, especially in urban areas, and mandatory driver assistance systems, like the e-call system, which is already a reality and was mentioned by colleague Olga Sehnalová. Road safety cannot be just for those who have more money. It should not be only the top-of-the-range cars to have assistance mechanisms offered by manufacturers, such as emergency braking, tire pressure control, the rear seat belt system, etc. It must be made mandatory for all vehicles the existence of these technologies, which help to reduce road mortality. Ten years ago, the industry used the argument that free e-call for all passenger vehicles would represent a cataclysm in vehicle prices. This has not happened. A simple automatic mandatory seat belt adjustment system to prevent neck injuries can save thousands of lives and has a negligible cost. I hope that the European Commission will take Parliament's excellent recommendations into account in this report and that we will be able to legislate intelligently to change the paradigm of deaths per year on European roads: going from 25,000 to zero.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I do not think anyone is questioning the importance of this report. I want to congratulate the rapporteur, I want to congratulate all the colleagues who contributed. Of course, road safety is directly related to people's lives. Commissioner, we have a new road safety strategy, but I think we need to think about other goals. I have identified the causes: our colleagues have said here, I want to point out a few. First of all the infrastructure. We have said many times that we need to direct European money, European funds, the European Fund for Strategic Investments to Infrastructure, but in areas where there is a backlog in terms of infrastructure quality. Then, the quality and professional training of drivers. Of course, here too I argue that we need to change in European legislation the way to check driving licenses, to periodically check the quality of training. We also need better signaling because there are situations in which, due to poor signaling, there are accidents. And, if I think that 51% of road accidents are in urban areas, I think that here, Commissioner, we need to encourage the Member States to allocate funds for urban decongestion of transport and the provision of bicycle lanes to new means, electric bicycles. . There is now a huge possibility of urban injury precisely for this reason. And I really think that this report helps and I propose to vote. Thanks.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every year in Europe, tens of thousands of people lose their lives in road accidents and the main causes continue to be excessive speed, distraction and drunk driving. The introduction of new technologies in vehicles is key to increasing road safety and the Commission must take responsibility for setting regulatory standards to ensure that new safety devices, such as emergency stop warning or digital pressure monitoring of tires, are present on all production cars, without additional costs for consumers. Considering that almost half of the victims of road accidents are pedestrians and cyclists, an effective global strategy for the safety of European transport cannot but start from the roads, from the often obsolete, poorly lit and dangerous infrastructures. Europe must raise the average quality of its infrastructures, especially in peripheral areas and small urban centers, transforming road safety into a driving force for the economy and a guarantee of safety for all European citizens.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Bulc, in Greece, my country, for every person killed in a car accident, there are 4 people with permanent disabilities, 8 serious injuries and 50 minor injuries. Road accidents in Greece cost 3 billion euros every year. New technology can help drastically reduce accidents and, indeed, the emergency lane, the speed return system to the prescribed limit, but also the diagnosis of distraction and driver fatigue are measures that we must adopt immediately and compulsorily. in the Member States. 72% of accidents are caused by human error. For this reason, we must at the same time upgrade the road safety education, with compulsory school lessons for children, teachers and employees. At the same time, we need to upgrade the technical control system in countries in crisis such as Greece, where the car fleet is almost abandoned. Finally, we must intensify the provision of immediate assistance, with the mandatory establishment of a coordination center in each Member State.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the report on saving lives and boosting car safety in the European Union is an important initiative that we must stand on, as thousands of our fellow citizens are losing their lives on the tarmac. The most important cause of accidents is alcohol consumption. At the same time, it is necessary to build serious infrastructure so that we can really drive on roads that are safe. I find it important that the emergency lane is always used and not occupied by all drivers. At the same time, we must pay special attention to accidents involving pedestrians and especially cyclists, which is why municipalities are required to take concrete initiatives to modernize infrastructure with money from the European Union itself. Significant traffic education of the students themselves is required. With these measures we will be able to really prevent the thousands of accidents and accidents that are happening in the European Union.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - I certainly support Mr Koch's report, which also falls at a time when the Commissioner I welcome, and I am also pleased that she herself is supporting this report, is preparing a third mobility package. The death toll is declining, so in Europe, we have heard, on European roads. There is a similar trend in Slovenia as well, although unfortunately in our country this decline has stopped in recent years and we need to do more so that there will be fewer victims. The facts are that the person who causes the most accidents needs good ... appropriate infrastructure, to pay attention to those who are most vulnerable in this traffic, that is, pedestrians as well as cyclists, to take care of additional cycling routes, and at the same time these to incorporate new technologically advanced technologies into cars as much as possible, because we all test these technologies in some way and we know that they help us a lot. That is why I strongly support this package, I think it is very important and the European Parliament, the European Commission has already done a lot in this area, and it is right that we continue to do so in the future.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Mr President, when talking about car safety there are a few elements which create this car safety. One is quality of roads, and because of that I believe the Cohesion Policy post-2020 should continue to invest in ensuring the key roads and key transport corridors of the European Union are of good quality so as to prevent any accidents because of the quality of the road.  Another thing, at least for me, is odometer fraud, which puts at risk all passengers and drivers on the road, without even mentioning the almost EUR 10 billion of damage to the economy and customers. Moreover, there are a number of studies showing that almost one third of all second-hand vehicles sold on major European markets have manipulated odometers.  I believe that a pilot project I proposed to the Commission this June is one of the answers to fight that fraud. I think this could be an example of how a single pilot project, funded by the European Union, could deliver a solution for such a problem, which has been a burden to people for decades.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Koch for presenting a very stimulating report. I would like to say that the Czech Republic, together with Latvia, has seen the largest decline in accidents with these fatal and serious injuries to road users, and it is important to emphasize that unfortunately European roads are not among the safest in the world and it is important just reducing that number to 25,000 dead a year. To this end, it is important to certainly involve a change in infrastructure, what my colleague Novakov said, we think is a very stimulating proposal. Secondly, of course, it is also necessary to change the safety equipment in cars, and there are also a number of stimuli for this. And thirdly, it is important to think about the driver and his skills and abilities, such as recognizing pedestrians or cyclists who are also involved in road traffic. So all three measures need to be changed so that we can achieve precisely the goal of halving the number of accidents for the next period.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the protection of human life is a key factor to consider when and how often we need to improve some technology systems. This of course also applies to the construction and use of state-of-the-art vehicles, which must be constructed in such a way as to guarantee that accidents are reduced. Of course, for this to happen there must be other conditions. There should be good roads, there should be systems to assist driving and, in addition, there should be a process of checks, both on the vehicles and on the roads on which these vehicles are moving, as well as the protection of cyclists, who are particularly sensitive to accidents. Finally, because as the ancient Greeks used to say "a man of all money", driver training plays a very important role. Drivers should not get into and use a vehicle unless they are sure that they know how to drive and if they do not comply with the provisions that ensure the protection of citizens. In addition, man should control the machines and not be controlled by them.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, we take note of your clear request from to accelerate the work. The Transport Ministers of the Member States have already reconfirmed their commitment to improving road safety. This is evident from the very ambitious Valletta Declaration that was unanimously adopted by Transport Ministers in March this year. Notably they called on the Commission to enhance the protection of road users, and especially vulnerable road users, by ensuring the deployment of new safety features for vehicles. This is what we are doing. The Commission is working hard to adopt the proposal to amend the General Safety Regulation and the Pedestrian Safety Regulation. Our objective is to do this as part of the third mobility package in the first half of next year, but this is not all. In the same package we will also present a proposal to improve infrastructure safety. You rightly highlight in your report that we need to improve the state of road infrastructure to increase its safety.  But before I conclude, please allow me to address some of your comments. On driver distraction monitoring, this is indeed on our radar. We have determined that this will be a cost—effective measure to include in the package of measures, so you can look forward to that. On proper tyre pressure, tyre pressure monitoring has been mandatory for all new passenger cars sold since 2014, but light and heavy commercial vehicles, as well as buses, are currently not subject to tyre pressure monitoring requirements. The Commission report suggests that tyre pressure monitoring should also become mandatory in light and heavy commercial vehicles and buses. I hope I can count on your support. On medical prescriptions, this is a perfect example of the need to raise awareness through appropriate training courses and information campaigns. Member States certainly need to work on those issues. Please encourage them. We will only succeed if Member States also adopt an integrated approach. On infrastructure safety, let me restress that this topic will also be addressed in our third mobility package to be adopted in the first half of next year. Our objective is to approach road safety in a very comprehensive, holistic manner. But the good news is – and this is worth mentioning – that we have also engaged our neighbouring countries, including the six Western Balkan countries, Turkey and the Eastern Partnership countries, to join us in our efforts in an active manner because we travel in our neighbouring countries as well.  On affordability, the cost-effectiveness of each specific safety device and technology is a key element of our preparatory work. Our impact assessment will consider, in particular, the impact on consumers. The affordability of the mandated technologies is evidently a must.  All of this will be accompanied by a document setting out our vision for the future framework for road safety post—2020, and key measures that we consider indispensable to reverse the stagnating trend. Allow me to point out one more time that road safety is a shared responsibility. Some of the issues you highlighted should be addressed at national and regional level but, when it comes to leading the world with a highly ambitious and effective approach to improve road safety across the board, you can rest assured that the Commission will make every effort needed.  I certainly treat road safety as a top priority when it comes to my portfolio. This is why we added road safety as an important part of the Spring mobility package, where it will be addressed in a very systemic way. I can only hope that this will be a sufficient push to see statistics on road fatalities and serious injuries substantially decreasing again.  Thank you for a constructive cooperation, in the future as well. Finally, let me thank Mr Koch once again and thank all of you that we care so much together.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner Bulc, ladies and gentlemen! We had an interesting, lively, and focused debate. My thanks go to everyone who took part, but above all to Mr Ferber, who spoke on my behalf at short notice. But I would also like to thank all those in committee who gave me advice and amendments to encourage, support and guide me on the right track. My special thanks go to my assistant, Cezara Petruc. Driver assistance systems do a lot. But they cannot do everything. Above all, don't let cars drive autonomously. Therefore, road users should know their limits. I recommend that drivers of vehicles with driver assistance systems familiarize themselves with the possibilities, but also the limits of these systems. Physical laws cannot override these systems either. I recommend to all drivers: Please remain attentive, keep your hands on the wheel and do not test the emergency braking system unnecessarily, for example. Because driver assistance systems are not toys, but helping passengers in emergency situations. I also recommend all Member States to work even more carefully on EU-wide accident data statistics, which also include a list of injuries and those involved in accidents. This is the only way we can identify specific measures that actually improve road safety, such as driver assistance systems. The EU Commission has proposed 19 measures as part of the update of the regulation on general vehicle safety. In a consultation that ended on October 22nd, it sought the views of stakeholders, including private individuals and local authorities. I'm curious about the result, which she plans to publish in the coming year as part of the revision of the General Safety Ordinance. We should A large majority will provide the EU Commission with important information on vehicle safety tomorrow in order to avoid even more accidents and save lives as quickly as possible.Because every person who dies on the European roads is one too many.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 14 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - Despite the fact that European roads remain the safest in the world, statistics still show a worrying number of traffic victims. Every year, in Europe over 25,000 people lose their lives on community roads, and 135,000 suffer serious accidents, the social cost of these tragedies - from rehabilitation, health care, damage, etc. - reaching approximately 100 billion Euros. In addition, the data of each country show that the number of road accidents still varies greatly across the EU, and the progress made by countries such as Romania - where there is a high number of deaths per million inhabitants - is insignificant. Based on these figures, the EP report raises a strong alarm about the measures that the Commission and the Member States must take to achieve their goal of halving the number of road accidents by 2020. National authorities must step up efforts to enforce legislation and raise awareness and educate citizens. At the same time, we call on the Brussels executive to monitor the situation more closely, to help Member States improve their performance by facilitating the exchange of data and to adopt legislation as soon as possible to sanction cross-border crime.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am in favor of new road safety devices becoming standard equipment. We would like to see driver assistance systems, such as cruise control, automatic braking systems and the lane-keeping assist system, become mandatory on all new vehicles. The figures speak for themselves: 25,500 people die on European roads and 135,000 more are seriously injured on our roads each year. With this vote, the European Parliament is therefore in favor of technologies that create more safety on the road. Among the measures proposed, we would like the detection of so-called weak users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists to be compulsory; helping drivers avoid them would save many lives. More specifically for trucks and buses, we would also like to have front, side and rear cameras installed as well as cornering assistance systems which are very useful in reducing blind spots.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the persecution of Christians worldwide (2017/2957 (RSP)).This is a very important debate for many of us.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the persecution of Christian minorities worldwide has been a recurring primary concern of this House. Only last May, the plenary debated the situation of Christians in the Middle East. As Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative Madam Mogherini firmly stated on that occasion, the freedom of religion or belief is a fundamental right of every human being. All persons should be able to practise their religion and worship freely, individually or in community with others, and to live free from fear. This applies to people of all faiths, or none, including to Christians. Yet we know that religious freedom is under attack in many parts of our world. Sectarianism is one of the diseases of our age. The millennial diversity of many societies is put at risk by the rise of the sectarian hatred. No continent has been spared from this kind of violence, from South Asia to Sub-Saharan Africa. This Parliament has often focused on the persecution of Christian minorities in the Middle East, and rightly so. Christians are discriminated against, harassed and persecuted in large parts of the Middle East, and the number of Christians is drastically decreasing. Christianity was born in the Middle East; it belongs to those lands, and this is something we cannot possibly forget. If the Middle East loses its incredible diversity, it would also lose its vitality and its greatest richness. At the same time, persecution rarely targets just one minority. As we see in Syria and Iraq, not only Christians but also Yazidis, Shia Muslims and other religious communities are suffering from discrimination, harassment and persecution. Therefore, a long-term strategic approach to protect Christian and other religious groups must focus on addressing those ideologies and changing those state structures that encourage discrimination and violence. Such violence may be committed by state or non-state actors for a number of different reasons. Ideology is certainly one of them, but it is not the only one. In many cases, the persecution of Christians and other minorities has political, ethnic or economic reasons. Very often, it is more about power than about religion itself. This is something we need to keep in mind if we want to make a real difference to the life of Christian minorities around the world. For this reason, our approach has focused on security as well as on culture and education, but also on diplomacy, governance and national reconciliation. We always react with public statements or private demarches to condemn violence against Christians. Let me also focus on other actions we have taken in defence of persons belonging to minorities.  First, since the adoption of the EU Guidelines on the promotion and protection of freedom of religion or belief in 2013, their implementation has remained a key priority for EU action. Second, the EEAS taskforce on religion and culture has led to an increased exchange on religious freedom and religious engagement both inside the EEAS, with Commission DGs and with European Parliament services. The EEAS actively participates in, and co-chairs, the Transatlantic Policy Network on Religion and Diplomacy. A number of concrete initiatives on diversity and tolerance have grown out of this network. Third, the EEAS also actively encourages cooperation among Member States on this issue. The Council’s Working Party on Human Rights (COHOM) created a taskforce on freedom of religion. It works on informal information exchanges on events and situations on the ground, and in preparation of EU resolutions at the United Nations. The Council’s Working Party on Human Rights’ informal meeting in Malta on April 2017 had a full dedicated session on freedom of religion and belief.  Fourth, during this year, the EU’s Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, continued being actively engaged on freedom of religion and belief. He has placed special emphasis on the implementation of the UN Rabat Plan of Action that includes positive elements to address hate speech and to counter violence perpetrated in the name of religion. Mr Ján Figeľ, the Special Envoy for the promotion of the freedom of religion or belief outside the EU, has also worked on the implementation of the EU Guidelines on freedom of religion and belief, particularly on his visits to Iraq, the United Arab Emirates, Jordan and Sudan.  Fifth, the EU also uses all its financial instruments to support this endeavour. The European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights now finances around 40 projects related to freedom of religion and belief accounting for more than EUR 15 million. The Commission’s Directorate General for Development has recently launched a new call for proposals for intercultural dialogue and culture. This programme envisages cooperation with partner countries on intercultural dialogue for peaceful inter-community relations. Sixth, we also continue cooperation with UNESCO, the UN alliance of civilisations, the Anna Lindh Foundation and the Istanbul process.  Seventh, education is the best tool for building open societies and for avoiding radicalisation. In this day and age, education in emergencies and protracted crises has become particularly urgent. Think of the Syrian children, who can only remember a country at war. It is essential to teach them about their country’s incredible diversity and about centuries of peaceful coexistence. A peaceful and diverse future for Syria also depends on their education. Next year, we will devote 8% of the EU’s humanitarian budget to education in emergencies. In the Syria crisis, the EU’s contribution to education is over EUR 1 billion, through the various financing instruments we have put in place since the beginning of the conflict. Let me conclude on another part of our work against violence on Christians that may not be as evident, but which is just as important. In many parts of the world, a sustainable future for Christians and other religious groups depends on the work we are doing today for peace, for national reconciliation, for inclusive institutions. Syria, again, is the clearest example. We are working every day to help Syrians find a political solution to the war and build a country where all Syrians, including Christians, can feel at home. Diversity, respect and inclusiveness are not abstract concepts. To millions of people, they can make the difference between persecution and security, between fear and freedom, between life and death. I know this Parliament understands this, and we truly count on your support to continue our fight against all forms of violence and discrimination.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, the statistics that can be read are terrible. The world has more than 215 million Christians who cannot enjoy their rights. North Korea leads the rankings. Under Kim Jong-un’s regime, 300,000 Christians live in total hiding and 50,000 of them are locked up in forced labor camps. In North Korea, the mere fact of having a bible earns you life imprisonment in one of these camps. There are fewer and fewer North Korean Christian refugees who manage to flee because of China's ruthless policy, which sends them back to their country where their chances of survival are non-existent. There are many other examples of this type. The situation of Christians in Africa is terrible. In Somalia, for example, the terrorist group Al-Chabab has set itself the task of eliminating all Christians. In Sudan, the government plans to demolish 27 churches and so on ... So you really have to tell it like it is. I do not agree with the commissioner who relativizes all these situations. It must be said that the defense of religious freedom must be at the center of our external relations. This is not the case today and we must not hide this reality. I also recall the dramatic situation of Christians in the territories of ancient Mesopotamia, in Syria and in Iraq: they have lost everything and will not be able to return home quietly.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President! Religious freedom is a universal human right, and this includes not only the right to practice one's religion freely, but also the right to change one's religion and the right not to belong to any religion. Any violation of this principle is a violation of human rights and is to be condemned everywhere and under all circumstances - such as in the Middle East, where a historically unique violation of this principle has taken place in recent years - can hardly be surpassed in brutality and inhumanity . This applies not only, but above all, to Christians and Yazidis. Now that the regime of the self-proclaimed caliphate is collapsing, we must do everything we can to create conditions so that people can return to their ancestral lands, that justice is done to all victims, that criminals are sentenced and, above all, that people can build trust in one another . As utopian as it may sound now, it is imperative to think about reconciliation in this region. Perhaps this tragedy that we have been through will also herald a change in awareness in the region. The principle “cuius regio, eius religio” is not suitable for the 21st century. Especially countries like Saudi Arabia, which like to talk about a new future, talk about modernization, talk about a global role, should think twice. There is still no church there, and Filipino housemaids - it has been reported - are punished if a Bible is found on them.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Mr. President, the persecution of Christians is often discussed in this House and this is the best indicator that we do not have the capacity, and obviously not the sincere desire, to work diligently on solutions that would improve their situation. If we had, the situation would have improved after previous discussions, and we would not be repeating here today what has been said so many times so far. Unfortunately, the European Union is increasingly fleeing from its Christian roots, so it is not surprising that in such an identity crisis, its leaders, as well as its citizens, are less and less willing to sacrifice their well-being to help Christians around the world. Aid by no means means invasion of foreign lands or the destruction of other cultures, but primarily a political and diplomatic struggle for the institutional equality of Christians where they are a minority and the establishment of the rule of law to finally protect their lives and property. The Union is the largest donor to third countries, an important trading partner for many of them, and has great ambitions to become a true global player that will be an indispensable partner in resolving crises. If the Union really wants to have global credibility, it should use its resources today to help vulnerable Christians. So how will members of other religions and cultures trust us if they see that we have turned our backs on those with whom we share Christian values?

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Europe stands on different philosophical, legal and moral pillars, but its history and identity are still difficult to understand without Christianity, even in the middle of the secular era. No other part of the world has been more influenced by Christianity, and no other part of the world can do more now to defend its survival and freedom in the face of persecution. I would just like to underline two facts in relation to the persecution of Christians. The first is that this persecution is global in nature and different indicators suggest that it is increasing, even in its most lethal dimensions. Christians are the religious group persecuted in the most countries. And, according to studies, between 60 and 80% of the acts of religious discrimination that take place around the world, carried out by both the States themselves and social groups, affect Christians. The second is that the persecution against Christians continues without receiving the coverage it deserves from the media, the major human rights associations and political institutions, including the European Union. We should be particularly concerned about the destruction of historic Christian communities that is taking place among our Mediterranean neighbors, an ordeal that threatens to spread to refugees who make it to Europe. Christians guard a valuable moral and cultural legacy that our Union is obligated to protect. And this we can understand believers and non-believers, as a citizen like me. Let us take advantage of the holding of this debate so that this issue enters with force on the European agenda.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, the persecution of Christians and the increase in it is real; it must be denounced and fought. But the problem is not the persecution only of Christians in particular: it is the increase in persecution for religious reasons around the world. And there are many examples: the savage persecution of Yazidis by the terrorist group Daesh; the genocide of the Rohingya Muslim minority in Myanmar, with at least 270,000 fled and more than 2,000 murdered, a massacre systematically organized by the Government of that country with the connivance of a Nobel Peace Prize winner and much applauded and cheered by members of this House: President Aung San Suu Kyi, who was awarded the Sakharov Prize in 1990; the repression in Egypt of the igures; the persecution in Yemen of the Baha'i religious minority; in Pakistan, any criticism of religion can be condemned with the death penalty; or in Malaysia, where there is a minister, Mr. Shahidan Kassim, who defended this summer to hunt down atheists. And we must not forget the increase in Islamophobia in many European countries, fueled by racist and xenophobic hysteria from all parties of the extreme right, but also from apparently more respectable political forces. The commitment of the European Parliament must be firm against discrimination and the increase in violence linked to religious differences. Addressing this global problem by choosing only one of the persecuted religions is to fuel religious conflict and the logic of hatred and confrontation.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! The world today is plagued by protracted conflicts, many of them with multiple ethnic and religious dimensions. Wars and conflicts have created tragedies as part of the reason why more than 65 million people are on the run inside or outside their home countries. Attacks on various religious groups have increased markedly, not only against Christians but also against other religious minority groups, e.g. Shiites and Yazidis. However, the situation for the group of Christians has deteriorated dramatically in recent years. The persecution is global and takes place in various parts of the world, including North Korea, Somalia, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Sudan, China, Eritrea, Iraq, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Egypt, India, Iran and Turkey. In some countries, the state is the main persecutor, while in others it is individual groups that are at fault - most often, however, it is a combination of both. The main problem is not that it is precisely Christians who are persecuted, but that there are so many countries, regimes and groups that violate religious freedom, which affects all religious groups and minorities. According to the Christian international aid organization Open Doors and their annual World Watch List report on the persecution of Christians around the world, the persecution of Christians has reached new heights, and today more than 200 million Christians face severe persecution for their faith, affecting nearly one in ten practitioners. One region that stands out in terms of the extent and intensity of persecution of religious groups is the Middle East. The number of Christians in Iraq has decreased by 80 percent to less than 300,000 compared to the previous total of 1.6 million in the country. In Syria, there has been a decrease from 1.2 million to 500,000 since the beginning of the war. Although Christians have lived in the Middle East for over 2,000 years, they now make up only 3–4 percent of the region's population. Their continued existence in the region is thus seriously threatened. The ethno-religious division and conflicts between different groups has made all minorities more vulnerable. In some areas, Christians, Yazidis, and other religious minorities have been persecuted by the Daish and killed for their faith. Many have been driven from their homes and forced to seek refuge in neighboring countries and in the EU. In my country Sweden there is today one of the world's largest diaspora of the Christian group Assyrians / Syrians / Chaldeans, and it has grown rapidly as a result of Daish's ethnic cleansing in the Middle East. Daish has certainly been expelled from its strongholds in Iraq and Syria, and some of those displaced may return home, but the situation remains difficult for religious minority groups in the Middle East. Despite the fact that the right to freedom of thought, conscience and freedom of religion is enshrined in international law and is granted to every individual, regardless of religion, many oppressed groups feel betrayed and ignored by the UN and the international community. As one of the largest contributors in the region, the EU has a role to play, partly in promoting political dialogue with a view to enabling a sustainable and peaceful future for Christians in the Middle East, and partly by involving its residents in the negotiations. about their future.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, throughout the UK and in many other countries throughout the West, many Christians have been denied the right to wear a simple expression of their faith, such as a crucifix, in public life. The right to hold and express faith is a fundamental human right which must be protected and defended equally. The UK was founded on a Judaeo-Christian culture and whilst we respect and appreciate the contribution of all, this must be respected.  But the trials and tribulations of Christians in many countries throughout the West pale in comparison to what many must face on a daily basis throughout other parts of the world. The persecution of Christians, Shia and other religions and ethnic minorities, during the rise of the Islamic State was well publicised. However, we must be constantly wary of persecution of Christians: it is still [going on] and many will be unable to get appropriate assistance after being displaced by conflict throughout the region. As the terror of Islamic State rule is rolled back, we must ensure that the seeds of future conflict and societal discontent are averted and reprisal attacks are not carried out. This may not be an easy task, but the cycle of shifting persecution as power changes hands must be broken. As these countries are rebuilt, the place of Christians and their rights must be protected.  The recent political instability caused by the sudden resignation of Hariri as Prime Minister of Lebanon is a sharp warning that the Shia-Sunni war propagated by Saudi Arabia and Iran could be spreading into the country, and we must ensure that minorities are not marginalised in any political fallout from the future developments in this country. Christianity is an ancient religion with firm roots in the Middle East. The place of Christians throughout the region must be protected. If the countries of the Middle East are ever to get past this cycle of religious persecution, they must develop a more inclusive model of national identity that extends beyond religion and is fully inclusive and respectful of all minorities who deserve to practise their faith free from persecution, and in many cases, free from threats to their lives.

name: Christelle Lechevalier
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, 215 million Christians suffer serious persecution in their country because of their religion. International relations are primarily the responsibility of the Member States, but it should be remembered that certain countries concerned have special relations with the European Union or its members. Turkey, Qatar, but also China where 300 churches were devastated in 2016. Among them, some are classified in the 20 most dangerous for Christians, in particular India, of which the Union is the first trading partner and the Vietnam, where the government is implicated in the persecutions, and which benefits from privileged trade agreements. If the cases of these extra-European countries are serious and require strong diplomatic pressure, let us not forget our own situation. In Europe, 100 churches were destroyed in 2016. In France, these acts have increased by 245% in 8 years. Everywhere the security of Christians recedes with each advance of Islamist fundamentalism. In our countries, I remind you, of Christian culture, Christians are killed for their religion, the assassinations of Father Hamel in Saint-Étienne-du-Rouvray and that of a young convert in Grande-Synthe in 2016, testify to this. Within European institutions which deny their Christian roots, a change of policy must take place. Let us act to defend Christians in the world and in Europe, where anti-Christian acts will multiply, including among us.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, yesterday, in the United Kingdom, communities and families paused to remember those across the nation who had laid down their lives in defence of freedom. Through their sacrifice we, like past generations, enjoy the benefits of a fair and democratic way of life. We are afforded fundamental freedoms of thought, belief, opinion and expression and, without restriction or recrimination, we are able to attend a religious place of worship. How often do we take these liberties for granted? Open Doors estimates that every month, across our world, 322 Christians are killed because of their faith, and 772 forms of violence are committed against Christians. These are shocking statistics but we must ask ourselves, are we doing enough?  We have a responsibility to provide a beacon of hope to those who continue to suffer daily – to support those whose sacrifice has not yet been translated into freedom for themselves and their families. And national governments must renew their commitment to these basic liberties in their dealings and discussions with countries across the world. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Dodds, the King of Morocco, Commander of the Faithful and a descendant of the Prophet Muhammad, protects the rights of Christians in Morocco. Would you say, Madam, that he is a fine example to Muslims throughout the world, and that this is the sort of leadership that we should see in the Muslim world: protection of Christians by Muslims?

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Coburn. I think that all of us in this House must be very concerned about the persecution and, indeed, some would say the genocide of Christians, throughout the Middle East. We have only to look at the sights in Syria, in Iraq, and see the devastation of Christian communities. Indeed, I have been pleased to actually meet and talk with some of those Christians and hear their stories of persecution, of death and destruction, and I think it is incumbent upon this House and these institutions to make sure that these terrible atrocities are raised on a continuous basis and that we deal with them in our discussions with these countries. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Dodds, just a short question. I think you come from Northern Ireland, is that right? You have had war in Ireland between Christians. How does this link up with the war within Christianity?

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – The war and the trouble and terrorism in Northern Ireland is really about a vicious terrorist campaign to push a people into a united Ireland who do not give their consent to such a way forward. Thankfully, we are in better times, and since my colleague is from Germany, I must say I visited Berlin last week. I visited Wittenberg, the place of the Reformation in Germany, and it was a delight to see the memorials there to Martin Luther and 500 years of the Reformation, which has done so much to transform our society and which did so much to transform Germany.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Europe has a special responsibility in the protection of persecuted Christians. I thank Mr Vella very much for joining this debate today with his statement. It has always been difficult to stand up for Christians in this House. There are massive dividing lines among us. The EPP believes that providing support for Christians cannot be a matter of ideology. This is clearly a human rights, security, cultural, and of course spiritual, issue as well. But we must overcome these dividing lines. Thank God we are already getting some results. Last year Parliament condemned the genocide by Daesh against Christians, but now we really must turn our political resolution into action. The EU and the bilateral diplomacy of our countries must ensure that these violations of human rights and atrocities against Christians are finished. Christians and other churches are often the only actors who take care of the persecuted on the spot, but they have no access to direct EU aid. This has truly been a scandal for many years now. These churches must be eligible for EU funding. For example, a reconstruction programme for displaced Christians is underway in North Iraq. Europe must take part in financing this very concrete project in close partnership with the churches. This is our last chance to save Europe’s credibility. Certain states, like my country, Hungary, implement direct aid on the ground for these persecuted communities. Now Europe as a whole must realise the historical exercise, preserving the presence of Christians in their homelands.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the real issue underlying this debate is the issue of religious freedom in the world. We in Europe know too well what religious intolerance means so that we do not leave or should not stop talking about it. Unfortunately, today, in most parts of the world, solutions of political organization prevail that do not take due account of this fundamental principle, which is the principle of the right of everyone to freely express their religious beliefs or the absence of belief, when appropriate. Theocratic regimes, in the name of one religion, completely nullify all others. The regimes that practice militant atheism persecute those who seek to pursue any kind of religious worship and, unfortunately, these countries still have enormous weight around the world today, in addition to what are today also attacks on religious freedom that do not have direct origin of the States, but they are promoted by some groups, namely terrorist groups, that throughout the world are attacking men and women for the simple circumstance of pursuing a certain religious cult. Christians are particularly affected and we, I believe, we Europeans have a responsibility at the level of our diplomatic action to try to sensitize the other countries with which we have relations, and where this respect for this fundamental human right that it is the right of religious freedom, for them to do more in that direction. This is also one of the duties of our diplomacy. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: blue card question.- Mr President, colleague, our issue today is not secularism, it is specific; it is the persecution of Christians.The crusades are long gone, but there is a particular religion that has manifested through its fanaticism and terrorist acts that it wants to kill Christians.How do you explain that?

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- If the question is not posed as I posed it, from my point of view, as a question of religious freedom, we will quickly be just fanning against fanaticism.The issue is deeper and it is a question of religious freedom and, from that point of view, Europe, in fact, has some lessons to give, it has no lessons to receive, because we were able to build a secular space where it is possible tocoexistence of people who follow the most diverse convictions of a religious order, from those who are atheists, agnostics, to those who follow this or that religion.If we get out of this line, from my point of view, we will quickly, as we did in the past, enter wars of fanaticism against fanaticism.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: - Yesterday, for the ninth time, we celebrated the Day of Solidarity with the Persecuted Church throughout Poland.This time it was dedicated to saving Christians in the Middle East - in the cradle of Christianity.Poles are not a rich society.However, millions of my countrymen got involved in the voluntary collection.The scale of this undertaking, specific programs that finance undertakings in the Middle East: housing, health, education, and return to home make this program unique on a global scale.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: - (FI) Mr President, recent reports of the persecution of Christians around the world point to serious human rights violations. The European Union and various actors must take very seriously the difficult situation of Christians in Syria and Iraq, for example, with as many as 50-80% of Christians having to leave their homeland. The point is not that they have taken some new religion there, but that Christians have lived in those areas for more than 2,000 years - more than 500 years even before the birth of Islam. We should urgently find adequate means to prevent the destruction of the assets of Syrian and Iraqi Christians and the trampling of their constitutional rights. The persecution of Christians is leading to the loss of the strong cultural tradition in the Middle East, and it is also a defeat for all of us. The constitutions of both countries - both Syria and Iraq - guarantee the same rights to the followers of all religions. In reality, however, this is not the case. Christians have also significantly built these societies and acted as balancing parties in conflicts. There should therefore be no basis for persecution. In China, too, North Korean Christians have been persecuted. Some of them have fled North Korea for faith, but some have embraced Christianity in China. Christians who are returned to North Korea end up in forced labor camps, and those camps usually do not survive. It is estimated that between 50,000 and 70,000 Christians are imprisoned in these camps. China must strive to protect the North Korean Christians who fled there and offer them security and allow full freedom to practice their religion. The strong influence of Hindu nationalists on Indian domestic politics has also led to a reversal of general attitudes against other religions. Christians in particular have found themselves on the line there. We cannot accept action like this in a democratic country like India. I could still mention South Sudan, where church workers have been imprisoned and churches have been destroyed.Here, too, we should address it, because we must remember that freedom of religion is one of the fundamental human rights that we must vigorously demand as Europeans, based on our own values.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: - Mister President! Yes, there are alarming examples of the persecution of Christians around the world. According to Open Doors, 50,000 to 70,000 Christians are locked up in camps as traitors to the state in North Korea alone, and death is most likely awaiting them there. A few refugee routes lead to China, but from there you are also deported back to North Korea. But Christians are also systematically oppressed on their own doorstep, in front of Europe's doorstep - in Turkey. Property of Christian organizations is expropriated and then placed under the administration of the Sunni state religious organization Diyanet. But of course there are also positive things to report, for example from the Kurdish region in northern Iraq, where the Christians expelled by the IS have been taken in, are being protected, and where they are even helping to rebuild the destroyed churches. Unfortunately - and it must be said - it is a fact that we like to complain about the persecution of Christians here, but we are not aware of our Christian roots and that the Union is doing far too little to protect the persecuted Christians in the world.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, as the two previous speakers have said, Christianity is still persecuted by the militant atheism of communism which has claimed tens of millions of victims in this area. But he is also persecuted, of course and mainly today, by Islamism. We cannot, ourselves, with our limited means, stop the atrocities of the Islamists, but we have bargaining power. Negotiating power with governments because there is an official persecution of Christians in the fact that the legislations of a number of Muslim states, with which we have excellent relations, prohibit, for example, the fact, sometimes under penalty of death, to abandon the Muslim religion to convert or have in their provisions crimes such as blasphemy which in reality allow to imprison, or even to condemn to death, any Christian who would cast doubts on the legitimacy of the Koran . This should not be tolerated any longer, and here we can, with our modest means, although parliamentarians, achieve something: we must demand reciprocity. Why is there not a single chapel in Saudi Arabia when my country is covered with mosques?

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: - Freedom of religion is a fundamental human right, and nowadays more than 300 Christians are killed every month, we record almost 800 victims of violence, and over 200 churches are destroyed. It is happening all over the world, from North Korea to Africa. However, I am proud to say that Parliament, as one of the first institutions in the world alongside the US Congress, in February 2016 recognized ISIS's crime against Christians and other minorities as genocide. I urge the High Representative to express this position in her international activities. Recognition as genocide has legal consequences. The victims, their relatives and, in general, the situation in the region, need this judgment and punishment of the guilty. The entire international community needs it. In 2013, the Council adopted guidelines for the promotion and protection of freedom of religion. And the guidelines that we have also worked on in Parliament provide an excellent basis, but must be implemented much more efficiently than before. I would like to emphasize the important fact of the appointment of a special envoy for the promotion of religious freedom outside the Union, following Parliament's resolution of February 2016. However, the mandate of the envoy, Jan Figel, who is doing an extraordinary job, needs to be strengthened. This seems to me to be particularly important when it comes to high-level integration with the European External Action Service. In Parliament, we constantly monitor the affairs of Christians in the world. I would also like to emphasize that next week we will hold a special hearing at the Subcommittee on Human Rights on religious persecution, in particular the persecution of Christians. At the same time, I would like to thank my colleagues, coordinators from other groups, for understanding and supporting this topic.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: - "Hope for a Miracle - The Future of Christian Presence in Iraq". This is the telling title of a recent publication by the German expert Dr. Otmar Oehring. He will speak for us in Brussels next week. From a human point of view, there seems to be scarcely a future for the centuries-old Christian communities in the Land of Two Rivers. Especially now that Iraqi and Kurdish claims to rule over the Nineveh plain have already led to fighting. The sad consequence was, for example, that returned Christians in the Assyrian town of Teleskof had to leave their recently restored homes for an unknown destination. Another major obstacle to the return of Iraqi Christians to the Nineveh Plains today is the intimidation of neighboring Iran and the Tehran-affiliated Iraqi Shia militia. Is the European Union, the High Representative aware of this new expulsion, expulsion, of Iraqi Christians? I would like to hear what the EU can do to protect and maintain the Christian presence in Iraq. A concrete EU action program is really necessary, as colleagues have already shown before, because then we are really proud and we stand for our Christian values.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, dear colleagues, according to a Vatican Radio program, 500 million Christians are persecuted in their faith, 90,000 were killed in 2016. Even in present-day Europe, everything that testifies to our Christian identity, toour Christian history, our Christian culture can not only be ignored, but even be suppressed.Our Europe is at the service of a new world order which has taken the place of the rights of God and therefore of religions in the name of the freedom of human rights, revised by triumphant individualism and relativism.Ours is an exclusive religion and the search for sanctions against Poland must be understood as Europe's struggle against the refusal of this people to abortion, gender and euthanasia.Only a Europe respectful of its religious identities can hope for and inspire respect for all religions and avoid Christian persecution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, unfortunately, even today, Christians are persecuted in 140 countries and some 100,000 people have suffered and been killed because of their faith. Although Islamic State jihadists are by far the first persecutors and killers of Christians, having carried out a genocide in Syria and Iraq, there are other countries in the world where Christians are persecuted, such as China, North Korea, Iran. , Iraq, Nigeria - because of Boko Haram - and Turkey. Turkey in particular, which has persecuted and killed mostly Orthodox Christians for more than 1,000 years, continues to use the same tactics. Even today, he challenges the European Union and Greece, as he has taken the first steps to turn the symbol of Orthodoxy, the Church of Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, into a mosque, and refuses to open the Theological School of Halki, which has been closed for 45 years. How do Christian countries respond to these challenges? They are indifferent and, possessed by a paradoxical, unexplained and inadmissible phobic syndrome, they hide the persecution of Christians by their citizens. Christian countries must protect Christians, it is a matter of honor for them. Finally, they must behave in a similar way in Turkey, which neither is nor should become a member of the European Community.

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, finally a debate entirely devoted to the persecution of Christians throughout the world. I am delighted to see that my request expressed in July 2014 has finally been echoed in this hemicycle. I want to thank the presidency for that. Commissioner, I would also like to thank you for your presence, although I think that, given the subject and its diplomatic impact, the presence of Mrs Mogherini would have been very useful as well. Ladies and gentlemen parliamentarians, we are ready - and I am delighted to do so - to defend all religious minorities in the face of intolerance. It is paradoxical that when it comes to Christians it is so difficult to get a debate in the European Parliament. When Muslims are persecuted in Burma, all the states of the Arab world protest and we ourselves vote a resolution to echo this protest and to fight intolerance. When Jews are attacked anywhere in the world, Israel knows how to respond and we strongly and rightly condemn anti-Semitism. But by a form of incomprehensible, even unjustifiable form of self-censorship, we Europeans, ignoring our roots and the origin of our civilization, do not dare to express our solidarity and our support when it comes to Christians who are persecuted. . Previous speakers have reminded us: more than 200 million Christians are persecuted, killed, forced to flee their countries of origin, to abandon the cradle of their civilization. We cannot remain motionless and silent in the face of so much barbarism. Mr President, as chair of the working group on tolerance and protection of religious minorities in our Parliament, I ask you: when will the European Union finally assume its responsibilities? What is the plan against persecution? How will we concretely defend our values ​​and those who share them?

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, last week I had an opportunity to visit Pakistan, and as we debate persecuted Christians we need to mention the name of Asia Bibi, a woman, wife, mother, who has already spent eight years in a prison cell, facing a death sentence for a minor religious thing.  We hear a lot in this House about so-called European values and we hear about so-called LGBT rights; we speak about abortion rights; we speak about international rights. And this House is passionate about those rights. But when it comes to those who share the faith of our founding fathers, many times we do not do too much, and this is a sign we are abandoning Christianity, we turn a deaf ear and remain silent.  So I implore you, Commissioner, with all the diplomatic and economic instruments the European Union has, please let us make these countries, like Pakistan, Syria, Iraq and some others, hear this. We will not forsake our biblical roots, and we remain committed to those who are suffering because of their faith in Christ. I implore you.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, in the last century the Communist dictatorships and the Ottoman Empire violently persecuted Christians. Certain atheistic regimes, such as the French secularists, the Spanish republicans or the Mexican revolutionaries, did the same. Today, many still suffer and die because of their faith. The "Aid to the Church in Need" and "Open Doors" reports are alarming: nearly 200 million Christians, 50 countries affected. In communist China, Christian refugees are sent back to North Korea with only death or internment camps as their sole outcome, in the Middle East and Africa, they are victims of institutional Islamism or jihadist, in India, the fundamentalists Hindus are increasing the bullying and the list goes on. If European leaders want to be heard, they must be consistent. It is hypocritical to take pity on the plight of persecuted Christians while refusing to recall Europe's Christian roots in treaties and vilifying Polish, Hungarian, Russian or American leaders for their attachment to their Christian identity. people. Let us first respect our traditions and our spiritual heritage, battered by decades of consumerist individualism and reasonable accommodation with Islamism.
