name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, today I think we need to state some key facts. First, the persecution of millions of people because of their Christian beliefs is widespread and is increasing. Second, Christians are the most persecuted religion in the world: 75% of religiously motivated violence is carried out against Christians. Persecution has intensified in many countries such as China, Iran, India, Nigeria and others. Third, special attention needs to be paid to the situation and future of Christians in Iraq and Syria. Today, despite the defeat inflicted on Daesh, Christians there face an uncertain future and further discrimination. In Iraq the number of Christians has plummeted five times in ten years, to less than 300 000. What do we need to do? First, to keep the persecution of Christians high on the EU agenda, mainstreaming it in relations with all third countries. Second, to generate awareness in Europe that Christianity is part of the European spiritual and cultural legacy and that this legacy has formed the European values and identity. Third, we need concrete commitment for the reconstruction of Christian homes on the Nineveh plains and elsewhere and also to provide direct access to EU humanitarian aid for Christian churches. And fourth, we need to do everything to prevent situations whereby new conflicts in the Middle East will force the last remnants of Christians to leave their ancient homes.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: - Christians are the most discriminated and persecuted religious group in the world. According to Open Doors, as many as two hundred million Christians are subject to such persecution. Every year, the European Parliament indicates and condemns cases of crimes and discrimination in individual countries of the world, and there are as many as fifty countries on this infamous list. It is good that we have been holding appropriate debates in Strasbourg for several years, denouncing these shameful practices. Unfortunately, the resolutions voted in our House do not have the desired effect. The European Union was founded by Christian Democrats. This predestines her not only to display her Christian roots, but also to protect Christian values ​​and Christians, both on the continent and around the world. I believe that the EU agencies should be more decisive in the fight against persecution and with concrete help. Unfortunately, we are currently seeing a tendency for the European Union to be more involved in protecting the rights and persecution of so-called sexual minorities than in protecting Christians.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it is a very sad reality for the 21st century that in 2017 we have to say that 215 million Christians are being persecuted. Who can mind a religion that proclaims love, mercy, the right to freedom of religion and the right to a dignified life. And that is why Christians are so persecuted today. In some countries, such as Egypt, Pakistan, India, Saudi Arabia, Christians are threatened with violence and oppression to demonstrate the strength of other religious groups, especially radical Muslims. In China or Vietnam, Christians are oppressed by totalitarian systems, especially in North Korea, which is the thirteenth country with the most persecuted Christians. It is important for the European Parliament to stand up for those wrongfully prosecuted, and I am pleased that some are eventually released, such as Petr Jašek or Miriam Ibrahim from a Sudanese prison. But we must not forget Asia Bibi, who was mentioned here, who has been in prison for more than 3,000 days. Pope Francis, who is a true Christian authority today, calls for reconciliation and solidarity with all. Christians are bearers of peace and reconciliation. That is why we here in the European Parliament have a duty to demand freedom for Christians where they suffer, we have a duty to ask for support where they want to rebuild their homes and live peacefully. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr Chairman!It has been rightly emphasized here many times that Christians are the most persecuted religion among all people persecuted for religious reasons.The honorable Member also mentioned the countries where such persecution takes place.In this connection, I would have a question: Could you also make some suggestions: what could we do, what actions to take to prevent, to limit this type of action, so that we would support Christians around the world, so that they would not be subjected to this type of ruthless discriminatory action?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Of course, it is one thing to clearly express our solidarity with all the persecuted, unjustly persecuted Christians, to declare that Europe was and is a Christian, but we need to do something concrete, whether it is through diplomacy when we deal withChina, for example, when we declare the EU-China European Year of Tourism.Then we should also demand freedom for imprisoned Christians or support financially, in the context of development programs in the Middle East, reconstruction after the horrors of war.Of course, we should also think about supporting Christians who are renovating their homes here, as has already been said here.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Mister President! Persecution of Christians: Nine Christians were shot dead four days ago during a Mass in Nigeria. In early November, a gunman attacked a church service in Texas, killing 26 people, including many children. On Saturday, China expelled hundreds of Christians from the country. At the end of October, vandals broke into the Martinikirche in Bremen and devastated it. This is just a small, current selection. The new World Persecution Index from Open Doors lists over 200 million severely persecuted Christians, in 50 mostly Islamic countries. We must not be silent about this. I thank Ján Figeľ for his work as the EU Commissioner for Religious Freedom. I would also like to thank Katharina von Schnurbein for her commitment. I would also like the Jamaica coalition in Berlin to create a government commissioner for religious freedom. I would like all EU countries to do that. I want us to tackle and not watch any longer. Discrimination on the grounds of belief is a daily tragedy that we Europeans cannot accept - not in Europe, not in the world. Let's use our power to stop this!

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: - The situation of Christians is quite specific, because Christians are not only believers, but are part of the churches. Christians are the Church, therefore the persecution of Christians is de facto persecution of the Churches. I think it is very important. Therefore, if we are to be serious about it, we need to support organizations that support Churches, such as the Church in Need. These are organizations that do a lot about this. But the churches have a huge role to play. I would not like to repeat arguments regarding the freedom of religion, religious freedom. But if it does not appeal to someone, if it does not fully understand the specificity and origin of European values, then strictly political arguments should appeal to someone. Christians, especially in the Middle East, guaranteed a certain stability through their contribution to education and health care. In fact, they have been a buffer between the opposing parties for many years. If the European Union and our external services are indifferent to this fact, the conflict in the Middle East cannot be stopped if the presence of Christians is not guaranteed. Because they are a basic element from the very beginning. This is a political argument that is undoubtedly related to the role of the churches in political life and social life.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the persecution of Christians around the world has turned red even on the European continent itself. The last disgusting and condemnable phenomenon is the persecution of Greek Christians of the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus. Where the Albanian authorities demolish churches, such as the church of Agios Athanasios in Drymades. They arbitrarily and illegally demolish the houses of the Greeks in Chimarra, with the aim of uprooting the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus from its ancestral homes and the demographic change of the population with the transfer and settlement there of thousands of other Kosovar Muslims and. What measures will you take, Mr. Vella, to protect the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus, which is now experiencing a violent violation of its religious rights every day? When will the Albanian leadership finally respect the rights of the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus and the Corfu Protocol of 1914 for the autonomy of the Northern Epirus? The persecution of Greek Christians from Albania is coming. In addition, Turkey must be forced to respect the rights of Christians in Turkey, stop desecrating Hagia Sophia, end the ban on the operation of the Halki School and, at the same time, stop dismantling Greek churches in occupied Cyprus.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, a Christian genocide is being waged across the Middle East by the followers of Islam. Every year since 2005, 90 000 Christians have been eliminated from this planet. The names of their attackers are well known: Al-Qaeda, ISIS, the Muslim Brotherhood. But whilst Christians are being burned across the world, the world’s atheistic elites wring their hands and turn away. They would rather discuss issues of migrants across the globe, or what President Trump is doing, rather than concern themselves about the murder, rape, torture of Christians across the Middle East. Just as the Islamic terrorists removed Jews from 1948 to 1970, with 850 000 removed from the Middle East, we have now seen a reduction of 1.5 million to 275 000 Christians in Iraq. If the elites do not do anything to protect our Christian communities then it is time for Christians themselves to rise up, come together once more and fight the Islamic terrorists who are trying to destroy them.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Mr President, there is no doubt that Christianity, both historically and historically, has been persecuted and, indeed, genocidal. But it is inconceivable and unacceptable that such genocides exist today, as is the case in the Middle East. I convey to you what we Greeks in Cyprus have been experiencing for 43 years. We are experiencing another kind of persecution and destruction of every Christian element by the barbaric Turkey invading Cyprus, for 43 years, which leveled every church, every Christian monument and expelled 200,000 Greek Christians. A Turkey that has a burdensome past and a criminal record regarding the genocides against Christians, since it has the sole responsibility for the genocides of the Pontians, the Armenians, the Greeks of Constantinople, Ionia and Aeolia. A Turkey that today receives funding and support from the European Union itself. If we really want to send a strong message to all those who directly or indirectly persecute Christians and commit genocides, the European Union must have no cooperation and no funding for countries that still do not respect Christian culture. they respect Christian monuments and they do not respect the Christian faith. This must start first with a member state of the European Union, Cyprus, which is experiencing all these really frightening consequences of the persecution by Turkey.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years the condition of Christians in the world has worsened in many areas of the world. Discrimination and violence are recorded in Pakistan, North Korea, India, Turkey, Sudan, and in some cases the violence becomes an attempt to destroy the presence of an entire community. The words of Pope Francis resound in this Hall: we see so many of our Christian brothers and sisters in Eastern churches experiencing dramatic persecutions and an ever more disturbing diaspora. This raises many questions and many whys. Nobody can close their eyes, much less Europe. We cannot turn away as if such tragedies were inevitable. We cannot stop at the denunciation alone, it is necessary to find effective and lasting solutions that help the Christian community in the world to overcome this difficult moment. We must assume our responsibilities and break the veil of resignation to the persecutions that affect us all, as Europeans even before as citizens.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - I have listened with great attention to what Commissioner Vella said. Although I was hoping for a speech by Mrs Mogherini, very important words were said here. However, we omit the most important thing. We are talking about Christians falling prey to some vague intolerance. We have even heard of the various political and economic contexts in which the persecution of Christians occurs. However, we did not talk about the most important thing - that Christians have been persecuted for 2,000 years, because the main source of this persecution is anti-Christian hatred, which so far refuses to condemn both the European Commission and this Parliament. After all, this week has been a hundred years since the bloody Bolshevik rule in Russia. According to Yakovlev's commission, 200,000 priests were murdered as a result of them, if the calculation is limited to the clergy only, 7,000 priests were murdered in Spain, and one third of priests were murdered in the Polish Gdańsk Pomerania during the German occupation. How much blood still has to flow for this simple conclusion to finally fall? The anti-Christian hatred must be condemned by the civilized world.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, anyone who knows a little about world history knows that minorities have always been oppressed wherever there has been no democracy and at the same time strong central government. Today this is happening to the detriment of Christian minorities. I have referred to the subject too many times and I will not repeat what I have said. But I will add something about Israel in relation to Bethlehem, a Christian -essentially- city in which more than 100,000 settlers have entered, which is essentially pushing Palestinian Christians to leave. I will, of course, also refer to Cyprus, dear Mr Vella, in addition to what has been said by my colleague, Mr Christoforou, who also comes from Cyprus. Please visit Famagusta, a European city, 4 hours drive from here by plane. Go see this ghost town that has been occupied for 43 years, with 200 churches in operation for 43 years. Why doesn't an MEP get up to go see this European city? In total, of course, all Christians have been expelled from the occupied areas of Cyprus and hundreds of churches have become yards for many decades.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the key to helping persecuted Christians around the world is religious freedom.Adherence to it must be an uncompromising condition for the European Union's good relations with any country in the world.But we must also take an uncompromising approach to religious freedom in the EU.According to the Pew Research Center, restrictions on religious freedom were strengthened in most European countries between 2007 and 2013.Pope Francis called them "polite persecution," which pretends to be modernity and progress, but deprives people of freedom and even the right to reservation in conscience.According to a report from a joint project of the University of Notre Dame, the Religious Freedom Institute and Georgetown University, the result is often job loss and other sanctions that prevent Christians from living in accordance with their religious beliefs.I am not surprised that the protection of Christians in the world has such reserves.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vella, the fact that Christians are being persecuted is a reality and a modern phenomenon that we all experience. The question, however, is whether what we say publicly here is the same as what we say privately. I confess to you, as an MEP for 3.5 years, that unfortunately there is a lot of hypocrisy; some we say in public and others we say behind closed doors. The example of Cyprus has already been mentioned by my colleagues, and we belong to different political groups, from the EPP to the GUE. The great hypocrisy, then, starts with the European Union. There is a Member State of the European Union where the vast majority - the Christian people - have been wiped out. He is not even allowed to visit his homes and properties in the Turkish-occupied part of Cyprus, and the best living example is in front of you. The underling was born in the province of Kyrenia and lived through the invasion of ’74. But I am here and I will close by saying this; that I will never accept this hypocrisy in the name of political correctness. Christians have the same rights as any other human being, especially within the European Union.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the main and timeless enemy of Christianity is Islam. Islamic extremism along with the rivalry of many other religions, communist or post-communist oppression, secular intolerance and intolerance are opponents of the existence and continuity of the Christian faith. Finally, tensions and stigma are being transferred within European countries. However, recorded incidents are being silenced, such as the murder of twelve Christians by Muslim illegal immigrants, where - according to the Italian police - the motive of the crime was religious hatred. The mainstream television media and the yellow press propagandize in favor of multiculturalism and unlimited tolerance, while not covering the mass and systematic persecution experienced by so many Christians. The supposed Christian Europe receives multifaceted threats, mainly from internal enemies, from political choices with a selective invocation of fundamental rights, from judicial decisions in the name of secularism, and, above all, from cold demographic and cultural data. The Christian religion is under persecution, as it was during the Roman and Ottoman empires. Soon, however, Christians will raise our Christian stature to confess and defend our faith.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we have already said that reports from independent institutions show that Christians are the most persecuted group on the planet.However, these reports also show trends and these trends are constantly deteriorating.The EU should therefore call this persecution by its real name.It is a genocide, we have heard the numbers here several times.And genocide is a crime of crimes.From the Christian-Jewish roots follows the very foundation of our Western civilization, respect for the individual.This is also the basis of the system of protection of fundamental rights.Protecting human dignity is what makes our civilization different from other parts of the world.It is therefore in the interest of all of us that the defense of Christianity in the world become a priority of the European Union's foreign policy, otherwise we are undermining the foundations of our civilization.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today we can say that certainly we are sensitive to all forms of discrimination against all forms of religion practiced, but there is no doubt that what is happening today in the world, in particular in Africa, in Asia and in the Middle East, against Christians it is a real form of persecution, which is often more underestimated than others. I believe we all know what the data are and we also know that many Christians, religious or lay, have suffered real forms of crime against humanity. I think of the fact that there are three particular situations. On the one hand, that of Islamic extremism, which in some countries such as Iraq and Syria, where Isis had genocidal intent, aimed at the complete elimination of any Christian presence. In Aleppo, Christians today are 75% less than in 2011. There are also other places, such as Egypt bloodied by the attacks, Nigeria by the violence of Boko Haram, Pakistan, where the case of Asia Bibi is only the tip of the iceberg, and also, unfortunately, we also have big issues in Turkey. Then there is another face of hostility against Christians and it is that of religious nationalism. So I also think, sometimes, of India, where attacks on Christian churches are constantly growing. I believe that Europe must support associations, humanitarian organizations and international bodies in a clearer and more evident way, because even in the return that today, after the ISIS crisis, to their countries in the Middle East, the Christians can do it in safe conditions.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, non-governmental organizations in their reports on the persecution of Christians from year to year conclude that this year is the most terrible so far when it comes to the persecution of Christians. The number of countries where Christians are persecuted is increasing year by year. 108 countries in 2014, 20 more in 2015. In 2016, there were 1329 attacks on churches in 62 states. More than 200 million Christians in the 50 countries in the world where it is most difficult to be a Christian are subject to persecution because of their faith. Some estimates speak of as many as 600 million persecuted Christians. And we here in Parliament often talk about the persecution of Christians, but action is unfortunately lacking. Hungary has established a State Secretariat for direct assistance to persecuted Christians, and I hereby call on the other Member States to directly assist Christians in need. I also call on the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, to strengthen the role and mandate of the Special Envoy for the Promotion of Freedom of Religion or Belief outside the European Union so that it becomes a central part of the European Union's foreign policy system.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this is a very important debate, and colleagues have outlined the extent of the persecution of Christians in the world. Frankly, when I talk to people about this, they don’t believe it. I think that there is a lack of awareness generally about how widespread this problem is and how serious it is. Over 215 million Christians are persecuted globally. I think the person we should give great support to in his work is Ján Figeľ, the EU Special Envoy for the promotion of freedom of religion and belief. He does incredible work and he is tireless in pursuit of this ideal where we all have freedom of religion and belief, and I believe he needs more support, both within the Commission and indeed from this House, because if we don’t tackle this type of abuse and persecution and if we allow it to increase, as is happening, then I’m really concerned about the future for Christianity and for people of all faiths.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange, and I would like to thank all the honourable Members who took part in this debate for their interventions. I think I can say that from this debate it is very clear that we all share a common interest in keeping freedom of religion or belief at the very top of the European Union’s agenda. As the HR/VP, Federica Mogherini, stated in a debate in this same chamber on 16 May, freedom of religion or belief is a fundamental right, and we will continue to look at how best to use all the instruments available to us in humanitarian relief, stabilisation and development assistance, political dialogue, and in specific support to freedom of religion or belief to everyone everywhere. So allow me to close by signalling once again my appreciation and that of the HR/VP, Federica Mogherini, of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - The eradication of Christianity from the lands where it was born is reflected in the numbers, since from 20% at the beginning of the last century, Christian communities represent only 2 to 3% of the population of the Middle East. This "confessional cleansing" is by the way far from over: despite the imminent end of military hostilities, many Christian families will never return to their places of origin. But if, according to the "Aid to the Church in Need" foundation, the Christian religion is the most persecuted in the world, it is because part of this drama is playing out in the West. The martyrdom of the Christians of the East cannot in fact obscure the trials experienced by the Christians of Europe in the practice of their faith. In addition to systematic denigration, they indeed face attacks on their places of worship. According to the French interior ministry, around 80% of desecration would target Christian buildings, an increase of more than 200% between 2008 and 2014. If Europe must therefore lend a hand to Christians persecuted in the world by a conquering Islam , it must also guarantee to the Christians of Europe a true freedom of worship and conviction.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. - Today's persecutions of Christians are a tragedy, the proportions of which are unfortunately on the rise and to which the media - sometimes for unforgivable distraction, but much more for senseless prejudice - do not recognize the visibility they deserve. This Europe which claims to be pluralist and sensitive to the issue of human rights, fails to stem a phenomenon that we see spreading in Africa (as in Nigeria devastated by Boko Haram), in Asia and in the countries of the Middle East, where Christianity had a presence indisputable historical. The main culprit of the persecution remains Islamic extremism, not only that carried by ISIS fanatics, but also that spread by the courts that strictly apply the sharia law and impose sentences for crimes such as "apostasy" and "blasphemy". This extremism is growing in once secular countries such as Turkey and in the European metropolis itself there is a growing intolerance of non-Christian communities, as the news often records. The brutality of these acts of violence against communities of millenary belonging to the faith in Christ is unprecedented in the modern era, apart from the Holocaust of the Vendeans. The EU is too concerned about its economic interests to denounce this terrifying reality.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Finally a debate on the persecution of Christians in this Parliament, it seems that often everything is done not to discuss this very serious situation. The numbers are staggering: we are talking about 215 million persecuted, most of them forced to flee their countries of origin. This is not a phenomenon limited to a particular area, but rather a phenomenon that is assuming global proportions: persecutions are recorded from North Korea to the African continent, to the Middle East. The Commissioner summed up the efforts of the External Action Service and the Commission to combat the situation well, but I believe that more determination is needed. It is important to keep attention and not to silence the drama of persecution. I hope that our debate will serve this purpose and to remind once again that freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we must not be afraid to remember it in every possible form.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I have had the opportunity to express myself on various occasions on the fate of Eastern Christians, especially in Syria and Iraq, where I visited.In the Nineveh Plain, Christians have lost everything, and recent fighting against ISIS has further displaced Christian populations.In these countries, humanitarian aid is needed more than ever.In the rest of the world, as in China, India or Pakistan, the situation of Christians remains worrying.In Bhutan, conversion to Christianity is often synonymous with persecution.In Mauritania, repentance will now, according to the government, be ineffective in avoiding death sentences for blasphemy or apostasy, which is very bad news for Christians.Also, the countries of Europe must rise to the occasion and help those who are, as we speak, 150-200 million to be worried because of their faith.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. “Four out of five Christians persecuted for their faith are the current shocking statistics in the world. Christian Europe has a responsibility and a duty to stand up for Christians in the Middle East who are persecuted for their faith. The question is just “how”. The leaders of Christians in the Middle East themselves emphasize that the solution lies not in inviting them to Europe, as these people were born there and want to live there in their homeland. So it’s key to get help there, thereby promoting staying in place. Because of the persecution of Christians, thousands of families have become runaways. In addition to food supplies, school-age children and families urgently need education and job opportunities. If European governments take action in the field of education assistance in the short term, it could be a turning point for tens of thousands of young people to survive in the land of their ancestors and maintain a 2,000-year-old presence of Christianity in the region. The Hungarian government contributes to this in Erbil, where a Christian school is being built with the financial contribution of the Hungarian government and the Catholic Church. With such and similar initiatives, we can really help persecuted Christians.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. - "Nobody can close their eyes": Pope Francis' warning regarding the persecution of Christians of the Eastern Churches is current, now more than ever. Christians in the world suffer like never before: the report "Persecuted and Forgotten", recently presented by the association "Aid to the Church in Need", took a picture of the violence in the three-year period 2015-2017, examining 13 countries: China, India , Iraq, Pakistan, Syria, Sudan, Turkey, Egypt, Eritrea, Iran, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and North Korea. At the same time, the "Open Doors" association denounced that in 50 countries 200 million faithful are persecuted: the courageous faith of Eastern Christians cost them physical violence, as in India, 410 cases in 2017; forced labor, as in North Korea and China for North Korean Christian refugees, sent back to their country, where they are then sentenced to die in labor camps; confiscations like in Turkey. In some cases, the violence even becomes an attempt to destroy the presence of an entire community. We cannot close our eyes: international cooperation is needed to provide a concrete, clear and coordinated response against the extremism that spreads around the world and forces millions of people to renounce their beliefs, and to be denied fundamental rights.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: signed up. - I followed with great interest the intervention of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs regarding the persecution of Christians in some parts of the world. I fully agree that these persecuted communities must be supported. However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, in most cases, the persecution of a minority is also linked to the situation of that group in its country or area of ​​origin. And if it can be said that Europe was the continent of Christianity, we can ask ourselves how worthy Christianity is in Europe today. Of course, Europe long ago separated the state church. We are accustomed to give to Caesar what is Caesar's. But do we give to God what is God's? What we see every day is that we Europeans are the first to indirectly persecute Christianity. In the press, on the street and even in institutions, Christian values ​​are considered reactionary, outdated, outdated. If we ourselves treat Christianity this way, why would others treat it with more respect? Let's learn to respect Christianity and Christians here in Europe! After that we will have the moral authority to defend him all over the world!

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Alain Cadec, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, and by Adina-Ioana Vălean, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the protection of coastal marine habitats - the seagrass casePosidonia oceanica (O-000076/2017 - B8-0605 / 2017) (2017/2903 (RSP)).

name: Gabriel Mato
text: Author. - Mr President, dear Commissioner, I am taking the place of the chairman of the Fisheries Commission, my colleague Alain Cadec, and I will also add my speech to the speech I had scheduled; with which, with the permission of the presidency, I will add the two times, up to a maximum of five minutes that I will not comply with. At the same time that the possibility of presenting this oral question was raised at the meeting of coordinators of the Fisheries Commission, the answer was immediate and unanimous in the affirmative. And do you know why? Because the fishing sector is always the first interested in maintaining optimal environmental conditions, and the defense of posidonia is a common element of all political groups in the Fisheries Commission. As is known, the Posidonia oceanica is an endemic plant of the Mediterranean, one of the most productive and resistant species in the biosphere, capable of forming underwater meadows of great ecological importance, within which many animal and plant organisms live that are found in it. food and protection. As if that were not enough, it is also an excellent bioindicator of the quality of coastal marine waters. Today doubts are raised about the conservation of these habitats; however, there are times when fishermen are always blamed, and it is not fair that the fishing industry is accused of causing a negative impact on the environment. There are many other elements, such as dredging practices, coastal development, eutrophication and climate change - among others - that have submerged this lung of the Mediterranean in a serious process of regression in recent years, making the posidonia, of slow growth and difficult regeneration, in one of the most threatened marine grasses at the moment. Given the importance of this fact, we ask the Commission to explain to us if it has envisaged any additional measures that could be adopted, not only to protect the populations of Posidonia oceanica, but also to reestablish their populations. In this sense, there are actions undertaken by some Member States - among them Spain, with six Mediterranean marine reserves with grasslands of this species - that have taken concrete measures to curb the impact of human actions and guarantee the conservation and preservation of the marine ecosystem . Within the routines of marine reserve services, the recognition of the state of health of these meadows stands out, and in particular their flowering and fruiting, whose higher interannual frequency and longer seasonal duration seem to be related to global change. Also specific collaboration in projects such as Posimed, in collaboration with different ecology institutes, or the prohibition of diving in integral reserves, or the development of specific content on the values ​​of this species that forms underwater forests of fishing interest. Also the incorporation of content on the need to protect marine habitats, with grasslands being a preferred habitat in national legislation on fisheries and biodiversity. And, finally, the incorporation of content on this species in the educational strategy of marine reserve networks, school campaigns and school outreach, because we cannot forget that environmental education and awareness are essential if we want to stop the deterioration of the Posidonia oceanica and also protect coastal marine habitats. In this regard, and to avoid the enormous pressure to which these essential habitats are subjected for the conversion of carbon dioxide into oxygen, the productivity of marine resources and the protection of the coasts, this House would like to know first hand what data is available to the Commission, as well as its assessment of the investments that have been made through its programs. I announce that, in this sense, I want to celebrate that the level of protection of the Habitats Directive, instrument for the protection of Posidonia meadows.Marine habitats provide great ecological services for humanity and, in this context, posidonia is an important part for the maintenance of this biodiversity.I am aware of this importance, but it is not enough to be aware.What is needed at the level of the European Union is the promotion of similar actions in other Member States, as I said happens in Spain.It is the task of the Commission to coordinate these actions across Europe.And finally, when we talk about the Mediterranean, it is also important that neighboring third countries participate in a joint effort.No matter how many efforts are made in one part of the Mediterranean, no result can be achieved if inaction is the tone of the other part.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu
text: author. - Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, concerned about the loss of biodiversity and the degradation of ecosystem services, the European Union adopted in 2011 the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which commits the community to halting the loss of diversity by 2020. , many marine species are facing a decline in population and a decrease in range and habitat, which brings to the attention of the European Union the need to supplement measures and actions in the field of protection of the marine environment. This is because marine protected areas are the ecological foundation of the blue economy, as stated in the Commission's report of 1 October 2015 on the progress made in creating marine protected areas. This question concerns a species of grass, Posidonia Oceanica, which is not only one of the most sustainable and productive species in the biosphere, but also, according to researchers at the University of the Algarve in Portugal and the French Institute for Sea Exploration, the oldest living organism in the world, over two hundred thousand years old, with a positive impact on biodiversity conservation. But Posidonia Oceanica is one of the most endangered species of seagrass because it grows at a very slow pace and needs a long time to recover from destruction. Obviously, the new measures for the protection and regeneration of Posidonia Oceanica must be the result of data and information on the evolution of coastal marine habitats, as well as the evaluation of programs and actions already undertaken by the European Union, directly or indirectly, in terms of investment and the impact on the protection of coastal marine habitats and the conservation of biodiversity. The Commission must promote research activities at European level with regard to protection of coastal marine habitats, environmental education and governance structures conducive to the inclusion of marine protected areas.The Commission must also support Member States through the European Union's financial mechanisms for the conservation and sustainable use of coastal marine biodiversity.Thank you.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, the Commission attaches very high importance to the conservation of Posidonia oceanica meadows, also known as Neptune grass or Posidonia beds. This is an essential habitat as a nursery and refuge for commercial and non—commercial species alike, and it provides a major source of food, regulates nutrient cycles and prevents coastal erosion. Impressively, Posidonia oceanica meadows alone bury some two 2 000 tonnes of carbon each year; it would be interesting to know how this phenomenal seaweed compares with our carbon emissions saving targets or the shift to electric vehicles.  Posidonia beds are a priority habitat type under the Habitats Directive, and Member States have designated around 30% as Natura 2000 sites to protect them. Other measures, such as national protection measures and environmental targets, are set under the Marine Strategy and Water Framework Directives. In addition, the Common Fisheries Policy prohibits the use of certain fishing gear – like trawl nets – above Posidonia seagrass beds and offers Member States special fishing management tools to be used in protected areas or essential habitats. Despite these efforts, in 2013, the status of Posidonia beds was considered unfavourable in four of the seven Member States where this habitat type occurs. And while information on trends is scarce, research studies point to regression rates in the order of 10% over the past 50 years, with losses mostly observed in the western and northern Mediterranean. The Commission expects further information to be provided by Member States in 2018, when they will report on their efforts to achieve good environmental status in marine waters. The decline in the population of Neptune grass is usually linked to coastal development, mechanical damage from illegal trawling, anchoring, beach nourishment, dredging, eutrophication and other forms of pollution. To restore Posidonia beds, Member States must establish site-level conservation objectives and restoration measures. New protected areas are also often designated. Compliance is currently being monitored by the Commission. The Commission is supporting the conservation of Posidonia beds through the dissemination of good management practices, the co-funding of LIFE projects, and financial support under the European Regional Development Fund, INTERREG Mediterranean and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The good news is that investments through LIFE have played a crucial role in ensuring the effective management and restoration of coastal ecosystems. The programme has funded more than 20 projects since 1992, focusing specifically on tackling Mediterranean seagrass habitat degradation through protection and even restoration. Other cross-cutting coastal LIFE projects have also contributed to the improved knowledge and management of Posidonia beds. The mid-term evaluation of the LIFE programme, adopted on 6 November, details the careful monitoring of investments via outcome indicators and targets. The EMFF also provides financial support for the protection and restoration of marine biodiversity and ecosystems, which includes a common monitoring and evaluation system. The Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, will undertake a review of the performance of the operational programmes, the performance review, in each Member State in 2019. Given its phenomenal ability to absorb inconceivable volumes of carbon from the air, the returns on investing in further conservation delivers an extraordinary public good and a real contribution to shifting to the low-carbon economy. This is a prime example of both why and how we must continue to secure sufficient funding in the future.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, COP 23 dedicated the 11th of November to the oceans and, therefore, I understand that the debate on the protection of coastal marine habitats is not only opportune, but also extremely necessary. When we talk about protecting these habitats that are essential for converting carbon dioxide into oxygen, we have to talk about marine meadows that are vital ecosystems in terms of biodiversity and that provide numerous relevant services for communities and the economy. The oral question is part of the defense of the marine herb posidonia oceanica, an endemic species of the Mediterranean and one of the most productive and most important for the maintenance of biodiversity. However, this important species of slow growth and regeneration has been decreasing drastically in recent decades due to human activity, eutrophication and other forms of pollution, as well as in the wake of climate change and damage caused by the anchoring of vessels. At the Our Ocean conference it was estimated that the total annual value of natural assets in the Mediterranean will be 4.66 billion euros, which represents about 20% of the annual global GDP. However, a strong and sustainable blue economy depends on the preservation of marine and coastal ecosystems and our ability to restore them. For all these reasons, Commissioner, I believe it is essential to address you on the following issues: what is the current situation and the future evolution of marine coastal habitats, particularly with regard to the monitoring indicators of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive associated with biodiversity and integration of the seabed? How does the Commission assess the investments already made through the various research and conservation programs in the context of defending oceanic posidonia and what programs and funding does the Commission intend to put in place to protect and recover oceanic posidonia in order to increase its resilience and minimize the impact of climate change on this species?Commissioner, we urgently need robust measures if we are to have a sustainable future for the Mediterranean and, therefore, I believe that the answer to these questions is fundamental to devising a coherent strategy for the defense of the Mediterranean ecosystem.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Commissioner, as has been said here, coastal marine habitats are fundamental for the conversion of carbon dioxide to oxygen, for the productivity of marine resources, the protection of coastal areas and other essential ecological services that they provide to the planet. Coastal marine habitats are those that are most threatened by human action, either because of their proximity, or because these are the first places to receive the influence of activities carried out on land. The European Union, it is recognized, has invested significantly in financing scientific studies and programs for the conservation and restoration of the marine environment. However, in a recent article in the journal Nature, in 2015, it is estimated that, in the last 50 years, there has been a 34% reduction in the oceanic posidonia meadows in the Mediterranean. The case of posidonia oceanica is just one example of how the disturbance of the marine environment can have significant impacts for an entire ecosystem, so the monitoring and evolution of key species, such as this seagrass, is of crucial importance. Monitoring the evolution of the conservation status of species — keys to conservation, the impact of investments made in the conservation and restoration of marine habitats and the improvement of their protection are essential for the protection of the marine environment to be effective and continuous. Knowing and publicizing the results and improvements obtained with conservation and recovery investments to all European citizens and, in particular, raising awareness of the importance of these investments is essential for the work carried out to be even more positive in protecting habitats and marine species. Climate change, which was also mentioned here, is a reality, we all feel the impact of these changes on a daily basis, so the protection and recovery of species such as oceanic posidonia, which exercise actions important in coastal protection and other ecological services, are essential.Protection and restoration of habitats and species are actions that cannot be separated from commitments to reduce carbon emissions with a view to overcoming climate change.The European Union, it is recognized, has been at the forefront and committed to combating climate change.But it is necessary to bear in mind that the knowledge, protection and recovery of marine habitats, in particular coastal habitats, are an important point in combating these changes.I conclude by reinforcing the need to improve knowledge and monitoring of oceanic posidonia, but also of other key species crucial to the conservation and preservation of marine habitats, which so many fundamental ecological services provide to the planet.

name: João Ferreira
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, coastal marine habitats and the species of fauna and flora that occur in them have a high ecological and conservation value. The populations of oceanic posidonia in the Mediterranean, as in general the banks with vascular provision in shallow waters, as is the case also of zostera, for example, whether in the Mediterranean region or in the Atlantic region, are important havens of biodiversity, are important in the carbon sequestration, are important in the regulation of nutrient cycles, in the elimination and recycling of polluting residues, among other functions. The threats that affect these habitats are essentially associated with human action. Commissioner, it is important in this debate to discuss what actions and resources that can be mobilized from the European Union can contribute to the cause of conservation of these habitats. It should be noted that, despite the fact that these habitats are threatened and protected by Community legislation, there is still no specific European Union financial instrument aimed at managing the areas included in the Natura 2000 network, which compromises conservation objectives. , as well as the restoration of degraded habitats. It was important, Commissioner, for example, to start by filling this gap.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, as an elected representative from the South-East of France, I can only worry about the spectacular regression of Posidonia under the effect of several combined factors: dredging, trawling and coastal urbanization, among others. However, this plant offers unparalleled services on a global scale, transforming CO2 into oxygen or boosting the productivity of marine resources. We should therefore seriously question our relationship with the environment, when we know that this species dating back millions of years, which has withstood the worst cataclysms, is now threatened. If awareness raising is useful, we must ask the right questions instead of increasing investments, studies and various European programs. It should be remembered that the European Union enjoys exclusive competence in matters of fishing and the preservation of resources. Also, the Commission cannot say that it lacks prerogatives to preserve marine ecosystems.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, true lungs of the Mediterranean, Posidonia meadows transform carbon dioxide into oxygen and are therefore vital for the survival of all species. But, today, around 34% of seagrass beds are threatened by wastewater discharges, nitrogen discharges, invasive species such as Caulerpa taxifolia, by the extraction of sea sands or by the anchoring of ships. Faced with these threats, should we create new marine protected areas from which fishermen would be excluded, since it is they who are most often accused of the destruction of Posidonia? I believe that this solution is simplistic and inefficient because trawling cannot, in principle, harm Posidonia meadows. Why? Because trawling is prohibited within three miles of the coast in France and above a depth of fifty meters in Italy and Spain. However, the seagrass beds are precisely located less than three miles from the coast and less than fifty meters deep, that is to say outside the trawling zone. So, rather than trying to impose new constraints on fishermen, I recommend investing in wastewater reprocessing. This is, I believe, the most effective solution. For example, in the creeks of Cortiou, in Marseille, or of Cap Sissi, in Toulon, the herbaria were restored as soon as the treatment of wastewater was improved. Of course, this solution must be applied throughout the Mediterranean. In this regard, I would remind you that, from its creation in 2008, the Union for the Mediterranean designated the depollution of the sea as one of its primary objectives. This depollution therefore necessarily involves reducing the discharge of land-based pollutants into the sea. This is why, Commissioner, it would be interesting to know what progress has been made by the Union for the Mediterranean in this area. whose projects are funded by the EIB and by the EBRD?

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here with us tonight. This is a serious issue because the meadows of Posidonia oceanica are declining at an alarming rate due to climate change and other human activities. Although the seagrass is considered the most important and well—studied seagrass species of the Mediterranean Sea, to date there has been a limited effort to combine all the spatial information available to protect the meadows across the basin. Its full recovery is usually considered irreversible in a human timescale because it is a slow—growing species with a low recovery rate. The management of direct impacts such as trawling, anchoring, dredging, pipeline refilling can help recovery and promote resilience, although this can take an extremely long time. Transposition of the seagrass is often unsuccessful, largely due to the fact that habitats are still too deteriorated to allow planted seagrass to survive. So what can we do now? It is crucial to undertake specific actions to mitigate the threats causing the regression and promote good conservation practices before the seagrasses regress, thereby allowing these habitats to fulfil their key roles in coastal areas. I hope that this discussion will motivate the European Commission to take specific actions to promote this situation.

name: Renata Briano (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Posidonia oceanica is part of our biodiversity heritage. Among other things, it is not an alga, but it is a superior plant and is endemic to the Mediterranean Sea, where unfortunately its presence is decreasing more and more. Due to its particular sensitivity to environmental conditions it has been considered a real bioindicator. Posidonia, among other things, combines some characteristics of terrestrial plants with others typical of algae. Thanks to this peculiarity in the past it had a considerable commercial importance, just think that, not being flammable, its leaves were used as an insulator, for example on roofs, or to integrate certain animal feed, or to pack fragile objects, and was even called the glassmakers alga. So it has a great tradition in our Mediterranean culture too. Its uses were not limited to commercial purposes only and the leaves were also used to heal irritations and inflammations. Posidonia today is essential not only to protect the coasts from erosion, but also to preserve the health of the seas, helping to transform carbon dioxide into oxygen. It is inevitable that the effects of climate change on marine and coastal habitats also have negative consequences on human activities related to these environments, such as fishing, and certainly it is human activities that we must act on. The Commissioner has already given me some answers as well, I am thinking, for example, of the themes of coastal erosion, but also of the themes of large construction. I remember when I was in the Liguria Region, that I had to fight hard to avoid the construction of a marina that would have canceled the only Posidonia meadow that still blooms from Liguria. So, for these reasons, we have to work and I wanted to ask the Commissioner some questions, but let's say that with his introduction has already answered.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the area of ​​Posidonia oceanica has decreased in the last twenty years by 50% in the Mediterranean. The decrease in this plant is caused by dredging practices, pollution, bad anchoring practices or uncontrolled anchoring linked to mass tourism, among many other reasons. The malfunction, insufficiency or non-existence of wastewater treatment and pollution of the estuaries is something that sectors such as shellfish and inshore fishing are continually denouncing, a situation that I have repeatedly brought to the attention of the Commission. And, Commissioner, the answers often reflect passivity or the lack of forceful actions to reverse this situation, both in relation to deficiencies in water purification systems and in relation to pollution linked to mass tourism or different infrastructures in these areas. And I ask you, Commissioner: are you going to take it seriously this time? Are you going to protect the posidonia and the rest of the coastal marine habitats by attacking the contamination that destroys them at the root? And last question: what limits to blue growth to preserve these habitats?

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here to talk about saving our sea, about saving the Posidonia prairie, when it would be enough to prevent devastating energy infrastructures such as TAP to do so. That TAP that in recent days has militarized San Foca, in Puglia, in the south of Italy. That TAP which believes itself to be the owner of an entire territory, and which buys it with 55 million euros, is devastating an entire landscape, an economy and tourism and has uprooted a hundred olive trees. But we can go back to talking about the Posidonia prairie, how it is important for the protection of ecosystems and for artisanal fishing and how it is devastated by trawling. We can talk about how beautiful and important the LIFE funds are to recover Posidonia. But the real responsible for the disasters of our territories, the real responsible for the devastation of our seas are you who are unable to say no to the oil and gas lobbies, it is you who are not able to initiate a real transition to renewable energy . To the citizens of Melendugno, to the children of the NO TAP movement, who were forced to leave the garrison in San Basilio after eight months of struggles, I say not to stop, and with them we will not stop to instead stop the devastation of those who do it only for the mere profit.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, this is one of the few topics on which we all in this Parliament mostly agree and I am glad that it has come on the agenda. This is just one of the species we want to protect because it is obvious that human activity has caused problems with marine habitats, and Posidonia oceanica is particularly endangered. We have already heard that it is one of the endemic species of the Mediterranean Sea, and more than half of the oxygen we breathe comes from the sea. We can call them the lungs of the sea because they enrich the sea with oxygen. Coastal marine habitats are essential for the conversion of carbon dioxide to oxygen and for the productivity of marine resources. Posidonia oceanica is the best indicator of the overall quality of coastal waters because it is very sensitive to pollution and can only grow in clean, unpolluted waters. One square meter of the Posidonia meadow produces up to fourteen liters of oxygen per day. Many species of algae live and breed in it, but also animals, crustaceans, cephalopods, shellfish, sponges, etc. Meadows grow very slowly, as we have already heard, and are even slower to regenerate. These habitats are clearly under great pressure, either directly from humans or as a result of global climate change. They are especially endangered by fishing with a hut and dynamite, but also by anchoring and pollution and construction in the coastal area. Therefore, I believe that anchoring should be stopped by systematically building marinas, and wastewater should also be treated. I personally represent Croatia here, where most of the Adriatic Sea is located, and I am sure that by banning anchoring and better planning, this could be avoided. In any case, we know that the Commission is doing a lot. We heard that from Commissioner Vella. However, we expect the Commission to engage even more. You said yourself that only four out of seven countries are satisfied with the way these habitats are managed and therefore this is an opportunity to invite non-EU countries to get involved and get more involved in protecting the sea and protecting the future of our children.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, coastal marine habitats are essential for transforming carbon dioxide into oxygen, for the productivity of marine resources, for coastal conservation and for other fundamental ecological functions that these habitats perform for humans and others. species. However, these habitats are subjected to strong anthropogenic pressures, caused directly by humans or as a consequence of global climate change. Posidonia oceanica, an endemic aquatic plant of the Mediterranean Sea, is one of the most resistant and productive species in the biosphere, it is part of an important ecosystem for the conservation of biodiversity and has a fundamental role in the defense of the coasts as, acting as a shock absorber for motion wavy, hinders the erosive action of the coasts by the sea. Nonetheless, its population has declined dramatically over the past two decades due to dredging and trawling, coastal development, eutrophication and other forms of pollution, climate change and mechanical damage caused by anchoring boats. This species is characterized by a very slow growth and, if destroyed, it takes a long time to reconstitute itself. Its reconstitution must therefore be ensured by financing European conservation programs and by raising awareness in the other Mediterranean countries to follow the example of Italy, Spain and France, countries in which legislation already exists.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! One of the biggest problems for lakes and seas is the high levels of nitrogen and phosphate caused by humans. They lead to excessive algae growth, which primarily damages the sensitive Neptune grass. But of course the rise in sea temperature is also partly responsible. A large part of the world's seagrass fields has already been destroyed in the last few decades, which has massive effects on biodiversity. We must finally act now to preserve marine biodiversity. What can we do? The pollution of rivers and seas with nitrogen and phosphate must be drastically reduced through tougher legislation and better control mechanisms, because if the sea goes under, so will mankind. We can still protect the oceans and their inhabitants from the ignorance of humans, which unfortunately knows no borders. It only takes political will.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, indeed, Posidonia oceanica, as analyzed, is endemic to the Mediterranean Sea and is certainly an important ecosystem which contributes to the conservation of biodiversity. However, it takes a long time to develop, and it is very easily destroyed, mainly by infection, fishing, sliding nets and the development of coastal areas. Some time ago, Mr Vella, I had a question for you: how will the Maritime and Fisheries Fund compensate those who have suffered damage from the Saronic Gulf pollution? I have not yet received an answer, especially now that there is a danger for Posidonia oceanica in the area. Also, let me point out that on 28/05 I had questioned the fact that the investment of Elliniko violates directive 92/43 which highlights the Posidonia oceanica meadows as a priority habitat. You answered me on 16/08/16 that Greece must comply with this directive. I ask you, have you done any research since then? Is the file of the Hellenic Investment Investigation open as to whether it actually violates Directive 92/43 and thus posidonia Posidonia oceanica meadows? I would like an answer to these questions.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we agree with Parliament on the importance of coastal habitats and in particular the need to protect the Posidonia oceanica meadows. We are concerned as much as you are about the unfavourable status and deteriorating trends reported in some of these habitats, and we acknowledge Member States’ efforts as well as research work during the last decades to increase knowledge on the status of such coastal habitats. I would like to make some comments. First of all, I agree that fishing is not the only factor affecting the state of the species of Posidonia, which is highly under threat. Mr Mato mentioned restoration. Yes, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) is offering the Member States financial support not only to protect, but also to restore the marine biodiversity and ecosystems, including the Posidonia meadows. What Mr Mato mentioned about what Spain is doing and about what other Member States are doing, they are doing this with the help and support of EMFF.  Protecting marine biodiversity is very much part of a number of actions on ocean governance. We have a number of tools at our disposal including the CFP, Maritime Spatial Planning, the integrated maritime policy, action against the negative impacts of climate change, and all these actions support our efforts to protect the species.  Mr Faria mentioned COP23. Yes, I was in Bonn last week and I was thoroughly pushing, together with my colleagues, the concept that you cannot separate the oceans from climate change – they are both inseparable and they are either mutually constructive or mutually destructive. The benefits that we are getting from the oceans are very clear. The oceans absorb some 90% of the planet’s heat, they absorb some 30% of the planet’s carbon dioxide, they give us some 50% of the planet’s oxygen and they will have to take all the melted ice when it becomes water. The oceans are climate change, as I said. This is something that we are pushing: you cannot discuss climate change without including the oceans in the discussions or in the negotiations. My colleague Ricardo Serrão Santos mentioned the support for protection; yes, they are protected not just through funding from some of our funding schemes but also through legislation and directives, especially through the Habitats Directive. We talked about funding; I already mentioned the EMFF, LIFE, the European Regional Development Fund, and these are all contributing towards the protection of the species. I mentioned as well that LIFE on its own funded 20 projects to specifically protect and restore sea grass meadows. We are also working a lot on the detailing and the monitoring of the investments. What counts is not the amount of money we are putting in; what counts is the output. That is why we are working on the output indicators and on the output targets as well.  I agree with Mr Ferreira when he said that the sea grass meadows have huge value as biodiversity habitat. Unfortunately we keep on repeating, and rightly so, that they are under threat, like all the other species in the ocean, like all the other species especially in the Mediterranean. Mireille D’Ornano mentioned a number of factors affecting these species. This is one example of a species which is giving us a lot of benefit, and what are we giving in return? I mentioned some of the benefits that we are getting from the oceans and in return we are only giving back over-fishing, pollution, eutrophication and all the negative impacts of climate change as well. Mr Goddyn: yes, there are problems not only in trawling zones, and that is why I started by mentioning that the problem is not only the fishermen. I am saying ‘is not only’ because bad practices in fishing could account for and could contribute to the denigration of these matters. We have eutrophication, we have acidification. Just to give you an idea, the acidification in our oceans has increased by 20 % since the Industrial Revolution. When we talk about de-oxygenation, we have today in our oceans four times as many dead zones – without any life, without any oxygen – as we had in 1960. Things are becoming very urgent in all the oceans, but in some areas more than others. Unfortunately, I myself come from the Mediterranean and my heart aches that the Mediterranean – we always say we are different, yes, we are different, but for me the idea of difference should be being different in a positive way, not being different in the sense that we are worse than the other regions. Mr Wałęsa, I agree about the resilience of nature too, because it is very resilient, but nature has to be given a chance. Renata Briano also spoke about the endemic nature and importance of this species to the Mediterranean Sea. We talk about the importance that this species has in the Mediterranean Sea, but unfortunately it is also affected by global threats as well, such as climate change, acidification, temperature increase, eutrophication and so on. I want to mention also what Maria Rodríguez said, because in the Mediterranean this year we came up with the MedFish4Ever declaration where we had all the countries of the Mediterranean for the very first time, all of them signing a declaration, and the declaration refers to the importance and the urgency of protecting not just the fishing species but also paid special attention to the Mediterranean’s biodiversity where Posidonia is included. It is a first step in the Mediterranean because commitment alone is not enough; signing and committing is important, but the most important thing is when it comes to delivery. We have to make certain that what the Mediterranean countries have committed to, they implement. Rosa D’Amato rightly mentioned the negative economic aspects if we are not looking after our seas from a biodiversity aspect as well. Rosa also mentioned renewable energy and this is also something which I have been pulling and pushing for quite some time, because the oceans can be one of our best allies when it comes to renewable energy. When we talk about renewable energy, very often we only think about solar and wind, but we have to start looking, and I have to say with pleasure that Europe is also already looking, at alternative energy coming from the oceans, tides, waves, currents so on and so forth. Human actions were mentioned by Ms Dubravka Şuica and I agree that we are testing our oceans and seas beyond their limits. When we talk about human actions, we should also include factors like climate change because after all climate change is also the result of human actions. Mr Caputo again mentioned that these are resistant species, but they too have their limits, and we have to look not just at the individual effects of all the threats that we have been mentioning, but we have to look at the accumulated effect of all the threats, when you have climate change working along with eutrophication, working along with acidification, working along with overfishing and illegal fishing and so on.  Mr Eck – and I will stop here – mentioned the importance of acting now, and for me this is a priority, because acting and acting together is not enough unless we are going to start acting now. I believe that there is a lot of awareness out there, but unfortunately the urgency is not there. Why am I talking about the urgency? Because I believe that things are moving much faster than we thought.  If I give you an example of the Great Barrier Reef, only 20 years ago scientists were putting the first questions about whether the Great Barrier Reef would take on the effects of climate. It was just a question, and later on they said that by 2050 the reefs would be feeling and having the negative effects of climate change. That was supposed to happen in 2050. Today, we are already seeing that half of the Great Barrier Reef is already dead, 30 years before 2050. We have to act, but we also have to act faster. I also agree with Mr Marias, because this is a species that takes a very long time to grow but you can destroy it in a few moments. With regard to the questions that were raised by Mr Marias, I have taken this on board and I believe that we have sent the information needed. If not, I will check again with my colleagues and make certain that you get the information because I remember that you raised it here.
