name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: written. - The «Posidonia oceanica» meadows are the most important Mediterranean forest by extension, CO2 fixation functions, great biodiversity, housing more than 400 species of fingerlings, most of them fishable or due to their great oxygenation capacity. The great problem with this forest of aquatic plants of such high ecological value is that it is not visible and its positive effects on the coast are only appreciated when they disappear. The population of rivereña continues to increase, negatively impacting this grassland so important for the maintenance of the good state of our sea. But, nevertheless, this growth and development is not accompanied by protective measures. The simple act of anchoring any pleasure craft, increasingly frequent, irreversibly destroys a portion of up to one square meter of posidonia surface, which will take 100 years to cover, a growth speed impossible to compete with the use that humans make. of the coast. The measures to be promoted by the Commission, such as ecological funding that make recreational use compatible with the preservation of biodiversity, should be included in the review of environmental and land use regulations in the Mediterranean coastal strip.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Iratxe García Pérez, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the use of cohesion policy instruments by regions in response to demographic change (2016/2245 (INI)) (A8-0329 / 2017).

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: speaker. - Mr President, Commissioner, we have before us a report on the demographic challenges that, from my point of view, are an essential issue for the European Union project: demographic challenges, because we are the continent of the world with the largest population. aged and because we must take into account an issue that I think reflects very well the X-ray of what these demographic challenges are. 80% of the European population lives on 20% of the surface of our Europe. That means that we have very extensive rural areas, with depopulation processes that are really worrying. I want to thank the presence here today of the Commissioner, Mrs Crețu, because it is a reflection of the commitment that the European Commission has regarding this fundamental issue, and I also want to thank, in this first speech, the work carried out by the different shadow rapporteurs, from different political groups, as well as from the staff of our committee, in helping to improve this report that we are bringing to debate today. Europe has significant demographic challenges and next year, 2018, is a year where we are going to face fundamental negotiations, and this Parliament will have to take a political position on this. We will face debates such as the new budgetary framework of the Union and what are the new Structural Funds Regulations. On both issues, it is essential that there is a political position from this Parliament to determine how we deal with the depopulation processes in the European Union. And I am satisfied with the result of the debate and the vote in the Committee on Regional Development on this report, because it raises fundamental issues and we have managed to position ourselves on issues that I think are important in tackling the depopulation processes. First, the establishment of a legal framework. It is essential that we have the possibility of a legal framework defining which are the territories with depopulation processes that have to be addressed as a priority to be able to solve the problems we are facing at the moment. Also in this report we propose that there are budget items in all the Structural Funds Regulations in order to face the challenges faced by regions with depopulation processes. There is an issue that is fundamental and that we have been raising for a long time, and that it is important that it has been reflected in this report, and that is that the GDP, the gross domestic product, is not the only criterion when taking into account or establishing the distribution of funds. And this is a fundamental question. And I say that it is a fundamental question because GDP, being a fundamental and important criterion, cannot be the only one. Other criteria must be taken into account, such as these depopulation processes, aging, dispersion, the rural environment, fundamental issues, because if not, we will find European regions that are the richest in all of Europe, but have no population. on which to launch the operational programs of the Structural Funds. And coordination between the different funds is necessary. Coordination between the Structural Funds, between the common agricultural policy, investment funds, and so on is a fundamental issue. We have to face the masculinization of the rural environment. We have to implement public service policies in rural areas, which are fundamental. The austerity policy has done a lot of damage to our society, but especially to the rural environment, because when we eliminate a teacher from a school in a city it is important, but when we eliminate him from the rural environment we are closing schools. That is why it is essential to make rural spaces attractive spaces so that young men and women can decide to create your future.We don't have much time: the rural environment is dying;We are closing the towns, they will disappear if we are not able to implement committed policies from the European Union to fight against the processes of depopulation.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - President! The Union's cohesion policy provides an opportunity for poorer Member States and regions to catch up, which is in the interests of the European Union as a whole and all its citizens. However, current statistical planning at NUTS 2 level has its limitations and there is often an increase in territorial disparities within a region or a Member State. This, and economic development, then, of course, also has demographic consequences. The solution may be to take this aspect into account when assessing cohesion resources, but the Member States' authorities have no control in this area, so a lack of planning or poor planning contributes to growing territorial inequalities. Greater consideration should also be given to NUTS level 3, as major disruptions within larger regions are masked by potentially favorable statistics, which, however, are only due to the performance of a few development poles.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we are at a turning point in history, with our European societies facing many challenges and transitions. Demographic upheaval must be dealt with in the broader context of sustainability. Responding to democratic challenges requires collective debate about how we can achieve social justice and guarantee a fair and inclusive model for everyone – a model which puts at the forefront not only economic development but, more importantly, the collective and individual well-being of citizens. Touching upon all the key policy areas – such as employment, poverty reduction, urban and rural development, connectivity and support for SMEs – cohesion policy is indeed the right tool to address those challenges. I particularly welcome the focus on women and their role in societies, as well as the call to use the fund for refugees’ inclusion. I would add that, in a fast-changing world characterised by increasing digitisation, robotisation and automation, a future-proof sustainable agenda should be included in a broader reflection on occupational literacy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, cohesion policy must address demographic problems, especially for Greece. On 10/11/2015 I had asked a question about how the problems due to the memorandum will be addressed, because the demographic problems in Greece intensified. I raised the same issue again on 07/29/16 with another question. We have a study by the Berlin Institute in Germany that states that the demographic prospects for Greece are ominous. The study estimates that between 2011 and 2016 Greece lost 3% of its population due to the birth of fewer children due to the economic crisis. Therefore, you understand that due to the memoranda, due to the harsh measures, positive support measures should now be taken by the European Union to deal with the demographic and we expect the Commissioner to explain to us what proposals she has to make on them.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I think the rapporteur, whom I congratulate, has put the issue very well. It is clear that there is an aging population in Europe, but I think the issue has been identified very well in relation to the differences between the population from the urban to the rural areas. And it is very important to keep the population in the villages, to keep them in the countryside; this is the only thing that will make the people of Europe feel that they live in a large space, where things are developing in the most normal way. If the source, which is the countryside, is lost, then we will have to deal with much more acute problems. So the population density that is being transferred to the cities is a huge problem and the only way to deal with it is the cohesion policy to push the people to stay in their homes, in their villages, in the countryside.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my colleague Pérez's report is a good reflection document on cohesion policy and combating depopulation phenomena in Europe. Non-urbanized areas in Europe are home to 113 million people, 12 million farms and 172 million agricultural hectares and contribute to the economy, culture and ecosystems. We have made concrete proposals, including promoting small and medium-sized agricultural and rural and mountain farms, which, using traditional techniques and production methods, exploit natural resources in an integrated and sustainable way, produce products with specific characteristics of quality and can help reverse the trend towards depopulation. Our assessment is therefore positive. The challenges that the territories subject to demographic change face are identified: population aging, low density, low birth rate, constant population losses. Central is the role of the European Social Fund in tackling social exclusion and poverty. Its budget must therefore not be reduced and part of the resources must be allocated to a fund for minimum income, as decided by a large majority by the European Parliament in the report signed by the Five Star Movement.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, demographics, and especially low birth rates, are a very important problem for all European countries. Cohesion policy, in order to eliminate the causes that cause it, must move in the right direction. We must first make a rational distribution of the population in the areas that have productive sources and, using the Community resources, be able to exploit these sources and have primary production. Young people need to be motivated to settle in the countryside, engage in agricultural production, start a family and then be given incentives and protection for motherhood and high-quality health services so that they do not leave the area. these young people.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I have tabled 7 amendments in the Committee on Women's Rights.Two ideas came into the final text of the report, but they are key to tackling Europe's aging challenges.The first is solidarity between the generations.Even a significant increase in the birth rate will not change the fact that in the next 20 years the number of seniors will increase and the number of economically active population will decrease.The second is the establishment of families and their support.Although the rapporteur refused to use the term family mainstreaming, which we proposed, she nevertheless acknowledged that supporting families is a way to improve the demographic situation in the EU.I would therefore like the Commission to take these two ideas into account in all future proposals in the field of regional cohesion.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as in all post-industrial societies, the European population is characterized by an increased longevity rate and a low fertility rate. There is also an increase in population in most urban areas and a decline in most rural and remote areas. These imbalances represent important challenges both for the areas affected by depopulation, and Southern Italy is one of them, and for those affected by population inflows. Cohesion policy has the right tools to help tackle demographic change, but the ESI Funds need to give priority to the problem and there is a need for greater coordination of EU instruments. A change of approach is necessary for the European Union to integrate demographic aspects into all its policies, in order to enable development, especially as regards cohesion, employment, agriculture, environment, research. , employment, education, social policy and transport.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, indeed, demographic change has profound consequences.Population aging, reducing the number of children and young people, as well as moving young people for jobs.What are the causes of this demographic aging and, in fact, the disappearance of dense settlements in some regions?These are mainly insufficient investment, poor infrastructure, low connectivity and limited access to social services, as well as a lack of job opportunities.I am of the opinion that the basic criterion for the distribution of cohesion aid funds should be the criterion of GDP, but we can have a discussion on how to supplement this criterion appropriately.Unfortunately, this report does not fully address this.However, I agree that the problem of population aging needs to be addressed, as the rapporteur suggests in her report.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: - Mr President, for me, the demographic crisis is no less a disaster than all the natural disasters and economic crises we know. And while the European Union has created its own instruments for natural disasters and economic crises, there are no instruments for the demographic crisis. That is why I want to present you with an idea for a European initiative on depopulated regions. Behind it, I mean the following: a package of measures that includes easier access to European funding, preferential conditions for applying for European projects, technical assistance on the ground, so that these regions create administrative capacity and attract more and more investment. We are obliged to do everything with the cohesion policy we have, to create conditions for people to return to their homes and to return the craft to their hands. We can bring human capital back to depopulated regions.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I thank the rapporteur for this excellent report, which highlights that the problem of depopulation is a European problem that we have to solve from a great deal in our institutions. Because, in the end, we all know the consequences of depopulation: there are consequences ranging from environmental to social. But what we have to go is to solve the cause. The cause, which is the lack of equal opportunities due to insufficient investments, a lack of public services and also the lack of companies that will create jobs. And, therefore, we need an effort, positive discrimination from the community budget for those regions, for those regions where there are major problems of depopulation. It cannot be that only the percentage of GDP is the meter to distribute community funds. Cohesion, which is ultimately the heart of Community policy, has to start by seeking internal cohesion between urban and rural. We need your help, Commissioner, to create more investment, to make more public effort, to guarantee equal opportunities in our towns.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: “I listen to this discussion and I am amazed to find that people fail to address the most important cause of demographic collapse.It is simply taking women out of their homes.By sending women to work outside the home, they have fewer children.And everyone here is saying that women should work outside the home and thus cause a demographic collapse.As long as we don't see this elephant standing in the corner of the room, it makes sense to discuss it at all.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, of course I would have liked to start by thanking Ms García Pérez for this report. But allow me as a woman, as a Commissioner, to say that it is inadmissible to have such a speech and to hear such a speech against women in the most democratic House of the European Union. I know your point of view about women. We are not weak, we are not stupid. We are women and we are on an equal footing with you, with all of you. (Applause and cries of ‘Bravo!’) So, above all I would like to warmly thank you for this report prepared by Ms García Pérez. I am very grateful to you for your energy in raising awareness of this important issue of the population of the European Union, and I also want to congratulate you for replying to these kinds of speeches. I was in Poland and I know the reactions in Poland. The Polish people thanked me for taking the floor and I said that this is unacceptable in the 21st century to say that women are stupid, weak. We are not per kilogramme here, Mr! (Referring to Korwin-Mikke)  Your report reminds us of the wide variations in the demographic trends between and within Member States. Already today, many areas in Europe face serious challenges with important social and economic consequences. You know very well that I visited some parts of the depopulated areas in Spain, as well as in northern Europe. I really think this is a very important topic and we have to be very serious. We have a lot of studies showing that population change is determined by the age structure of the population – mortality, fertility and the balance between inward and outward migration. It is not about women staying at home and making children. It is about the economy, it is about families: it is for a better life that they go out because, as you said here, they have no opportunities and not enough investment, not enough means for a better life. So these kinds of thing evolve very slowly, and as a result demographic trends also evolve slowly, including at the regional level.  So it is our duty with public policies to take these changes into account and, as you already said, the Cohesion Policy already contains many provisions to address the specific needs of geographical areas suffering from severe and permanent natural and demographic handicaps. Measures identified by Member States show a variety of responses to demographic challenges. However, whatever actions you take, they might be taken having inclusion and equality as a precondition. And this in turn means providing essential infrastructures such as child care, health care and long-term care facilities. Another important question to address is the integration of migrants across Europe, and I am very grateful that you have included this because it is a challenge that was not foreseen but which we have to face these days. As the report indicates, we must support Member States by reinforcing measures to tackle this issue. You have already underlined here that it is our responsibility to ensure that all migrants are integrated, and this means that they can fully participate in all aspects of our societies and communities, be it social or economic. At the end of the day this is clearly a win-win situation. For one thing, the alternative is unthinkable. Exclusion in any form breeds resentment, confrontation, extremism and sometimes violence. Integration, on the other hand, is a promise of stability and of peace, not to mention the economic contribution that migrants, usually young people, can bring to an ageing population. I believe that the European Union funds, including the Cohesion Policy, can and should provide opportunities for Member States to support such integration measures. In her report Ms García Pérez also touches on, and I saw that many Members touched on, GDP and the possibility of having new indicators to allocate cohesion policy funding. I agree with all of you that GDP alone does not accurately enough reflect the needs of a region, as it leaves out crucial parameters such as quality of life, social inclusion, level of employment or sustainable development. This is why, to complement GDP, the Commission is investigating other indicators, including demographic change. Regarding the new ex ante conditionality on national strategies for demographic development, I will be very honest with you. You know very well that, at the level of political groups, we are all reflecting on how to reduce the overall number of ex ante conditionalities and simplify the mechanism of accession to the European funds. Ex ante conditionalities have proved to be the most effective mechanism to ensure the right framework for investment, but at the same time they are a burden for beneficiaries, and I am of the opinion that we should be careful not to overload the Cohesion Policy with too many conditions. Anyhow, after this very fruitful debate, and listening carefully to your interventions, I am more than ever convinced that cohesion policy cannot tackle demographic change in the EU through a one-size-fits-all approach. Some regions will face sharp population decline while others will experience steady population growth. Demographic changes in the EU therefore call for a differentiated approach. We need to ensure policy coherence and flexibility to address this specific situation, and this can only be done through close cooperation with local and regional authorities.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: speaker.- Mr President, yes, a point of order, very briefly.During the debate there was an intervention, by a Member, who has raised an issue, repeatedly now, and which I believe is discriminatory with regard to women in the European Union.Therefore, I ask the Bureau to study these statements, which have also been repeated, to see if any type of sanction is possible in this regard.Equality is a fundamental value in the European Union, and we cannot allow discriminatory messages to be transmitted in this House with regard to women, who are half the population of the European Union.Therefore, I ask the Board to study the content of these statements, to enable the implementation of some type of sanction in this regard.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, such an analysis will be made.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 14 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Demographic change is a challenge for today's European society, which is closely linked to the effects of globalization, the benefits of the free movement of people within the single European area and, last but not least, the aging of the population. These demographic imbalances affect both urban and rural areas, and migration trends to more developed regions have led to population movements resulting in depopulation of poorer areas. In this context, investment through cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy has given priority to poorer regions and rural areas. The aim was to strengthen infrastructure, access to services, encourage investment in rural areas and, in particular, attract young people to the agricultural sector, with some positive results. Therefore, demographic change should be a priority in the revision of the regulations of the funds that finance the reduction of territorial disparities. For the post-2020 period, investments in basic infrastructure in depopulated areas and access to digital technologies are still required. I believe that GDP should remain the main indicator for classifying areas with major and permanent demographic challenges, along with other relevant demographic indicators of an economic and social nature.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up. - The demographic changes facing Europe and the imbalances they may generate at European level risk hindering the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. become accessible and competitive. First and foremost, specific measures are needed to encourage young people to remain in their region and thus ensure a sustainable renewal of generations. On the other hand, cohesion policy must promote the employability and inclusion of women, especially mothers who have difficulty finding employment, which is why women need to have access to training programs and education, in order to be able to meet the needs of the labor market, on the one hand, and reliable structures with a continuous program of care for children of all ages, including for pre-school education, on the other. In addition, the implementation of the EU Smart Villages Action Plan will be beneficial, requiring policies to pay particular attention to bridging the digital divide between rural and urban areas, and to develop the potential of rural connectivity and digitization.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - Dear Members! Demographic change is a decades-long social problem with many and varied causes, and therefore requires an interdisciplinary approach and approach. It is indisputable that the fight against depopulation must be one of the objectives of cohesion policy. In many cases, it is the economically disadvantaged regions that are being hit repeatedly by an aging population, the emigration of young people of working age and a negative natural increase. Cohesion policy, while retaining its fundamental role, can also make an effective contribution to achieving demographic goals. At the same time, it is unfortunate that migration is mentioned in the report as a possible solution to reverse Europe's declining population. I believe that it is completely wrong to think that European regions that are lagging behind should catch up with migration measures. On this issue, immigration policy cannot be placed before active family policy. Rather, the EU should look for answers on how to revitalize the traditional family model and how to promote family-building and family support measures at EU level. I would cite Hungary as a positive example, where these measures have been an integral part of government policy for some time.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - The composition of the population of the European continent is changing, with an accelerating aging of the population. It is indisputable that this demographic change, the declining proportion of the working age population, is placing a significant economic, social and financial burden on the Member States, especially in terms of maintaining the welfare state. The declining population calls for a rethink of Member States' policies and the search for appropriate responses. Many Western European countries think, as is reflected in the report under discussion, that it is possible and desirable to offset the decline in their countries' populations through immigration. We in Hungary do not agree with this. We believe that immigration involves many risks (such as security policy), integration is difficult, and in most cases ineffective, leading to the emergence of parallel societies. We can expect a solution to the demographic crisis by increasing the level of family benefits and focusing on families and their children. The Hungarian government is working to encourage as many people as possible to take home and start a large family. The numbers speak for themselves: between 2010 and 2018, the level of family benefits doubled in the Hungarian budget, and 2018 was declared the Year of Families by the government.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. - Demographic change and the depopulation of certain areas are a problem and a threat to Europe in the future. It is right that the report calls for the EU to integrate demographic aspects and family support into all policy areas, but I cannot agree that the greatest burden of tackling demography should lie on the shoulders of cohesion policy. Cohesion policy is a privileged and effective instrument that helps to balance the economic levels of countries and regions in the EU and leads to the overall convergence of the Union. If we look at the demographic map of the Union (proportion of citizens over the age of 65), it is clear that in the foreseeable future the demographic problem affects more richer EU countries than those with lower GDP levels, and it is clear that the richer countries they can solve themselves. The demographic criterion would weaken the current GDP criterion. In the long run (measured by today's birth rate), the problem, with a few exceptions, affects almost everyone in the EU and should therefore be addressed horizontally using various instruments. However, the report has the right emphasis on tackling the problem of depopulation in some regions.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The situation is dramatic and urgent. The countryside is being depopulated and some cities receive population without being able to absorb it adequately. This leads to less availability of public services in rural areas and to an overload of them in cities. The consequences are dire, socially and environmentally. Let us remember that the fires suffered in Spain and Portugal a few weeks ago are a consequence of the neglect of rural areas. Fewer services in rural areas imply more emigrants to cities that cannot absorb them; and thus in a spiral cycle very difficult to contain. All of this is avoidable, with adequate policies, which are certainly not the ones the Union is applying. An example is the CAP, which only favors large landowners and penalizes small farmers, which is one of the major causes of rural depopulation. The countryside and cities need each other, they are interdependent. Let us change the productive model, favor small businesses and farmers and guarantee quality public services that allow the rural population to be established; This will bring a better quality of life in cities and in the countryside, desirable environmental conditions and a greater distribution of wealth.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of the report by Olli Ludvigsson, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Retail Financial Services Action Plan (2017/2066 (INI) (A8-0326 / 2017).

name: Olle Ludvigsson
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! EU financial services markets for individuals and small businesses are still underdeveloped. Therefore, it is important that the Commission now does its utmost to complete the work on the Capital Markets Union, where the deepening of the internal market for financial services is a cornerstone. It will be interesting to follow what concrete measures the Commission is actually proposing until 2019. At the same time, there are no measures for most of the issues raised by Parliament in the Green Paper on Financial Services. There is still a lack of a holistic approach with the aim of increasing transparency, promoting growth and innovation, reducing the high fees for private pension insurance, mutual funds and other financial services. Digitization will increasingly change consumer behavior and the financial markets. Therefore, our legal framework needs to be adapted at a rapid pace in order to remove cross-border barriers in order to strengthen our European fintech companies in global competition. In my report, I therefore call on the Commission to examine the possibility of introducing a 29th financial services system. We must also address direct deviations in the functioning of the internal market. For example, banks today can cancel debit and credit cards for EU citizens who choose to move to another Member State. Clear EU rules are needed here, which give the national supervisory authorities the power to act against banks. If we are to seriously breathe new life into European cooperation, citizens need to feel that the Union is constantly working to remove obstacles to internal mobility, as we did with the roaming charge. In the future, it needs to be easier for consumers to change financial service providers. That is why I would like to call on the Commission to present a specific legislative proposal that counteracts so-called geoblocking of financial services in the internal market. In the slightly longer term, the Commission will need to present a proposal for a pan-European electronic identification system. With regard to the concrete measures taken by the Commission, I think it is a good idea to propose an amendment to the Regulation on cross-border payments in order to ensure equal charges for cross-border payments and national payments for currencies other than the euro. Another issue is that of 'dynamic currency conversion', which means that consumers today have the choice to pay in euros or in their national currency when paying and withdrawing abroad. It usually becomes more expensive for customers to pay in their national currency. Customers need clear information and preferably an overview of which choice is the most advantageous at each time of purchase and at each ATM withdrawal. With regard to the Commission's statement on developing the internal market for consumer credit, I believe that it is very important to develop effective measures at the same time to counteract over-indebtedness in households. That is why I believe it is necessary to develop an EU credit rating system. I am convinced that we need to see more jobs and increased growth in today's Europe to curb today's expressions of dissatisfaction. With your own income, more people can save in simple and secure financial services to create a better life in the future. In this way, we can ensure a fairer Europe for all. I would like to end by thanking the shadow rapporteurs for their good and fruitful cooperation, and I look forward to hearing from the Commission's forthcoming proposals in the field of financial services.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the action plan aims to set out the next steps for creating a true single market for retail financial services. However, it is important for the Czech Republic that its currency is not the euro, and therefore it is particularly affected by the section on transaction fees. The problem is that charges for cross-border and domestic euro payments are already covered by the 2009 Cross-Border Payments Regulation, but payments in currencies other than the euro are not covered by this Regulation and charges for such cross-border transactions remain high and well above purely domestic transactions in currencies other than the euro. It is clear that the level of these charges also discourages consumers from transacting, in particular, small-scale transactions in these other currencies. I therefore very much welcome the fact that the proposal includes measures to extend the scope of the regulation on cross-border payments to these other transactions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the report on action for retail financial services is particularly interesting. I will focus on the issue of transparency when taking a loan, because we know the mortgage loans in Swiss franc clause and this concerns at least 70,000 families in Greece, but it also concerns many other borrowers across Europe because, with the increase in foreign exchange value of the Swiss franc, borrowers actually pay the installments and not only do not repay, but owe even more money. This is an issue that has preoccupied us in Greece and in the Committee on Petitions, and there must be an answer to this question, because the financial ruin of the borrowers themselves continues. In practice, this was not a loan but essentially a stock exchange transaction, of which the borrowers themselves were not informed. Measures are also needed on the part of the Commission, Mrs Crețu.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the numerous concerns expressed by the European Parliament in its resolution on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services have not yet been answered by the Commission. For example, there is no coherent solution to the difficult practices that consumers face when making ATM withdrawals involving currency conversion and no solution that allows the consumer, among other things, to fully understand and control the condition. In this perspective, the Commission should step up its work to promote mutual recognition and interoperability of digital recognition techniques, without compromising the security level of existing systems or their ability to meet the requirements of the European Union framework. to combat money laundering.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: - Online shopping for goods as well as services is increasing day by day.We consumers have changed our shopping habits drastically over the last decade, so it happened a few days ago on Asian Black Friday that they recorded 256,000 purchases per second online on Alibaba.However, when it comes to financial services, we still have big concerns.In addition to concerns, this trade is also hampered by barrier numbers, such as ignorance of legislation in other countries, transparency in foreign currency conversion, consumer protection rules, as well as technological barriers.Our common goal is the single market, so I support all efforts to get as close as possible to it in the field of financial services.I believe that this would also be a greater incentive in this area to lower prices, so I welcome this Commission action plan.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I recognize that the rapporteur has made efforts to have a report closer to the needs, but we cannot follow the final decisions because, as we have been talking about during the various negotiations, the problem of retail financial services is not a problem of information, be it about taxes or currencies, is not a problem of transparency, it is not just a problem of digital inclusion, nor is it a problem of communication. The problem is the products themselves, they are those that people have access to at the bank counter when they get there. In Portugal, there was a group of injured BES and many people suffered from these products. We continue to have structured, speculative products and that is truly the problem: is that people's savings can still be dedicated to the banking casino and not as savings, and that is why I want banking to be more conservative and products are much simpler. That is what we need and that is why we cannot accompany the rapporteur in his proposal.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Ludvigsson on this report. I think it is a most welcome expression of Parliament’s strong support for the deepening of the single market in retail financial services. We also think that a single market for retail financial services which can rely on innovative solutions is very welcome. To get there we need: first, to increase consumer trust and empower consumers; second, to reduce legal and regulatory obstacles for businesses when offering services across borders; and, third, to support digital innovation in financial services for the benefit of consumers. We are moving fast to implement our Action Plan. At the beginning of 2018 we expect to come forward with a legislative proposal to lower the charges on all cross-border payments throughout the European Union, in particular for non-EU countries. To achieve this, we propose to expand the scope of the Cross-border Payments Regulation and we welcome your support on this. This is particularly important for our fellow citizens from countries which are outside the euro zone. To support the provision of financial services across borders, we will also aim to facilitate the cross-border use of electronic identification. The reality is that more and more Europeans are living and working in an EU country that is not their own. Highly mobile citizens need a means of electronic identification, allowing banks to know their customers wherever they may reside in the European Union. We will bring together the required expertise on e—identification and anti-money laundering to make sure that providers of financial services can work with customers all over Europe.  Lower transaction costs and e—identification across borders are key to empowering consumers. It is a way to help them take advantage of the best financial services that are available all across the European Union. But we also need more market transparency. Therefore we will promote high quality standards of websites which allow to consumers to compare various offers. Moreover, we will investigate any barriers that may prevent consumers from switching to better offers. This will also put us in a better position to assess the possible benefits of additional European product regimes, as suggested in your report. Along the same lines, we will explore ways to facilitate access to loans across borders. We will also address in a more efficient manner the over-indebtedness of consumers linked to credit activities. We will seek to introduce common standards to assess the capacity to take out a loan. We will also reflect on the common principles for lending.  Thank you all for your interventions. This report and our discussion confirm that we share the same vision, namely that the European Union must ensure that all European cities have equal access to financial services of the highest quality. We should always remember that consumers are, first and foremost, citizens. This means that we need to put in place a framework capable of preventing any abusive or opaque practices. It also means providing innovative solutions to overcome any obstacle, whether legal or behavioural, that might unfairly hinder consumers. This is precisely what our Action Plan is about: achieving a single market in consumer financial services that is transparent, fair and innovative. The European Union cannot afford to lag behind on this matter.  Let me conclude by mentioning another key enabler of a deeper single market for financial services, FinTech. The Action Plan referred to our internal task force and the public consultation on FinTech. In early 2018 we will present the fruits of this work and table a FinTech Action Plan. It will offer a vision for a technology-driven and globally competitive financial sector.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner.I understand that the rapporteur already feels some success.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 14 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The action plan drawn up by the Commission on creating a single market for retail financial services is presented as a benefit for all citizens.Rather than increasing competition and the protection of retail investors as the report hopes, the aforementioned market will instead favor the concentration and oligopoly of large "too big to fail" banking groups and amplify the already unsustainable financial imbalancesin the Euro area.There are no effective and sufficient safeguards for citizens - both consumers and small investors - who, instead of benefiting from the initiative, thus risk being endangered.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, at dawn on Sunday, November 5, there was a terrible fire at the Ornua factory in Ávila, and it has been completely destroyed. Ornua is an Irish multinational dedicated to dairy products and has a plant in the Vicolozano industrial estate. This fateful situation puts the work of 120 employees and a large number of farmers from Avila who supply this factory at risk. It is urgent and a priority to rebuild the plant in the shortest possible time and to guarantee the salary and employment of the workers. The Junta de Castilla y León has reacted urgently and has committed actions under its jurisdiction, but the Union must and must help through the EAFRD operational program in its reconstruction and with the initiatives supported by the European Social Fund for workers affected. From here I want to draw attention to this terrible event that affects many families in Avila and ask for the solidarity of the European institutions and, especially, the solidarity of the Commission.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am protesting against the confusing fiscal measures taken by the Romanian Government. I want to draw attention to the economic and social instability caused by the Social Democratic Party. The upheaval of the social security system and the taxation of individuals' incomes has managed to displease both unions and employers. Six million employment contracts will be affected by the amendment of the tax code through an emergency ordinance whose constitutionality is being challenged. Even the European Commission warned last week that Romania's economy would be affected by current government policies. According to the Commission's forecast, Romania risks a worrying budget deficit in the coming years, despite the increase in gross domestic product based on private consumption. Public investment is being sacrificed and foreign investors are being driven away by legal uncertainty. Unfortunately, the incompetence of the rulers seriously damages the Romanian economy.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, nuclear fusion is the holy grail of energy research, with the potential to deliver the energy equivalent of 10 000 tons of coal from the atoms in this small bottle of water, and with no CO2 emissions. Commercial fusion now has a realistic future but that is a future at risk because of Brexit. The UK Atomic Energy Authority operates the world’s largest magnetic fusion experiment – the Joint European Torus (JET) – with scientists coming from all over Europe. This project is far too big for any one nation state alone. It is the classic example of the economies of scale we achieve through our European Union. This world-leading research facility is in my constituency and you cannot simply put it on a truck. I hope that Mr Barnier and Ms May are both listening. JET needs Europe, Europe needs JET and the UK’s place is in Euratom.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: - Mr President! At the opening of the plenary session a few hours ago today, the President of Parliament Antonio Tajani promised to send a letter of protest to the President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko. The reason is clear: the recently adopted Ukrainian Education Law prohibits national minorities in Ukraine from receiving general education in their mother tongues: Slovak, Hungarian, Polish, Greek, Bulgarian. But in reality the same thing is happening in Latvia at the moment. 28% of all Latvian students study in minority schools in Latvia, and the plan of the Ministry of Latvia provides for instruction only in Latvian. This means phasing out schools. According to a survey commissioned by our ministry, only 2% of children from minority students support this type of reform. Equally low is the support for parents and teachers. Dear colleagues! It turns out that another government is being formed in the European Union that intends to jeopardize the democratic values ​​of the European Union in order to achieve its selfish goals.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - We will be debating here the rule of law in Malta and Poland, human rights and democracy far away in Somalia, Sudan and Madagascar. But Spain and Catalonia, that is apparently taboo. Citizens do not understand that. They see brutal police violence against Catalan voters. They see leaders of a democratic, peaceful civil movement being imprisoned, teachers being prosecuted for the content of their lessons, elected politicians being jailed for rebellion and threatened with sentences of up to 30 years. Citizens are well aware that this is not in line with democratic principles, with the fundamental rights and freedoms that we share together in the European Union. EU leaders remain silent, look away, or worse, in Juncker's case, support repression. Believe me, there will come a time when history will judge Juncker, Tajani, Timmermans and so on. There should be no political prisoners and certainly not in the European Union. We cannot remain silent. I am not going to remain silent and not rest until the political Catalan prisoners are released.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, today I want to denounce the situation of 10 Catalan political prisoners in Spanish jails, eight of them members of the Catalan government and two of them former Members of the European Parliament – Raül Romeva and Oriol Junqueras. They have been jailed without being condemned, and they risk four years in prison before trial with the Spanish justice. Their crime? To be loyal to a democratic mandate of the Catalan people. Two years ago, in 2015, pro-independence political parties won in Catalonia an absolute majority in the Catalan parliament thanks to two million votes, with the highest turn-out ever in our history: 77%. Dear colleagues, let me remind you that to declare independence was not illegal. The Spanish tribunals also did not declare illegal in 2015 the electoral programme of pro-independence parties, so this is why we call for the immediate release of all Catalan prisoners so they can run in the elections next 21 December. Llibertat presos catalans!

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, with the complaints against the Catalan Government and the Bureau of the Parliament, an unprecedented path of criminalization of political positions began, a regime of exception and repression. The Commission will say that it cannot interfere in the judicial system of a Member State. He will say that it is an internal matter. But how long can he sustain that answer? Seven members of a legitimate government and two social leaders have been jailed, and its president and several councilors are in Brussels after facing a Euro order. Is this how political conflicts in the Union are solved? Will they allow that every time the Spanish State does not like the political position of an autonomous government, it suspends or imprisons it because it is an internal matter? It is not an internal matter. It is a political option supported by citizens who chose a government to fulfill it, and it has done so. The European Union has to meet this challenge. The Catalan people are not going to give up. Hundreds of thousands demonstrated this Saturday, and we also demand, here today, freedom for political prisoners.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President! Each EU member state has transposed the European Convention into its own legislation and has an obligation to respect the rights of all citizens, including minorities. Time and time again, however, we see that this is not happening, but the EU has no tools to actually force its members to respect all its citizens. However, we are not only national citizens, but we are also citizens of the Union, and in all its activities the Union must respect the principle of equality between its citizens, which must receive equal attention from the Union's institutions, bodies and agencies in accordance with Article 9 of the Treaty. Today we have a deep and protracted conflict in one of our member countries. I'm talking about Spain. As a result, elected Catalan government members, including former EU parliamentarians, have been detained indefinitely for carrying out what they went to the polls - a mandate given to them by voters - because the state, the EU member , has refused all dialogue and change for many years. It is in such situations that Union citizenship must play a role. Where the state lacks, the EU can intervene. Today, Catalans are wondering where the EU is or whether it is even worthwhile to join. It is not an internal matter, it is about Union citizens, and they should not be imprisoned for their ideas.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, just two years ago, a terrible terrorist attack bloodied Paris on November 13, 2015. I want to pay tribute to the 130 people whose lives were cut short by Daesh on that day. This drama is reminiscent of those few verses by Paul Verlaine which one might think were written to show its horror: "such a dreadful death on a dragon shows itself, passing like thunder in the midst of humans, overturning , overwhelming, everything she encounters, and holding a faulx in her livid hands. " Let’s never forget what happened, but lighting candles and reciting poems is not enough. All necessary measures must be taken to ensure that such a tragedy never happens again. Let us crush the caliphate of Daesh, strengthen our intelligence and security services, close the Salafist mosques that preach hatred and defend our values ​​and our identity steadfastly against Islamist fundamentalism.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman!Everyone is noticing that the propaganda of the greatest fraud in human history, namely global warming, is coming to an end.That the thesis about man-made global warming is beginning to retreat among scientists is one thing, but I am demanding that the European Union, which has spent enormous amounts of money on this fight against global warming, investigates who benefited from the financial benefitsout of this supposed fight against global warming who decided to spend that money.Because this is really a lot of money.Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.Thank you for your attention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: - We are proud that one of the greatest achievements of the European Union is the free movement of people.We also encourage it with many support projects, which is of course also evident with each new financial perspective.However, for both the future of the Member States and the future of Europe, it is important to ask ourselves who is immigrating to our countries and who is leaving them.In 2015, almost 15,000 people emigrated from Slovenia, many of them young and educated.Due to the search for a job, a little more than 5,500 people moved back to Slovenia, but with relatively lower education, of which 3,300 people from non-EU countries.I wonder what kind of development potential countries like Slovenia can still have, and there is too little talk about the brain drain that will mark our future.This means that there will also be a two-speed Europe in the future.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: - Dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the implementation of cohesion policy is, in my view, one of the major challenges facing the European Union. At the same time, these policies represent a huge opportunity for development, reducing gaps and, essentially, well-being for people. For my country, Romania, even if the degree of absorption can certainly be improved, the availability of cohesion funds is a priority. It is indisputable that a large percentage of the amounts allocated through the cohesion funds go back to the so-called net contributors in various forms, such as purchases of goods and services from those Member States. For these reasons, I believe that maintaining a high level of available resources under these policies certainly remains essential for everyone. I therefore invite you to use all the means at our disposal to support a level of cohesion funds at least equal to the current one in the next budget year.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - This week has been 100 years since the terrible night when the Bolshevik Party took power in Russia.It was the beginning of this bloody century and we had the right to have a very strong "never again" sound that day that would remind us of this terrible age.First of all, our memory is entitled to millions of murdered people, millions of victims, hundreds of thousands of people who resisted communism and have the right to our homage, enslaved nations, and enslaved half a century of Europe.Unfortunately, we did not hear such strong declarations that day.It is good that there will be a debate on this this week in this Parliament.But until communism with its aspirations, with its hatred of religion, of the nation-state and of the family, is definitely condemned, the world will not be safe.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Parliament cannot judge judges, but judges cannot prohibit debates and prosecute Members for raising and voting on them. Nor should they imprison members of a legitimate government - seven in total, among whom are my dear friends and former MPs Raül Romeva and Oriol Junqueras - through decisions harshly criticized, as arbitrary, by Amnesty International. This degradation of democracy is a European issue. Spanish nationalism must assume its diversity, and when millions of Catalans have been unsuccessfully demanding for years to be heard, recognized and respected, organizing an unauthorized referendum to overcome the blockade is the most peaceful thing that can be done. Repressing it with sticks and by criminal means is as unacceptable as it is useless. Because politics, a mediation like the one attempted by Basque President Iñigo Urkullu, is the only possible solution. Please, Mrs. Creţu, go ahead and send this message to Mr. Juncker: Get the batteries going. Help find solutions and take advantage of the fact that Basques and Catalans were involved from the beginning in the European project, convinced that federalism, free membership, is more useful, constructive and modern for Europe than the indissoluble unity of any country.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, one of the greatest exponents of job insecurity occurs in the agricultural sector, a situation that is aggravated in the case of day laborers. In the countryside, we are witnessing a decline in rights, the systematic breach of collective bargaining agreements and, in addition, committing fraud against Social Security by not paying the social contributions of the workers. This is the case of the companies Baena Franco and Agrícola Espino, from Andalusia. Both companies have used a perverse system, that of peonies, to commit this fraud against Social Security, against companies that act legally and against female workers. The Spanish Ministry of Employment recognizes this obligation of employers and, however, sanctions the workers, putting their subsistence at risk when the non-payment of contributions occurs, as if they were responsible, and looks the other way when it has You have to act against unscrupulous employers to whom you provide coverage while maintaining this system. This fraud has to be stopped, and it's very simple. We must end the peonies. This has been demanded by the Platform of People Affected by the PER, hundreds of women of all ages who want to have a dignified life achieved through their work.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, two days ago there was in Barcelona the most extraordinary demonstration that has taken place in recent years and yesterday there was a large demonstration in Brussels. What happens in Catalonia? There are ten political prisoners in preventive detention, two of them are recognized pacifist social leaders. The democratically elected Catalan Government has been dismissed, eight of its members in jail, five in exile, members of the Parliament Board sentenced to preventive detention, seven hundred mayors sued, teachers who must go to court for talking about police brutality. They have entered printing presses and weeklies without judicial permission, they have broken the judicial guarantees with the National Court assuming powers that, by law, do not correspond to it. Elections have been called for those who do not have the power to do so and who keep their opponents in jail. This is not what the founding fathers of the Union wanted, because that should not happen in a democratic state of the 21st century; and it does not scandalize political leaders, but it does scandalize Democrats. What a shame! Shame on you!

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this month we celebrate the anniversary of the end of the communist regime in Eastern Europe and the fall of the Berlin Wall. Last week we remembered the one-hundred-year anniversary of the Bolshevik takeover of power in Russia. The legacy of communist repression is still visible in our countries. That is why we need to make sure that the legacy of this criminal regime is presented in a relevant context. Against the background of these November anniversaries, I would like to touch on the issue of the House of European History and its exhibition, notably the part which concerns the 20th century. There are studies that suggest that this exhibition does not reflect the communist tyranny in Central and Eastern Europe. It does not even mention important events such as the Budapest Uprising or Prague Spring, or dissidents like Václav Havel and others. The European Parliament has some power over this institution, so we should push for changing the exhibition appropriately.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, two months ago the headlines screamed of the crisis of cancellations at Ryanair. Yet I fear the calculation that Ryanair bosses made has paid off. Their profits are up, the negative publicity has subsided, the news agenda has moved on, and yet the misery for pilots continues. I recently met Ryanair pilots at Stansted Airport and they told me of a climate of fear, scared that if they speak out Ryanair will move them to a far-flung base – Ryanair pilots who are self-employed and do not get sick pay, so they turn up to work ill. What price safety? It is literally only the time in the air that is paid, not taxiing on the tarmac, not weather or security delays. I heard of a pilot who was at work for 14 hours, but paid for under one hour. We cannot allow Ryanair to fly out of the news agenda so quickly. They need a turbulent ride until they end these employment practices which are unfair and wrong.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to introduce you to the scandalous behavior of the Serbian authorities this weekend. They arrested medics who went on a humanitarian mission in the western Bulgarian suburbs, today in the territory of the Republic of Serbia. You can imagine the arrest of doctors, of medics who go to provide free humanitarian medical care. Let me remind you that the western outskirts of Bulgaria were illegally occupied in 1920 and since then a policy of ethnic cleansing and genocide has been pursued there. Let me remind you that the Republic of Serbia claims to be a candidate for membership in the European Union. Let me remind you that this country plays a double role and a double standard and tries to weave in two looms, to play in two weddings. Let me remind you that this is, to put it mildly, non-European behavior - the arrest of doctors who have gone to help people who do not have access to health care. Ladies and gentlemen, I bring this issue to your attention, I will present it to the chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, to the rapporteur on Serbia's progress, to the shadow rapporteurs. Serbia must learn to follow European rules if it wants to be part of the European Union. Otherwise he will get a veto from us for sure.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the Commission’s working programme for 2018 will very soon present Serbia and Montenegro as frontrunner candidates for EU membership. This is very good, but the question remains: What will happen in the region when Serbia goes forward and Kosovo does not? Will it ease tensions in Kosovo? In the case of Bosnia, what will happen? Will this move ease ethnic tensions in Bosnia or worsen them? The Balkans is a fragile region, with a history of war, genocide and nationalistic narratives. The decision to put forward two countries will be perceived in the rest of the region as a reward, despite the war and genocide which these countries’ societies have now left behind. Even worse, it might be perceived as a new EU anti-Muslim policy. Therefore, I beg the Commission to include all the countries of the Western Balkans in the working programme. These countries are certainly at different levels, but all of them should be allowed to take some steps forward from where they are.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Efacec Energia and Efacec Engenharia e Sistemas, headquartered in the district of Porto, are in a restructuring process that foresees the elimination of 409 jobs.The Efacec group has received support from the NSRF in the last five years in the amount of 11 million euros.In addition, the company's financial information shows that, compared to the previous year, in the last year there was an increase in efficiency of more than 7 million euros.As Community support is involved, does the European Commission require any compensation?Shouldn't you be defending the maintenance of jobs?On the last 10th, 250 workers went on strike and, on the next 23rd of November, they will fight for their jobs again.The European Commission's role should be to support them and not to finance their dismissals.Commissioner, when it comes to attacking workers' rights, the European Commission has not forgotten to intervene.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, during this week, in this chamber, we are going to discuss the rule of law and democracy in Member States, such as Malta or Poland, and it is good that this is the case. We need to do these debates, because we cannot allow these fundamental principles and values ​​to erode in any part of the European Union. But there is something else that the European institutions cannot afford. And it is the use of double standards and the use of the double yardstick. Because the reality is that, in another Member State, in the Spanish State, we have eight members of the legitimate Government of Catalonia in prison, unjustly deprived of liberty. They have not committed any crime. They have not stolen. All they have done is put the ballot boxes and let us vote, and, furthermore, the order of the judge that has sent them to prison is a real kick to the rule of law. Therefore, let us also look at what is happening in the Spanish State ... (The speaker ends his intervention in Catalan.)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to draw attention to one of the biggest problems facing consumers in Europe today.For criminal activity with used cars, especially for turning kilometers and fraud with the history of the vehicle.Every year, millions of European customers are victims of illegal practices with fraudulent kilometers.It is worth noting that surveys estimate that up to 30% of cars are sold on the European market, with damage amounting to € 9.6 billion a year.It is essential to stop this illegal activity, and I repeatedly call on the European Commission to take up this issue and, as it addresses the dual quality of food, to tackle crime related to fraud in the used car market.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, tonight it will be 6º C in Calais, next week even colder, and the week after that even colder again. Imagine your children sleeping under a bit of plastic in those temperatures through a long, harsh winter, if indeed they can sleep at all. We are 42 days from Christmas, a time of compassion, goodwill and celebration, but for those kids it will be none of those things. We know this is a challenge that is shared across Europe, but tonight I ask the UK Government to re-open the Dubs Amendment, to fill the places made available for some of those kids in desperate and dangerous circumstances and, in order to give those kids some hope for their future, to do so now before the long, harsh winter sets in.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Mister President! Genocide is just beginning in Western Cameroon. Since the end of 2016, the violence has escalated, driven by President Biya and the government. The conflict worsened when at least 20 demonstrators from the English-speaking minority were shot dead by soldiers in October during the symbolic proclamation of the Republic of Ambazonia: state of emergency, cell phone traffic stopped, several dozen demonstrators arrested, and well over a hundred killed by military force. Right now: the license of the Catholic hospital St. Martin de Porres in the city of Njinikom has been revoked. Many people shot dead by security forces were treated there. Around 20,000 anglophones fled the violence to Nigeria. We expressly demand: No violence against the English-speaking minority. We demand a clear message from the EU, France and Great Britain: No European country - especially not old colonial powers - must be responsible for violating human rights! Together with the regional association of free voters in Hesse, I am calling for a blue helmet to be deployed in the region. We need well-functioning arms export controls and international concepts to protect the civilian population in such areas of civil war.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I will make a reference to Lebanon. We are all aware of what has been going on there in recent weeks; there is a great danger that we will see a new war begin, equivalent to the war we saw in Syria. That is why I think the Commission must act, talk to Mrs Mogherini and see how we can prevent a new outbreak of disaster in this country and the surrounding area. Imagine a war with Hezbollah, Iran, Saudi Arabia, and I do not know who else will be involved. The European Union must not turn a deaf ear this time and try to find solutions to the humanitarian problem that will arise. Please act, as far as we can, in order to contain this great danger, this great possibility, through diplomatic means.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last week those negotiating the Brexit agreement appeared to reach a stalemate and we now look to the summit next month and I hope that sufficient progress can be made there in order for the future arrangements between the UK and Europe to be agreed. We should remind ourselves at this time that this Parliament’s resolution recognises the unique situation and the special circumstances on the island of Ireland, and that any solutions will have to be mindful of this, and that means protecting the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts.  The 1998 Good Friday Agreement, voted by people across the island of Ireland, was underpinned and was supported by the European Union. Now we have North-South cooperation on the island of Ireland in many areas, in more than a hundred areas in health, education, and environment, and we need that to continue. Northern Ireland needs to stay within the EU regulatory regime if that is to continue, and that means within the Customs Union or within the Single Market. I think we need to bear that in mind when we are looking again at the negotiations that will occur next month.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Conservative MP Chris Heaton-Harris, a former Member of this House and a Eurosceptic, recently wrote to UK university vice-chancellors asking for the names of professors who teach European affairs, with particular reference to Brexit. Ignoring the long tradition of academic freedom that universities consider crucial to their success, his letter asks for a copy of each university syllabus and any online lectures on Brexit.  Labour Members of the European Parliament wish to express our concern at what appears to be a deliberate attempt to intimidate academic institutions. While the government may have disowned Mr Heaton-Harris’s actions, its failure to speak out more firmly about the behaviour of one of its own parliamentary whips displays a lack of commitment to ensuring space for free, open and informed debate in respect of politically contentious issues. Beyond reaffirming strongly that academic freedom is non-negotiable, we want to support universities teaching about all levels of our democracy, and reiterate that education is key in the functioning of a healthy society, in particular citizenship education.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to draw attention to a problem that concerns smaller municipalities and cities, especially in the rings around the capitals.This applies to both the Czech Republic and the European Union.These smaller cities are affected by huge demands on infrastructure and the availability of public services.I am talking about the problem of suburbanisation, which is the result of the movement of large sections of the population from those large cities to adjacent areas, which is putting pressure on local and regional government.It is important to call on the Commission to use cohesion policy measures to stop the growing emigration from sparsely populated regions, which lack adequate infrastructure and a sufficient level of services.These are the basic conditions for keeping families with children in particular, and I am glad that Commissioner Creţu is sitting here to hear my contribution.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.
